PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SCIACCA
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a matter of privilege. On Thursday last, 11 November 1993, I was served with a writ of summons issued out of the Supreme Court of the ACT, dated 21 September, naming one Anthony Robinson as plaintiff, myself as first named defendant and Federal Capital Press of Australia Pty Ltd as the second defendant. The writ was issued by a Canberra firm of solicitors—namely, Gary Robb and Associates of 29 Torrens Street, Braddon, ACT. The writ seeks damages for libel against me arising from a letter I forwarded on Friday, 20 August of this year to Senator the Hon. Bob McMullan, the responsible minister, concerning the proposed reorganisation and restructure of the Commonwealth car fleet in Brisbane.

PARA.TAB: The plaintiff in the proceedings—namely, Anthony Robinson—is a Canberra based bureaucrat who, I understand, is the acting national manager of the Comcar organisation. I mention in passing that I do not know the gentleman personally and, to the best of my knowledge, I cannot recollect ever setting eyes on the man and I certainly bear him no malice.

For some time leading up to the 1993 budget, and indeed since that time, I have been extensively lobbied by drivers employed by the Comcar organisation throughout Australia—particularly in Brisbane—who have been concerned about their future employment prospects. There has been for some time now continual rumours of the impending closure, or at least massive scaling down, of Comcar operations in some states. A substantial number of drivers have been very concerned about their jobs.

Earlier this year, as a result of a meeting of a number of drivers in Queensland, I was approached to make representations and generally try to assist the drivers in their continual perceived struggle to secure their employment. Given that out of some 35 or so drivers working out of the Comcar Brisbane depot approximately eight of them live in my electorate of Bowman and are known personally to me—as are all other drivers in Brisbane, I might add—I agreed to help them as a group in any way I could. In the normal course of events and in my usual practice of dealing with general constituent matters as a member of the House of Representatives, I caused inquiries to be made of the minister's office and I generally discussed the situation of the drivers with some of my parliamentary colleagues. From time to time I would report the results of my actions to various Comcar drivers.

In the budget there were decisions, of which I was unaware, which impacted quite markedly on the general operation of the Comcar organisation. I was again requested to make representations on behalf of the drivers. Accordingly, given that the budget decisions were not in accord with what I thought would be the case and following strong representations made to me on my return to Brisbane from Canberra at the end of the budget week—namely, Friday, 20 August 1993—I caused a letter to be written and faxed that same morning to Senator McMullan. The letter was forwarded by me on behalf of my constituents—namely, the Brisbane drivers employed by Comcar. As is my normal practice when I sincerely believe a constituent has a very strong case, I couched my letter in very strong terms.

It is my normal practice to provide my constituents with a copy of representations I have made on their behalf. Knowing that the drivers were anxious to learn what action I had taken, I gave a copy of my letter to the Comcar driver who, that same morning, was driving me into the city where I was to represent the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) at an official function.

My duty as a member of parliament is to represent the interests of my constituents and people who ask for my assistance to the best of my ability and without fear or favour. I believe that any action which inhibits me or attempts to inhibit me in carrying out my duties is a serious matter that should properly be dealt with by the appropriate forums of this House. I believe that in this instance the issuing and serving of a writ without any warning is deliberately intended to intimidate me as a member of parliament and is an attempt to seriously curtail my continued representations on behalf of my constituents, in this case the drivers employed by Comcar in Brisbane and elsewhere.

I believe that this rather unique situation in which I find myself has wider implications for all present and future members of this House. There is no question that a member of parliament who faces the possibility of court action every time he writes a letter to a minister which is critical of a public servant will be naturally impeded in carrying out his representations to the fullest extent.

I believe I have a duty to my colleagues in this place to have the whole question deliberated upon by the Standing Committee of Privileges so that honourable members can be made aware of their position. I refuse to allow a senior Canberra based bureaucrat to stop me from trying to help save people's jobs simply because he issues a writ against me. This would create an undesirable precedent which would have ongoing repercussions for all members of this House who may from time to time wish to strongly and vigorously represent the interests of their constituents.

I make no comment as to the substance of the allegations made in the writ as I believe that would be improper and should properly be determined by a court in the normal course. But I ask that this matter, in so far as it relates to my actions as a member of parliament acting on behalf of constituents, be referred by you to the Standing Committee of Privileges and given priority.

Mr Speaker, I submit the following documents for your consideration in determining the matter: first, a copy of a letter dated 20 August 1993 to Senator McMullan; and, secondly, a writ of summons dated 21 September 1993.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek your indulgence to speak on the same matter.
—The honourable member for Kooyong may proceed.

—I do not want to reflect on the concern of the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca) and the grievance that he has given oral testimony to here, but I personally can recall supporting most reluctantly a bill which the honourable member voted for in 1987 and which severely curtailed the ambit of the Standing Committee of Privileges in areas such as this. I recall warning people outside this chamber that this sort of thing would happen.

PARA.TAB: When honourable members propose legislation and vote for it, if it comes round and belts them right between the eyes later on, then I think they ought to pause and reflect on their action in this House when they voted for it in the first place. This is a defamation action and the changes that curtailed the power of the privileges committee curtailed that power by giving citizens the right to institute proceedings against members of parliament—who ought to be as liable under the law for statements that they make as any other citizen, save and accept for what applies in here for the privilege that is given to elected representatives to stretch that a little bit further.

I have no qualms about this matter. I am Deputy Chairman of the privileges committee. Mr Speaker, you will determine, not me, whether the matter comes before the privileges committee. But I am sitting here as a member of the committee listening to an honourable member who voted for legislation which brought this very situation about and who says that he is severely restricted in what he can say. He has not told the House what he said in the first place. I do not know what the subject of complaint is. I have listened to an impassioned speech, but I would not have a clue what the matter is that is being complained about. The letter has not been provided to us.

I have to make a response and say that I will view this matter objectively as Deputy Chairman of the privileges committee. But I get a little bit sick of the humbug in this House, particularly from people on the other side who complain about their rights being constrained when they are the ones who initiated the constraint to their rights.

If the letter is couched in the normal terms that we would expect of an honourable member forcibly arguing his case, then so be it. But just bear in mind that the difficulty the honourable member is referring to is brought about partly because of the way in which constraints were introduced a few years ago by the government itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, with your indulgence, I do not intend to speak on the specific issue raised by my colleague the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) but when the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca) raised this matter he suggested that he was submitting certain documents for consideration. Could I suggest to him that, as parliamentary secretary, it would be more appropriate for him to table the documents which would enable us all to peruse them and to make the judgment which the honourable member for Kooyong intimated he was unable to make and which I suggest is a matter for us all. I know that, as a parliamentary secretary, he can submit them. If, on the other hand, he raises the matter as an ordinary member, I would be quite happy to assure him that leave would be given for the documents to be tabled and then they are available for wider perusal.

—In respect of that particular matter, the documents which the parliamentary secretary indicated he was submitting as part of his submission to me on this matter are considered to be tabled now within the House and will be made available to honourable members who wish to peruse them.

—Mr Speaker, with your indulgence: I am a little taken aback by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), but I take his advice on board. We all should be very careful of what we do. From time to time I believe I have written letters that are exceptionally strong in language and highly critical of certain public servants, including senior public servants. I think all members of the House have done this from time to time in the belief that they have an unfettered right to vigorously represent all their constituents but especially those that feel perhaps powerless to pursue their rights and claims in other ways.

PARA.TAB: I am very concerned about the matter that the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca) has raised, because I think that it will affect us all. If, when we write to a minister, we have to consider the tone, language and content of how we represent views vigorously, I fear for the ability of honourable members to adequately represent their constituents. It would be a farce if, every time we wanted to raise something vigorously and in strong language, we had to get up and, in effect, read letters to ministers in this House. I believe that 90-second statements would take on a totally new meaning and adjournment debates could be quite interesting.

I sincerely hope, Mr Speaker, that you will consider the matters raised by the honourable member for Bowman because I think they are serious and they affect us all. If, as the honourable member for Kooyong suggests, we need to change the legislation of the privileges committee to provide protection for members of this House in this way, then that is something that we ought to contemplate.

TALKER.NAME: Mr O'KEEFE
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, with your indulgence: in respect of the submission that has been made to you, and reflecting on the comments from the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), I counsel you that it is very easy to come into this place and say, `I told you so'. Often, circumstances arise which give effect to the wisdom of hindsight, and that will certainly be listened to. —I thank all honourable members for their comments in respect of the matter raised by the honourable member for Bowman. I will, of course, examine the issue with the seriousness with which he has raised it and report to the House at a later time.

—On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the following report, incorporating a minority report: 326th report—An assessment of tax: a report on an inquiry into the Australian Taxation Office.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I am pleased to present the report of an inquiry of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts into the Australian Taxation Office. This report concludes a two-year investigation by the committee into the administration of one of this country's largest and most significant institutions. For probably the first time in Australia, a parliamentary committee has extensively investigated the manner in which income tax is collected.

PARA.TAB: The inquiry was undertaken in recognition of the enormous changes in all aspects of the tax office and tax administration commenced during the 1980s under the banner of modernisation. These reforms, principally engineered by the former Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Trevor Boucher, were acknowledged by witnesses before the committee as revolutionary and even evolutionary. This inquiry was commenced during the previous parliament under the chairmanship of my colleague the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch). I pay tribute to the significant contribution made to this inquiry by him.

I take this opportunity to outline the history of this inquiry and to place on the public record a brief summary of the work undertaken by the committee in preparing this report. The inquiry's terms of reference were agreed in November 1991 and publicly announced in January 1992. After a period for the reception and analysis of public submissions, the committee conducted a number of private inspections of tax office facilities. At the end of May 1992 the committee commenced a series of public hearings. Between June and October, 13 public hearings were conducted in Canberra, Adelaide, Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane. Several of those hearings were notable for, amongst other things, the media interest that they generated in the work of committee.

At the end of October 1992 the committee concluded its public hearings and a preliminary draft report was prepared for consideration by members. Over the Christmas period, honourable members were requested to provide written or oral comments on the preliminary report to the secretary. Several members did this and in January of this year the committee reconvened to consider a draft report incorporating honourable members' suggestions. This draft formed the basis of the committee's deliberations this year.

Following the resumption of parliament after the March election, the committee determined to resume the inquiry. That decision was taken in recognition of the sizeable amount of information already gathered, the significant effort demonstrated by witnesses and those who had made submissions to the committee, and the consequent need to fulfil the public expectation that the committee would complete this task. In June two further public hearings with witnesses from the tax office were held. These hearings served to update the information collected the previous year and provided new committee members with the opportunity to familiarise themselves with the issues and raise their own points of interest. The committee accepted 125 public submissions accounting for over 5,000 pages of evidence from ordinary taxpayers, academics, taxpayer agents and industry representatives, accounting and legal professionals, officers of the tax office, senior tax office management and many others. In addition, it received more than 40 exhibits and considered a number of confidential documents.

I take this opportunity to thank all of those who have contributed to the committee's investigation. In particular, I take this opportunity to thank the current Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Michael Carmody, and his staff for their cooperation and assistance. I also express the committee's gratitude to the former commissioner, Mr Trevor Boucher, who, as honourable members will note on page 4 of the report, retired in the course of the inquiry.

At the conclusion of the two additional public hearings, the committee commenced an intense program of meetings for the purpose of considering this report. Indeed, since May the sectional committee met on no fewer than 14 occasions to consider the report. In addition, a private meeting was held with the Commissioner of Taxation and one of the second commissioners to enable some of the committee's proposals to be discussed in general terms. In October the committee resolved to engage the services of a consultant to review the report and to propose amendments in respect of the report's technical accuracy. I take this opportunity to thank Mr Peter Dowling of Ernst and Young for his assistance and advice. The committee found his experience and practical observations to be exceptionally valuable.

At no stage has the committee acted to bring forward this report with undue haste. On the contrary, the fact that this extensive report has been tabled today is testament to the exceptional commitment of members of the public accounts committee and, in particular, to the members of the sectional committee formed to consider this inquiry. In particular, I pay tribute to Senator Watson, the former vice-chairman of the sectional committee, who has been fully involved in the report's formulation. Senator Watson's interest in the report extended with the full concurrence of the committee to reading and reviewing the text even after his formal resignation from the committee in August due to a heavy workload with Senate committees. I thank him for his advice and support.

I also take this opportunity to thank the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Aldred) for his enthusiasm and encouragement throughout the inquiry. To the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay), who participated at no small cost to himself in the full development of the committee's recommendations, I extend on behalf of the committee our thanks and best wishes for a swift recovery. I also acknowledge the work of my colleague the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) who, along with the honourable member for Fairfax, has participated in the inquiry from its establishment.

To the other members of the sectional committee in this House—the honourable member for Corinella (Mr Griffin), the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland), the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) and the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile)—and to all of the members of the full committee who have gone out of their way to attend and participate in the report's consideration, I commend them for their dedication to a difficult and challenging task. This report is a tribute the parliamentary committee system and to the diligence and bipartisanship of committee members.

I also take this opportunity to pay tribute to the remarkable work of the public accounts committee secretariat. To the committee secretary, Mr Trevor Rowe, to Ms Geraldine Skinner, and to Ms Sue Morton, who served at various points as secretary to the sectional committee, I express my thanks for their professionalism and tolerance during a long and at times difficult inquiry. To all of the staff of the secretariat, who particularly in recent weeks have spend unduly long and weary hours in reviewing, proof reading and perfecting this report, I extend both personally and on behalf of the committee a genuine tribute to them for their capacity and patience.

In particular, personally and on behalf of the committee, I would like to express my sincere thanks to Mr Simon Edwards, seconded from the Department of Finance, who performed the research for the inquiry and did most of the writing of this report. His dedication and commitment to the task were exceptional.

I am sure that all honourable members will agree from experience that it is through the dedication of our committee staff that the excellent work and reputation of our committees continue to grow. The committee's report is a comprehensive assessment of the administration of the Australian Taxation Office. While it is critical where necessary, it also recognises and commends the tax office for its many innovative and positive achievements, particularly in the areas of modernisation, self-assessment, personnel management and revenue collection. The report puts forward 148 recommendations, all of which I will not attempt to cover in this statement. However, I would like to highlight to the House a few of the areas in the report.

In evaluating the tax office's performance, the committee has considered the efficiency of administering the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. The committee has recognised that which must be painfully obviously to all in this parliament: the act is long overdue for a redraft. The resolve to simplify the act must come from within this place. A commitment across political lines will be necessary for any redraft or rewriting to be effective. The committee has recognised that to redraft the act and simplify its administration will not be an easy process, nor will it be quick or inexpensive. Nevertheless, in the committee's view, a redraft must be commenced urgently. The committee therefore recommends that sufficient resources be devoted to this exercise as a matter of the highest priority.

After 80 years, the committee considers the time is ripe for the establishment of a new administrative framework for the tax office. The committee has considered a number of options including the establishment of a board of management. This proposal was considered inappropriate for our taxation system. To be effective, it would require that the general powers of taxation administration be vested in a collective group. Such an unwieldy administrative structure would reduce parliamentary scrutiny.

The committee has determined that the tax office should be constituted under its own act as the Australian Taxation Commission. Through such a commission, all the advantages of a board can be embraced. In addition, a commission will facilitate the use of experts in executive roles on either a full- or part-time basis. A commission will also allow for a more flexible system for the employment of taxation professionals and provide the capacity to respond to changing international and domestic priorities.

The committee has carefully and comprehensively considered the system of private and public rulings issued by the commissioner. The committee has recognised the importance and significance of rulings for taxpayers. As an administrator, the Commissioner of Taxation has no authority to create law. Nevertheless, as a result of both legislative changes and the financial barriers in accessing judicial review, the committee acknowledges that the word of the commissioner has come to be seen by many as de facto or quasi law. The committee gave extensive consideration to proposals to make the commissioner's rulings subordinate law through the procedures of tabling and disallowance. While this mechanism would provide parliamentary scrutiny and an effective discipline in the exercise of the commissioner's powers and discretions, the committee considered that there were significant practical difficulties in such a system.

In particular, the possibilities of delay and increased uncertainty, the need to establish a capacity within the parliament capable of analysing and evaluating technical and complex administrative guidelines, and the capacity of the commissioner to avoid the parliament through the issue of other administrative guidelines, were considered to be so significant as to militate against the introduction of such a system at this time. Nevertheless, the committee has concluded that parliamentary review is both necessary and desirable. The committee has recommended that all public rulings should be tabled in the parliament and be available for review by the parliament's committees. In this way, the interpretations, discretions and powers of the commissioner can be best monitored and an effective deterrent to the abuse of power established.

Since the introduction of the self-assessment system, the importance of taxation auditing to the detection of taxpayers who fail to comply with the law has been paramount. The powers of taxation auditors to access information are both extensive and exceptional. The committee has carefully reviewed the auditing function. Its recommendations for change seek to establish a professional, independent audit operation which is balanced and efficient. Through the separation of the information gathering and analysis functions from the decision making process, the committee considers the powers of auditors can be better harnessed and the independence of final decisions enhanced.

There can be little doubt that access to our judicial system has become the privilege of the privileged. In the field of taxation this is even more the case as no legal aid is available to those citizens who wish to challenge a decision of the tax office. The committee has recognised this dilemma and urges the establishment of a low cost facility for the resolution of taxation claims below $5,000. While such a facility would not be judicial, it would allow issues of principle and importance to individuals to be argued and settled in a manner which is both practical and equitable. Under the committee's proposals, issues of significance could still be resolved by judicial interpretation where it was considered necessary. However, such determinations would be paid for by all taxpayers and not an individual taxpayer.

The committee has evaluated and considered a number of models for a taxpayers charter of rights. While such statements can satisfy a number of possible goals, the committee concluded that their merit lay in the focus they provided to administration. The committee considered the extent and description of what constituted a right of taxpayers should be detailed in a charter which is readily available for public scrutiny. In addition, the tax office should be required to provide standards of service in accordance with the rights detailed in the charter.

Some other major recommendations of the committee's report include the funding of a taxation ombudsman within the Commonwealth Ombudsman's Office, the removal of administrative culpability penalties, the need for a review of the financial position of the tax office and the payment by the tax office of the service fee for lodgment of tax returns on the electronic lodgment service.

I will now comment briefly on the dissenting report lodged by Senator Bishop. I note firstly that much of the dissenting report is on matters outside the terms of reference of this inquiry. To maintain bipartisanship the committee agreed very early in its deliberation that matters of taxation policy would not be considered. Nevertheless, the dissenting report extensively canvasses issues of policy and the tax mix. Secondly, it is noted that the dissenting report does not disagree with a majority of the committee's recommendations. Furthermore, several of the recommendations in the dissenting report are included in the committee's report. Some of the reasons for the committee's conclusions from which Senator Bishop has dissented have been addressed earlier in my statement.

While it is a matter of regret, it is my duty as chairman of the committee to refute the unwarranted insinuation contained in the preface and general statements of the dissenting report. While acknowledging the contribution of Senator Bishop, as with other members of the committee, I consider her inference in respect of the work and aims of those members who participated in the report's finalisation to be condescending, irrelevant and quite offensive.

In conclusion, while it would always be possible to find examples of deficiencies in any organisation of 18,000 people, the committee recognises that these examples are the exemptions rather than the rule. This report acknowledges that the tax office has been a progressive and generally efficient public organisation. Thus, while the committee does not condone any inefficiency, it has sought in its 148 recommendations to achieve a structure that will improve the overall administration, reduce costs and provide justice and equity to taxpayers.

I would again most sincerely thank the members of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and the committee secretariat for their efforts in respect of this inquiry. I believe that this report will provide a platform for a modernised tax office to step into the 21st century as a servant of the Australian people. Like all tax assessments, this report is not all good and not all bad. Some day we will all have to come to terms with that reality. I commend the report to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—This major report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts upon the committee's inquiry into the Australian Taxation Office, the ATO, is a culmination of two years extensive and intensive work. This report covers every significant aspect of the administration of the ATO and makes profound recommendations to effect improvement in the running of the ATO. Tax policy is not canvassed in the report, as that was beyond our terms of reference, and is a matter for the government of the day. During the inquiry, 15 public hearings were held and 128 submissions were received. Most of these submissions were of high quality and in great detail. As the member who initiated the inquiry and played the principal role in initially setting its parameters and a substantial part in its conduct throughout, it gives me great satisfaction to see it successfully brought to a conclusion today.

PARA.TAB: Several key recommended reforms are contained within our report upon the ATO. One of the most important is the suggested establishment of an Australian taxation commission. This proposal is made because, on the evidence before it, the committee was of the view that a wider perspective was required at the corporate management level of the ATO. Responsibilities of the ATO in contemporary Australia extend far beyond traditional revenue collection within the domestic jurisdiction. The ATO must now contend with a wide range of functions, from dealing with highly sophisticated matters in the international tax arena, through to the unique social role arising from the inclusion of the Child Support Agency within the ATO.

The report recommends that the commission consist of a chairperson, five full-time commissioners and three part-time commissioners. It is the firm belief of the committee that the retitled Chief Commissioner of Taxation, who will be one of the five full-time commissioners, must retain the power of general administration over taxation legislation.

Another vital recommendation of the committee is that relating to the long overdue simplification of Australian income tax law. It is pointed out in the report that when the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 was first passed by the parliament it covered just 126 pages. Nearly 60 years later, the act and its associated material has grown to over 5,000 pages. It is little wonder that the proportion of taxpayers using tax accountants continues to grow, and that even the best tax accountants have difficulty in grappling with the expanding complexity of tax legislation. We clearly have a significant problem.

Accordingly, the committee proposes that a broadly based task force be established to redraft the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. Moreover, sufficient resources should be committed by the government to complete priority simplification within two years, and full simplification within five years. However, the committee remains cautious about well-intentioned but naive notions that the tax law can be reduced to what is commonly called plain English.

In respect of the significant abuse of interest withholding tax arrangements—an issue I raised in this House a number of times in the lead up to our inquiry—the committee noted that there has been no action on the like treatment of trusts and corporations as recommended in the Follow the yellow brick road report of March 1991. Some 2 1/2 years later, problems about withholding tax collection remain, most especially about the quality of information held and available on non-resident beneficiary trusts.

The Bureau of Industry Economics report on this subject, commissioned by the ATO late last year as a result of my questions to senior ATO officers in public hearings, confirmed the ongoing nature of the problems, and also the considerable difficulty in arriving at definitive estimates of revenue lost. Therefore, the committee, quite properly, has recommended that the ATO review its supervision, monitoring and auditing of non-resident beneficiary trusts and improve its policy mechanisms to control abuse of interest withholding tax. In addition, we have recommended that the ATO, as a matter of priority, seeks to obtain double taxation treaties with those countries that are significant destinations for trust distributions.

One final key area of the inquiry's attention I would like to address is the vexed question of a taxpayers charter to protect the rights of taxpayers. This is a difficult question to resolve, as there has to be a sensible balance between adequate safeguards for taxpayers against arbitrary or improper action by the ATO, and the clear obligation of the ATO to efficiently collect the revenue of the Commonwealth. Effective grievance channels for taxpayers who suffer loss or unwarranted inconvenience as a result of the actions of ATO officials are naturally essential.

However, the committee was of the view that, over and above this, a formal statement of how relations between the ATO and taxpayers should be conducted was an appropriate initiative. To this end the committee studied a number of possible models, and it was generally thought that the citizens' charter, introduced by Prime Minister John Major in the UK in July 1991, probably provided the most practicable and equitable model. We have, as a result, suggested the establishment of a taxpayers' charter by the government, taking into account the various models available as options.There is a diverse range of other recommendations relating to ATO administration contained within our report, and the committee looks forward to the government's expeditious consideration of them.

In drawing my remarks to the close, I would like to express the gratitude of the committee and my own personal appreciation to the former Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Trevor Boucher, and the present commissioner, Mr Michael Carmody, for their excellent cooperation and frankness during the course of the inquiry. As our report correctly says in its introduction, Mr Boucher was the driving force behind the major reforms in the ATO during his term of office as commissioner from 1984 to 1993. In all, he gave nearly four decades of dedicated service to the ATO. Mr Boucher has moved on to his post as ambassador to the OECD with a fine record of achievement behind him, and the committee wishes him well in his new post.

At a particular stage of the inquiry Mr Boucher was the subject of some colourful television coverage, which no doubt won plaudits among some unthinking elements of the community who thought that bagging the chief tax man was good sport and wonderful entertainment. I understand that this `good sport' caused Mr Boucher and his family some personal distress.

We in this place are not here, however, to be entertainers. We are here to provide for the good government of this Commonwealth and its people, with restraint and moderation in the use of the powers conferred upon us in the exercise of that responsibility. Mr Boucher and his family can be absolutely confident in the knowledge that he fulfilled his time as commissioner without a stain on his character, and the inquiry demonstrated that he was the highly able and honest senior public servant that members of this House have always held him to be.

A minority report by Senator Bishop is being tabled along with this majority report, and the community will make its own judgments upon the quality and relevance of that minority report, and the motivation in its presentation. I would only say that, in its discussion of capital gains tax, for instance, this is obviously a matter of tax policy and is irrelevant to our terms of reference. Any member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts could have raised particular matters of tax policy dear to our hearts, but the overwhelming majority of the committee, I think, had a clear comprehension of the terms of reference and purpose of the inquiry.

The committee is deeply indebted to the public accounts committee secretariat which gave us excellent support and advice throughout the inquiry. In particular, I would like to mention the sterling work done throughout by our committee secretary, Mr Trevor Rowe, who is in the chamber with us today; tax sectional committee secretary for much of the inquiry, Ms Sue Morton; seconded Department of Finance adviser, Mr Simon Edwards, who is also with us today; and towards the end of the inquiry our other adviser, Mr Peter Dowling, from the Brisbane office of Ernst and Young. Mrs Laraine Brennan ably provided most of our secretarial support during the two years of our inquiry.

The committee and supporting staff all take great pride in the successful completion of our long and exhaustive inquiry. Adoption of this report resulting from the inquiry will be a watershed in the tax administration of this commonwealth, for which both the ATO and the taxpayer will certainly be the long-term beneficiaries. I join the chairman in commending the report to the House.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PUNCH
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—As the former chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts I rise this morning to commend those concerned with this fine body of work which has taken, as the chairman said, some two years to come about. Basically, this report says, to coin a phrase, `If it ain't broke, don't fix it'. The report says that there is no need to fix the Australian Taxation Office because it `ain't broke', but it does say that following the technical modernisation undertaken some years ago under Trevor Boucher's policies, the tax office nevertheless needs legal, social and administrative updating. This report very capably highlights those areas where it needs to commence that process.

PARA.TAB: A number of people have already been thanked. I refer to Trevor Rowe, the committee secretary; Sue Morton; Simon Edwards; and, of course, Mrs Laraine Brennan. This was no small achievement by Mrs Brennan. If she had been running the Gulf War it would have been over sooner than it actually was.

I would like to express my congratulations and appreciation to a number of people for the time I served as the chair of this inquiry and the PAC, not the least of whom is the current chairman, the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott), who has done an excellent job in bringing this inquiry to fruition; the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Aldred), whose efforts right across the inquiry were tireless; the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon); and the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay), who I understand is still recuperating—we wish him well. I also thank Senator Watson, whose expertise on tax matters is acknowledged by all in both chambers of this parliament, and the previous member for Tangney, Mr Peter Shack, who was a very active participant in my time on the committee in the last parliament.

This report says a lot of good things and makes a lot of substantial recommendations, recommendations that will not be easy to fulfil and will take a good deal of effort by government and the tax office. Redrafting the tax law, as the honourable member for Deakin said quite rightly, is far easier said than done. But following so many of the legislative changes that have been made by this government and state governments across the 1980s and 1990s, the law has to be put into somewhat plainer English. It is no good, as the honourable member for Deakin hinted a few moments ago, for people in the community to simply wish that the tax act would shrink. It is only as big as tax practice in this country has made it. If we consider, on a bipartisan basis, how we can go about reducing the size and complexity of the tax act, every Australian will be better off.

The idea of a commission says volumes for what the committee system can do in this parliament. The expertise formula, rather than the presiding over formula—that is, the commission idea rather than a board of management—is the way to go. I am very pleased that it has bipartisan support. At the last election, the coalition had a proposal not dissimilar to the idea of a board of management for the tax office. But in a bipartisan spirit the coalition members of the committee were willing to move from that and the Labor members of the committee were willing to move towards it, coming to what can be seen as not just a compromise but, more importantly, a very good, workable and constructive idea.

The small taxation claims tribunal is really for the little people, for the ordinary Australians who have minor problems from time to time with the tax office; small matters of interpretation with small moneys involved. If government were to pursue this, it would take so much of the trauma, fear and animosity out of the tax system that it would make the life of government—and in particular the tax office—so much easier.

The charter of rights is something we were all quite passionate about. I am very pleased to see it in the report today. So much of what the public accounts committee has done in the last few years is specifically highlighted by the Midford Paramount episode and shows just how vulnerable the ordinary individual in our society can be to a bureaucracy. I am sure I can say, on behalf of people on both sides of the House, that it is frightening at times. A charter of rights will go quite some way to equalising that playing field. It may well be that some of these items will be implemented now by government and the tax office, only to be built on further in subsequent years, perhaps after subsequent reports.

The charter of rights, for instance, may later need legislative backing. A future parliament may see it as warranting that. But, quite rightly, the public accounts committee has not gone so far so soon. Similarly with the issue of rulings, in the future further starch, as it were, may need to be put in the cloth of these recommendations. But it is a cautious road we must tread because any idea of disallowance procedures in this House, the Senate or both would create absolute, total and utter chaos in the taxation system and would have a very marked effect on industry, trade and commerce in this country.

I also refer to Senator Bishop's minority report. It is highly regrettable and, as the chairman said, it does not have a good deal of substance. The sum total, to draw a close to one chapter in the life of the public accounts committee, is simply this: with the exception of one member, this report says very starkly, clearly and in a bipartisan manner that the members of the committee not only supported but revered the work of Trevor Boucher. Probably enough has now been said on it.

When I was quickly scrawling my notes I left out one member whom I meant to mention, the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), who did a great job—as he always does on the public accounts committee. He is ever blunt in coming straight to the point. Believe me, Mr Deputy Speaker, with some witnesses that is a very good attribute to have on a committee. Once again, congratulations to the chairman, who did an excellent job, and to the staff and all concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on its inquiry into the Australian Taxation Office is the culmination of a lot of work from many of my colleagues on both sides of the House in this parliament and the previous one. All the congratulations have been made but, bearing in mind that Trevor Rowe—the secretary—and Simon Edwards are in the House, I take the opportunity to thank both of those gentlemen and their staff, without whom this report would not be before us today.

PARA.TAB: It would be reasonable to say that this report was written in a climate of confusion, complexity—some complexities have been mentioned by my colleagues, whether in terms of the Income Tax Assessment Act or other things—frustration and, for some individuals, despair. That climate of despair saw the domination—perhaps arguably—of the technocrat in the Australian Taxation Office. Of necessity, therefore, the report is very extensive, technical and radical in nature.

I have one disappointment with the report. If the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott), as the Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, will bear with me, the title An assessment of tax is very boring. We need something in this report to draw people's attention to what we are saying. As a number of my colleagues would know, I argued very forcefully, but unsuccessfully, to title this report PAYE. By that I do not mean `pay as you earn' but `pray as you earn'. Unfortunately, the majority view prevailed, so I have made that comment in the House today.

Whilst a number of my colleagues on both sides of the House have referred to former Commissioner Boucher—he is referred to specifically in the report—congratulating him on his distinguished and lengthy service, I do not think any of us here, in the other place or in the electorate at large should lose sight of the fact that Mr Boucher oversaw a tax administration regime which, in the view of many people, at times was overly legalistic, was sometimes moralistic and, in some cases, had more than a distinct hint of bias. That is covered, in one way or another, in the report.

All I would say to the House today is that there is a substantial challenge in this report—a challenge for the government and a challenge for the new commissioner, Michael Carmody. Bearing in mind that I was not a member of this committee in the last parliament, I have to say that at the hearings that we had earlier this year with Mr Carmody, he showed that he has the right leadership to get on with the job. He is already taking up some of the report's recommendations in the context of the reinvigorated ATO.

There is one aspect of this issue which continues to disappoint me and deeply concern me. Mr Deputy Speaker, as you will recall, in the last sitting week the Speaker, in his wisdom, referred certain aspects of this committee's deliberations to the privileges committee. I know I have to be very careful because that matter is before the privileges committee. I draw your attention, Mr Deputy Speaker, and that of the House to an article in this morning's edition of the Australian, which once again repeats a lot of those leaks that are the subject of the privileges committee inquiry. It seems to me that a lot of those leaks are being used for other than public accounts committee purposes—there is a political agenda, some might say, on both sides of this House.

The only comment I make is that I hope the privileges committee will see this morning's article in the Australian as yet another reflection of those very undesirable leaks and on the nature of this committee in the very important report that it has tabled this morning. I do not want to go on with some of the specific recommendations that have been mentioned by my colleagues, other than to repeat what I said earlier—this is a very strong challenge for the government and for the Australian Taxation Office.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The chair acknowledges the care with which the honourable member for Groom raised the matters that are in the press this morning that impinge upon the issues before the privileges committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I will make my comments brief; I know the House has a lot of business to deal with today. I want to make a few brief comments about this report on the Australian Taxation Office. I have come into this committee only for the last six or seven months, right at the tail end of the tax inquiry, and have been part of the sectional committee that has been conducting this inquiry. I suppose I have really been more involved in the wrap-up, the documentation and the straightening out of all the evidence that has been given over the last couple of years in order to put this report together for tabling this morning.

PARA.TAB: From the outset I would have to say that I agree with the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) in that I was not overly impressed, I am sorry to say to the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott), with the name of the report. I will go further in agreeing with the honourable member for Groom. We believe the name should have been `pray as you earn', but in my interpretation the word `pray' should have been spelt p-r-e-y.

I took a great deal of interest in getting on this committee and the sectional committee that was finalising the inquiry into the tax office. I did not come on to the committee carrying any baggage from anywhere else; it was purely out of interest in seeing whether there was any possible way that this parliament could make the process in relation to taxation and the understanding of that process in this country much simpler than it is. It was certainly heartening to see that the recommendation for redrafting the tax act got widespread support. The act has been in existence for almost 60 years. Surely it is incumbent upon this government now—whether we can do it in modern day, understandable language or not—to attempt to redraft the act. We should not just sit back and say, `We cannot do it, we cannot simplify it, we cannot make it more understandable'. We certainly must try. We are in the 1990s, not in the 1960s. It is also timely with the recommendations that are coming out of this report, as far as the restructuring of the tax office is concerned, that we are bringing it into the 1990s with the structure of the elected commissioners and so on.

Probably the more controversial aspect of the report that is being alluded to this morning is that of rulings. We have a dissenting report in the back of this document which went further than the committee was prepared to go. Having come from local government, I am afraid that I believe in the committee system where we should thrash these things out thoroughly and reach a point where we generally agree on what is happening.

Interestingly enough, when I picked up the report yesterday and read the relevant recommendation on rulings—that is, tabling public rulings within five sitting days after their publication—I found that it happens to be recommendation 6.66, which we all know is the devil's number. It will be interesting to see whether that generates more accountability and transparency, as far as those rulings are concerned, with the Commissioner of Taxation. I support that point. It is going to be interesting to watch.

I certainly will be watching to see the effect that that recommendation has in trying to gain more accountability and transparency as far as the commissioner is concerned. If, down the line, that recommendation does not achieve the committee's perceived goal, then someone, whether it is this committee or another committee of this parliament, should revisit that aspect. The people of Australia are demanding that that be the case. We have attempted to address it in this report. If this recommendation, if taken up by the government, does not achieve that goal, then that particular area of the report will need to be revisited.

The small taxation claims tribunal and the charter of rights are very important recommendations and aspects of this report. I think it is bringing it a long way. I think the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch), in his comments, alluded to the fact that when people are dealing with government and government departments and get into legal wranglings, it is absolutely awesome. So many people walk away and say, `I cannot afford to take on the tax office; I will just put up, shut up and cop the penalty and do whatever'—whether they believe they are right or not. At least now if the government takes up these recommendations there may be an area where the little fellow, the small person out there in the community, can pursue his rights.

After the short period I have been involved in this committee and particularly the sectional committee, I acknowledge the work of the staff—Trevor Rowe, Simon Edwards, Sue Morton, Ms Skinner and Mrs Brennan. They have put in long hours. They have put up with what could be termed some pedantic behaviour by all of us on the committee in relation to what we were trying to do. They have been very patient and I think that they have done an excellent job. We have spent some long hours putting the report together to get it tabled today and I think it is important that we all recognise the input from these people. Putting up with the 17th and 18th Joint Statutory Committee of Public Accounts, they will probably go down in history for their patience and consideration involved. In closing, I commend this report to the government. As, I think, the honourable member for Groom said, the challenge is now before the government to take up the recommendations contained in this report and to do something about improving the whole area of taxation right across the Commonwealth of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reports which I am about to present will not generate the coverage or the excitement of the preceding one. Nevertheless on behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the fourth and fifth reports of the committee for 1993 relating to the redevelopment of CSIRO site at Prospect, New South Wales, and the rationalisation of inner-Melbourne accommodation.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The first report which I have tabled deals with the redevelopment of the CSIRO Ian Clunies Ross laboratory complex at Prospect, New South Wales. It is proposed to relocate staff of the Division of Animal Health from the McMaster laboratory, Glebe, and staff of the Division of Animal Production at the poultry research unit at North Ryde to Prospect. It is also proposed to provide upgraded research facilities for existing staff of the Division of Animal Production at the Prospect site.

PARA.TAB: The McMaster Laboratory at the University of Sydney, Glebe, is occupied under permissive occupancy and needs to be vacated as soon as possible after June 1994. CSIRO considered several options before coming to the conclusion that the McMaster Laboratory should relocate to the site at Prospect. At the public hearing, the committee was advised that relocation of the McMaster activities to Prospect is in the national interest in terms of the research synergy between McMaster and Prospect programs and is in a metropolitan location appropriate to research outputs for the manufacturing sector. Relocation of the poultry facilities from North Ryde to Prospect was examined by the committee in 1991 and endorsed in its report to parliament in March 1992. The committee was advised that coordination of the move within this project will minimise costs and overcome potential cost penalties of a separate development.

The Prospect site contains 41 major and minor buildings, many of which have reached the end of their useful life. Working conditions are cramped and the dated design of some buildings has made animal handling labour intensive. At the public hearing the committee was advised of the inter-institutional links between CSIRO and the University of Western Sydney, Nepean. The committee commends the CSIRO on these links and believes that these will be strengthened once library facilities at Prospect are extended, thus providing access to a greater range of research material. The committee was also advised that the Wool Research and Development Corporation has a 100 per cent equity in the land at Prospect. The committee believes that the government should give consideration to transferring this equity in the site at Prospect to CSIRO. The estimated cost of the proposal at August 1992 prices is $11.6 million.

The second report which I have tabled—the committee's fifth for 1993—deals with the proposed rationalisation of inner Melbourne accommodation for the Department of Defence. The committee has recommended that the work, estimated to cost $27 million, should proceed. The Department of Defence proposes to rationalise its activities in the inner Melbourne area. This will affect premises on St Kilda Road which are currently leased. Some personnel will remain in the inner Melbourne area. Others will be relocated to, for example, RAAF Williams—another proposal being examined by the committee, as you would be well aware, Mr Deputy Speaker.

There will therefore be a surplus of leased accommodation.Various studies have determined that by July 1996 there will be 2,379—I do not know why it is not 2,380—Defence personnel in the inner Melbourne area. Existing leased premises would require substantial refurbishment to bring them up to modern office standards. Furthermore, if Defence were to remain in these buildings, substantial recurrent expenditure on rent and running costs would be incurred. Defence believes that most of these personnel could be accommodated at Victoria Barracks, provided the buildings within the barracks precinct are upgraded to a standard consistent with modern office accommodation. That is what the RIMA project is all about—the refurbishment of buildings at Victoria Barracks—and the committee has concluded that existing buildings in Victoria Barracks need to be substantially refurbished and upgraded to provide a modern and efficient office accommodation for Defence personnel. The entire Victoria Barracks precinct is listed on the register of the National Estate.

Defence therefore commissioned the preparation of a conservation and management plan which concluded that there is no reason why any of the significant buildings cannot be adapted for re-use provided a number of guidelines are followed. Defence was also required to inform the Australian Heritage Commission of any proposed action and to give the commission a reasonable opportunity to consider it. Defence did not formally advise the commission of the action proposed until shortly before the committee's public hearing. The commission was therefore unable to give full consideration to what is being proposed within the time frame required for submissions to the committee.

Normally the committee expects proponent departments or agencies to obtain environmental or heritage clearances for projects before they are referred to it for consideration. This was not possible in this particular instance because the proposal is in the pre-schematic design stage. The commission acknowledged that Defence has the best track record of all departments in protecting its National Estate assets. Defence also gave an unequivocal assurance that the committee will be involved in the management process to ensure that heritage matters are taken fully into account during the detailed design process. The proposal has the strong support of the local community and the committee has recommended that Defence and the primary contractor liaise with local Commonwealth Employment Service officers to encourage the use of locally registered unemployed tradespeople on the project.

The council of the city of South Melbourne expressed strong support for the retention of the Defence headquarters in the city of South Melbourne. As I warned your predecessor in the chair, Mr Deputy Speaker, these two proposals are not nearly as exciting as the preceding document that was presented to the House. I thank the House.
Debate resumed from 16 November, on motion by Mr O'Keefe:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that the most significant gift a nation can give to anybody is the gift of citizenship. There are few things a nation can do which can supply a recognition, an acknowledgment, to people equally, no matter what their background or country of origin. We cannot do it in money, we cannot do it in the amount of land they own, but we can acknowledge people who come to Australia by granting them without fear or favour citizenship and equal rights in this great nation. I regret that in the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill we see flawed thinking on the part of the government as it approaches this great subject. The subject of citizenship should encompass, I believe, something of the character and attitudes of a person who becomes part of this great nation and should also deal with the legal obligations and background of changing nationality.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the government has not paid attention to the great requirements necessary in granting citizenship. If one looks at the government's administration over the past 10 years and the administration of citizenship and its immigration policies, one would have to form the view that the government does not care. Minimum standards, preferences rather than commitments, are the government's objectives.

The changed citizenship oath is quite a meaningless little oath. In fact, it is the most meaningless oath amongst all nations. I put to the House that there is not a statement any other nation requires of new citizens which is so weak in its commitment and its statement of character of an Australian citizen. I will read it for the benefit of the House. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: From this time forward—
one may, if one wishes, include the words `under God'—
I pledge my loyalty to Australia and its people,
whose democratic beliefs I share,
whose rights and liberties I respect, and
whose laws I will uphold and obey.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pretty wishy-washy.

—It is a wishy-washy statement by any standards. I will read for the benefit of the House and for the packed galleries the statements other countries—some of them deadbeat countries we would not want to join, others some of the great leaders of the freedoms of this world—require of people becoming citizens. Nobody offers such a weak commitment as Australia. We are one of the few remaining great immigration nations; people are queuing in their millions to come here. Each year we have 1 1/2 million people applying to come here permanently, and we have absolutely millions of visitors, and we say, `You do not have to make much of a commitment. We will make it easy for you. Just slip in. We do not require any acknowledgment really of our head of state'.

PARA.TAB: I will go through the speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr O'Keefe) for the benefit of the House to find out what he thinks about this because I am sure that, by trying to divine his mind and understand what he is driving at, we will gain a clearer picture of what the government is seeking to do. The parliamentary secretary said:
In the past year, the government has sought to promote community discussion of issues relating to our national identity.

SPEECH.PARA: That is shorthand for, `We raised the republic issue'. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) went off around the nation saying that we needed to be a republic. That was the biggest fizzer of all time. The public are now asking who is doing this. The Governor-General himself, who lead the Australian Labor Party when in opposition and was a key figure in the Australian Labor Party, has questioned the value of a republic, asking, `If it's not broke, why fix it? We have the great freedoms and the great opportunities as a nation. Why do you want to shove a republic on Australians?'. Yet, in the second paragraph of the second reading speech, the parliamentary secretary said that we have had this discussion and the government now thinks that we have to change our oath of citizenship based on the promotion of community discussion. That reflects the single-mindedness of the Prime Minister trying to swing in on Australians the thing that Australians are rejecting. He has lost the argument. John Brown and David Hill are saying that the Prime Minister has blown it—`There'll be no republic. He's blown the issue'.

PARA.TAB: The next thing that caught my attention was the parliamentary secretary's statement that the preamble in the bill makes a clear statement that `citizenship involves both rights and obligations'. This is the greatest hire-purchase agreement of all time. Hidden behind a weak pledge is a statement in the Australian Citizenship Act. No nation does that. How can people be asked to accept citizenship sight unseen? There is no instruction, requirement or anything which acknowledges what it means to be an Australian citizen; but here in the act is the pledge on which the minister places so much emphasis.

That pledge refers to members of the Australian community and says that citizenship is a common bond involving reciprocal rights and obligations for uniting all Australians, while respecting their diversity and that persons granted Australian citizenship enjoy these rights and accept these obligations by pledging loyalty. There then follow four items. Why is that not in the oath itself? Why is it hidden? This is a shonky deal like some of those deals out in western Sydney where one signs an incomprehensible contract to buy a house, only to find that one has signed one's life, money and future away. If we are proud of it, why is it hidden? For goodness sake, if it is the greatest gift we can give anybody coming to a nation, should we not also be proud of it; or is there another agenda?

Are we trying to run this nation by accommodating in the citizenship act the views of all those migrants that come here? Are migrants the only group that we consult in this process? Surely the rest of Australia needs to have a say. Surely the rest of Australia deserves to have a comment on the commitment, involvement, and pledge of citizenship. Surely the rest of Australia deserves a comment on the commitment, not the preference, of citizenship; how one stands before the laws; and how one shares both the rights, responsibilities and benefits of citizenship. What about asking the other Aussies?

This is not a hire-purchase agreement set up to confuse somebody. This is a proud statement of our nation. I reject the concept put forward by the minister that, because there is a pledge, it does not matter what the oath says. Further in the speech, the parliamentary secretary states:

SPEECH.PARA: As the multicultural society it is proper that the pledge of commitment be one which will be equally meaningful to all our people.

Whom did the government ask? How did the government find out whether it is meaningful? I know the way in which these things are done: someone runs around the ethnic leaders and asks, `Do you agree with this? If you agree with this, we won't consult anybody else. We won't have a debate in the community about it. The Prime Minister is running the republican thing. We will pull the Queen out of it and change the oath of commitment'. There is no real commitment to the head of state. It just says, `We acknowledge it's a democracy and we think that a democracy is a good idea'. There is no need to make a commitment to promote it or stand by it in times of trouble—there is nothing like that. It is simply, `Yes, of course, I respect it'. Who does not respect a democracy or free ideals? This is meaningless garbage:
As the multicultural society we are, it is proper that the pledge of commitment be one which will be equally meaningful to all our people.

Whom did the government run this past? Is this the result of the Prime Minister's judgment of who ought to have a proper commitment—`I'm a Catholic' or `I'm Irish'? Is that the way it is done? This gives great comfort to the bigots in the system. Here we are building into our citizenship process the comforts that the Prime Minister gives to bigotry in his statement about why he thinks we should be a republic. That is the reason for the change—nothing more. What a spurious reason for playing with this greatest gift we can give to any person coming from overseas. The parliamentary secretary goes on to state:

To reinforce this commitment to national identity, we must continue to develop a special Australian identity. We need strong national identity to give us more strength of purpose. We need it abroad to leave no-one in any doubt about who we are and what we stand for.

Why adopt then the most meaningless pledge in the world? That is a lack of understanding of identity. It shows a lack of commitment. It shows a lack of knowledge of where Australia has come from and where Australia is going. It epitomises the completely lost attitude of every member of the government.

PARA.TAB: The government is playing games with Mabo and the republic while people out there are dying. There are kids without homes and people without jobs but the government does not deal with the hard issues. The government's failure to deal with the hard issues, alas, has become one of the things that we need to accept as our identity so that we know who we are in the world. I reject that. It is spurious logic and it lack ideals and commitment. It is absolutely spurious—a false premise based on a false supposition that Australia needs to become a republic. Then the parliamentary secretary goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: The government is of the view that the process of nation building is enhanced by reinforcing the notion of an `Australian' citizenship.

Although I have searched the bill and the pledge to find anything particularly Australian, the government still claims that it is particularly Australian. Then the parliamentary secretary goes on with this huge leap of logic which says that this process of nation building is `reinforcing the notion of an Australian citizenship'. I do not see any nation building going on. Can the government tell me where it is? Can the government tell me one part of Australia where nation building is going on? Today, because there are no ideals or commitment from the Prime Minister or any of his cabinet, we have the destruction of the nation.

PARA.TAB: I agree with the need to reinforce the concept of Australian citizenship; but it is sheer bunkum and hypocrisy for the government to say that it is based on the fact that we are building a nation. The government could not care less about what is happening out there. It could not care less about the unemployed or the families. The government could not care less about the destruction it has created and continues to create while the Prime Minister worries about his teak tables in the Lodge or whether the chairs are the right design, whether they are original or whether they are a copy from some mate of his in Sydney that he has done business with over a long period of time. What does this have to do with citizenship? For that matter, what does this have to do with leadership? In his speech on Australian citizenship, the parliamentary secretary goes on to state:

SPEECH.PARA: Some residents are reluctant to apply for citizenship partly because they do not see the present oath or affirmation as being adequately Australian in character.

What does that mean? Again we come to the Irish, the Catholic and the Queen—that is what that means. If we look at the oaths of other nations—the commitment of those nations who have supplied the great flow of migrants—we see really meaningful oaths and pledges. The honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton), who is at the table, has not read it and would not know. He does not have the brains or the ability to go out and do it; but he is prepared to let it run right over the top of him and accept blindly the Prime Minister's notional concept of the character of Australia. The honourable member is prepared to accept it blindly and willy-nilly. Finally, on the second last page, the parliamentary secretary states that this pledge:
. . . also reflects a sense of national identity that can be readily identified with by citizens of Australia, not just applicants for citizenship.

I do not know where the government consulted. Who can identify with this? If this pledge were taken around the streets, to senior citizens, the RSLs, the P&Cs and if one asked whether it was a fair statement about what Australians believe, one would get a big `No', because those people do not believe in this. This satisfied the ethnic leaders of Australia. It did not satisfy the average Aussie, and it is our citizenship we are giving away, it is our prized possession. It is the people's right to understand the commitment to citizenship of people coming to Australia. Yet the minister says it must be the applicants who are satisfied.

PARA.TAB: We do not disagree with discussion and consultation with applicants but, as Australians, our citizenship is a gift to those coming here. I have dealt with the parliamentary secretary's speech. What rubbish! There is no focus and no commitment. Weakness is mistaken for tolerance in the airy-fairyness of this debate. The wish to please overrides any commonsense to change Australian citizenship. I do not believe that there is an Australian person who, after honestly assessing the changes we are making here, would agree with them.
If we look at the international context, what we are doing is even more frightening. I will read to the House some of the international commitments. The Austrian oath states:

SPEECH.PARA: I pledge that I will belong to the Republic of Austria as a faithful citizen, that I will always conscientiously observe the laws and that I refrain from anything which would be detrimental to the interests and the reputation of the Republic.

It is no longer than the Australian pledge, oath, or whatever we call it, but it has substance and a commitment from the people taking the oath that they will conscientiously observe the laws; that they believe the nation has gone through a process of law making that is worth while and that they can identify with; and they will not do anything detrimental to the interests of that nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —They must be proud of their country.
—Yes. The Austrians are proud people. We would not think that the good old Brits would have anything written down, but they do. The British oath states:

SPEECH.PARA: I—
the person has to give his or her name, which does not have to be done with the proposal before the House; people can just make an anonymous commitment to Australia—
swear by Almighty God that, on becoming a British citizen, I will be faithful and bear true allegiance to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth the Second Her Heirs and Successors according to the law.

That means that a person will deny other allegiances and will follow the laws. Wonderful citizens from Greece have come to Australia. They understand democracy. I bet they understand what the pledge or commitment is to Australia. The Greek oath states:
I swear loyalty to Greece, obedience to the Greek Constitution and the Laws—
the government does not have the guts to put anything about obedience in our pledge; it is just tagged on the end as something that a person will try to obey—
as well as to fulfil conscientiously my duties as a Greek citizen.

That is good stuff. Then I come to the best of the lot, the United States, the freest nation on earth by anyone's measures. It is the freest nation on earth, judged by the United Nations or any other group that we want to wheel out. The oath of the United States of America states:

I hereby declare, on oath, that I absolutely and entirely renounce and abjure all allegiance and fidelity to any foreign prince, potentate, state, or sovereignty, of whom or which I have heretofore been a subject or citizen;—
the person is saying, `This is the end of my past. I am starting a new life. I renounce all other allegiances'—

that I will support and defend the United States of America against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the same; that I will bear arms on behalf of the United States when required by the law; that I will perform non-combatant service in the Armed Forces of the United States when required by law; that I will perform work of national importance under civilian direction when required by the law; and that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; so help me God'.

There is an oath that means commitment. That is not preference; that is not seeking to appease the ethnic communities of Australia; that is not kowtowing to an exaggerated understanding of multiculturalism. It is really seeking a commitment from people that come to Australia. We say, `Look, we are all one. We want you to share in this. This is a commitment we expect of you because it is our home. It is our nation'. We cannot do anything better or be more welcoming than to open our front door and say, `Come into our home and be part of our family'. This is the process that is going on here; it is a people thing. `We want you to like us, and we like you. In this process we know that you need to make a commitment. We will honour your commitment as a citizen of this nation'.

PARA.TAB: I wrote to about 10 local government bodies around Australia because they administer citizenship oaths. I got a variety of responses from them. They all condemned the government's approach to this issue because they see the people coming forward to take the citizenship oath; they know what people who want to be Australians feel about this nation. These are some of the comments from local government:
"It is inadequate."
"General consensus is that the proposal is inadequate and something along the USA lines is required."
"The pledge lowers the importance of the declaration and any proposal to change should heighten this value."

"The current Oath and Affirmation clearly require a pledging of allegiance and a commitment to fulfilling all the responsibilities of a citizen. The proposed pledge uses words such as `democratic belief, I share' and `rights and liberties, I respect'. These wordings are more in keeping with agreements of common objectives rather than commitment to uphold these virtues."

SPEECH.PARA: That is the view of local government in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to have the opportunity to speak today on this most important issue, the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill. A decision to change one's citizenship is taken with careful, considered thought and great seriousness. It is, in fact, an act of courage that one becomes a citizen of a nation by choice rather than by birth. It is an act which requires great courage. Millions of people have come to our shores from over 150 other nations around the world. They have come here willingly. They have sought Australia as a destination.
