They have desired to stay, to accept our culture, and to make themselves a part of our nation and of our lives.

PARA.TAB: Those millions of immigrants from over 150 countries have changed the nature inevitably and irrevocably of this great nation. We are not what we were 200, 100 or 50 years ago, and we will be different again tomorrow. In great part I think that is undoubtedly so because of the contribution that is made to our continuing developing culture by new citizens. So the act of citizenship is one which is not taken lightly by those who come here and ask to become one of us.

I ask honourable members to think carefully and to put themselves in the shoes of the person who comes to Australia as an immigrant. We should remember that those immigrants have enjoyed birth in another country. Their heritage sometimes goes back not just for generations but for centuries, sometimes many centuries. They have a heritage and a commitment to that country, to that culture, to that way of life, to their religion, to their race, to their creeds and their morals—to all that goes together to make them individuals.

In giving thought to becoming an Australian citizen, one must surely go through a great deal of questioning. Some 19 years ago when I made that decision and stood in front of a town clerk of the city of Berwick and pledged allegiance to the Queen of Australia, it was with a great deal of nervousness. In my own heart I wondered whether I needed to give up my heritage, forget my own background and deny my roots in order to become a part of this new nation—to become a citizen by choice rather than by an accident of birth.

Over and over again I tell my new citizens at citizenship ceremonies all over the electorate of La Trobe that they need not fear because in Australia we have adopted a welcoming stance to people from all cultures, all religions and all races. We ask only that they make a commitment to Australia; that they themselves wish to be a part of this nation; that they wish to observe our laws and in general our customs; and that they truly integrate themselves within our society to participate to the fullest extent in all the activities that help make us a community of people. Foremost in the message that I give my new citizens is the message that, while Australia has a responsibility now to them, they likewise have a great responsibility to Australia.

Increasingly in this country we talk about rights. I am a person who fights very hard for rights. Undoubtedly later this day I will wind up in debate, perhaps argument, with the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) over the issue of rights. In that instance it will be in regard to the right of individuals to not belong to associations as well as the right of individuals to belong to associations.

In this instance we are talking about responsibility. There are all sorts of rights that we talk about, are there not? Today we talk about Aboriginal rights—we will debate that in this place very shortly—about women's rights, about children's rights and about animal rights. I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that very seldom do we hear our leaders, our government, our officials or our bureaucracy talk about responsibilities. This comes to the crux of the argument with respect to this legislation. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr O'Keefe), in his second reading speech, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The government's view is that there is strong and growing support for ensuring that our national symbols effectively express our distinctive identity.

I do not know where that strong and growing support is. In particular, I do not know what national symbols he is talking about. Is it our flower? Is it our bird? Is it our animal? Is it our flag? Perhaps it is our flag because I recall that our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) went to Indonesia in 1992 and told the Indonesians that we would change the flag. He said, `We will give you a new one because we do not like the one we have'. At the same time he took the opportunity to dump on our head of state, the Queen. He came back to Australia, and there was a huge uproar.

PARA.TAB: Have honourable members noticed that recently the Prime Minister has quit talking about changing our flag as a symbol of our nation? It is no longer appropriate to talk about it. Do honourable members know why? He no longer talks about it because opinion poll after opinion poll tells him that Australians do not want to change their flag. Yes, there are some who would like to change our flag. There are a few. But the very clear majority wish to retain this national symbol which has been ours since federation and parts of which were ours dating back to the early 1850s. That is a national symbol.

I guess the oath of allegiance too is a national symbol, but I do not recall the government going out and canvassing the nation, the nation's citizens or the nation's citizens-to-be about the oath of citizenship or a preamble to the act. I do not remember that at all; in fact, I am quite confident it did not occur.

In this place we are now debating a bill to amend the Citizenship Act because the government decided it wanted a new oath. It wants to change one of our national symbols, and without proper debate in the community. Thank goodness this bill is not under the guillotine in this place. Just for a change it is nice to be able to debate the issue, at least in the House.

On 2 October 1993, the Canberra Times reported the statement of our new oath of allegiance in the context of discussions that the Canberra Times had had with the poet Les Murray. It is my understanding that it was the understanding of the Canberra Times that our new oath came from words which were written as a poem by Mr Murray. Just to put things in context, I read the new oath:

SPEECH.PARA: From this time forward under God,—
in the case of the oath, and without in the case of an affirmation—
I pledge my loyalty to Australia and its people,
whose democratic beliefs I share,
whose rights and liberties I respect, and
whose laws I will uphold and obey.
Mr Murray evidently said that his original oath was a bit more daring. It went:

Under God from this time forward I am part of the Australian people. I share their democracy and their freedom. I obey their laws. I will never despise their custom or their faith and I expect Australia to be loyal to me.
Speaking on ABC radio, evidently, on 1 October, Mr Murray said:
My sorrow is only that they left out those last two things that I was trying to get said.

PARA.TAB: In the end it's their business. It just sounds a bit more bureaucratic than I wrote it, but they didn't guarantee I would be providing something set in cast iron that they had to take.
Mine was a bit more daring. It put the citizen above the Government and made the Government into our servants and it expected Australia will be loyal to us.

SPEECH.PARA: That is not a bad idea, is it—that we expect Australia to be loyal to us? At the end of the day I do not mind whether we pledge allegiance to the Queen of Australia or whether we pledge allegiance to Australia. Some of my colleagues think differently. It does not particularly worry me. The Queen is our Queen and is the head of state and will remain so unless the government, by the will of the people through referendum, changes our constitutional arrangement. I doubt that that will happen at any time in the near or medium future. But in any case it does not worry me. I am quite happy for people to swear allegiance to Australia. It is a concept that I can well and truly cope with.

PARA.TAB: The thing I object to in this oath is the fact that it lacks any sense of responsibility on the part of citizens towards their fellow citizens, towards their communities, towards their states and towards their government. No responsibility is taken by anyone for this act. As my colleague the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) just said, the oath does not even require one to state one's name. It is an anonymous pledge of loyalty to Australia—`I will be loyal'. I think we need to go further than that.

The government should rethink this pledge. I think the solid, demonstrated voice of opposition to proceeding with this legislation ought to give the government cause to think again. Surely we can come together and agree, as we do on many things in this place and in committees outside these four walls. Surely we can come together and agree on a new oath that we all find acceptable and desirable. Surely we can come up with some words that add a sense of responsibility for one's actions and the responsibility that one takes when one becomes a citizen of Australia, because there are parts of our culture, parts of our ethos which we rightly insist that new citizens join and share.

We expect that people from other countries will not reject their heritage, will not reject their background, will not reject their ancestors and will have great pride in those things. But we, as a nation, need cohesiveness to work together. After all, we are one of the world's greatest melting pots of humanity. In my view, there is no other nation that has handled so well the transition of bringing people from all over the world from all backgrounds into an atmosphere which has not produced ethnic or religious hatred and violence and has provided for its citizens in a manner that means we demonstrably do not have the ghettos and the abject poverty which exist in so many other countries.

This is a bastion of democracy. It is a bastion of freedom but a place also where each of us needs carefully to make sure that we exercise our responsibilities—each of us to each other and to this nation. If we do not, surely our democratic system will fail just as our nation will fail. Any concept of that frightens me. Other countries today are going through terrible times of questioning who they are and what they mean, as various segments of their societies try to rewrite history and segregate themselves from the new society that has been formed.

Arthur Schlesinger Jr, in a book entitled the Disuniting of America, points out to us a lesson which we ignore at our peril. Schlesinger says essentially that, in his country—the United States of America—the peoples are breaking themselves apart into many discrete bits and pieces, whereas we, from this distance, see America as perhaps the world's greatest shining example of democracy and integration of peoples from many backgrounds. But it is breaking apart, because people are looking more to their individual ethnic backgrounds. They are calling themselves by hyphenated names with `Americans' last, so that groups become Jewish-Americans, Irish-Americans, Bosnian-Americans, Afro-Americans or whatever.

In Australia, with our multicultural process and with our attempts—feeble or otherwise—to come to grips with the differences that seem from time to time to divide indigenous Australians from the rest of Australia, somehow we have managed altogether so far to produce not perfection but something that works particularly well. We must be very careful that we do not follow the path of the United States—that is, that we do not start to break up into little bits and pieces—because our federation will not survive it and neither will our democracy. I say to honourable members that we have so much of which to be proud as Australians that we need to work to make sure that we retain it.
The pledge which we have discussed is inconsistent with any concept of dual citizenship, but the parliamentary secretary, in his second reading speech, said:

In dealing with this amendment, I wish to refer briefly to the High Court decision relating to the Wills by-election. That decision clearly has very important implications for those Australian citizens who are dual citizens and their ability to fully enjoy the rights of other Australian citizens. The government has already made clear that it intends to pursue these issues with the opposition with a view to changing the current constitutional requirements for eligibility for parliament. In our view Australian citizenship should be sufficient qualification.

SPEECH.PARA: I take exception to the parliamentary secretary's statement. I am a new Australian, and I am proud of the fact that I am an Australian by choice. I am a member of this parliament and am proud of that fact as well, but I tell honourable members that I will fight with every ounce of energy that is available in my body to change the requirement that one has allegiance only to Australia. I decry the fact that this oath of citizenship does not require one to renounce former allegiances or citizenship. I believe it is a bad mistake—a very bad mistake. I believe that, if this legislation is passed, we will live to regret that decision. Surely, as the people's representatives, we must be able to demonstrate to everyone in the community and to the world at large our absolute commitment to this nation and to its people—not only to the world at large but to Australia and to Australians. I am disappointed with this legislation, and I ask the government once again to reconsider. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lieberman The Hon L.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to express some grave concerns about the Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill which, as we all know, is designed to change the Australian Citizenship Act to incorporate a preamble and to introduce a new form of commitment to Australia for people who are becoming citizens of Australia, for example, through naturalisation. In relation to the points that concern me, I must say that I do not just rely on my experience as an Australian. I have asked a lot of people from all walks of life in my electorate for their opinions on this issue and I have also asked people who have been through naturalisation ceremonies and who came from other countries. I hope that I am able to give a fairly broad basis of opinion. Hopefully, I can persuade the government to think again, although I suspect that it is a forlorn hope to get this government to think again on an issue such as this.

PARA.TAB: The first thing I would like to say is that I find it very sad that Australian politics today has reached a point where a matter as fundamental as the commitment that people make to their country cannot be resolved by all parties and an agreement reached. I think that is sad. As one of the members of this parliament, I have to therefore say I must be partly responsible for that. I am not ducking, in any way, the responsibility that I must have as one of the members of this parliament. I think, however, that it is fair for me to say that a lot of the problems attendant to this issue and other major issues in Australia stem from the way in which the Keating government has been running Australia, making decisions and manipulating people's views and policies. In that sense, many Australians feel an enormous amount of distrust and concern and a betrayal at the way in which the current government—when we consider the terms of Mr Hawke and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—has been in control and has been stewards of Australia's interests for more than a decade.

Many people say to me in relation to this proposal that it seems odd and strange that the government seems to want to make a change to the way in which people embrace Australian citizenship ahead of the resolution of other items that have been placed on the agenda by the Prime Minister. I refer of course to the issue of republicanism, which is not yet resolved, which is in its early days of discussion and which already has seen the government, in its own way, attempting to manipulate the issue to its advantage.

People ask me why we are being asked to agree to legislation on this issue when more fundamental issues about Australia have not yet been resolved. Thankfully, the issue of the republic will be resolved by a referendum. I suspect that if the constitution did not protect us in that regard there is no way that the Prime Minister would acknowledge that there will be a referendum. I believe he concedes reluctantly that there has to be a referendum. Thank goodness for the foresight of the fathers of Federation in that regard.

It is odd that a fundamental issue, such as the republican issue, placed on the agenda by the government is not anywhere near being resolved; yet this legislation, in my view and in that of many others, is a logical consequence and outcome of the resolution of that most important issue. For my part, the constitutional monarchy—the system under which this nation operates now and has for many years—despite its imperfections, is by far the most proven and best system that any democracy can have.

I, for one, welcome debate on any changes put forward, but I feel very strongly that no case has been made to support the abandonment of the constitutional monarchy and its safeguards, checks and balances, which to me are more important than the arguments put forward by the Prime Minister, who attempts to convert it into an argument about the relevance of royalty to Australia. It is much more than that. It goes much deeper than that. We should be concerned about the checks and balances that protect our nation and control the parliament and the executive and ensure proper accountability.

It was a privilege to hear the contribution from the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles). How unique it is to hear a person who was an American citizen talk about these issues as a very true and committed Australian. We are very proud indeed to have the honourable member on our side of the House—as I am sure all honourable members are very pleased and proud to have him in this parliament.

I have been an admirer of American democracy for a long while. When I see Americans celebrating an important event and pledging loyalty to their country, I sometimes feel that they do it with more vigour than Australians. I wonder why that is. I think perhaps it is a characteristic of Australians that we do not sing easily—maybe it is because we all sing as badly as I do! But the fact is that we are not as expressive as other nationalities, especially Americans. When Americans participate in public ceremonies about their country one cannot help but feel that they really do love their country. They show it, which I think is very good. I would like to think that perhaps one day Australians will break down their inhibitions and be a bit more expressive and forceful.

That is why a proposal to change the oath or affirmation, which this bill proposes to do, and convert it into a simple pledge, quite frankly, worries me. I was going to say that it offends me, but I think that is an overstatement; it worries me more than it offends me.

I believe an oath or an affirmation of allegiance to one's country has a stronger message, a stronger personal commitment, than a mere pledge. As a lawyer, I do not want to get into legalistic argument as to what a pledge really means in contrast to an oath or an affirmation. Rather, I would like to refer to the customs of our nation. When people have to go to court and give evidence they are required to give that evidence on oath or by affirmation. In certain committees of the parliament people giving evidence are frequently required to do so on oath or by affirmation. In that sense, I feel that it is part of Australian tradition and when someone says something on oath or by affirmation it has very deep and meaningful connotations, with repercussions that can provide the basis for a criminal charge for perjury, for example, which is a very serious offence.

I do not see the same degree of seriousness and commitment in the words of this bill as I feel exist in relation to the oath or the affirmation. To me, to simply say `I pledge', whilst it is important, does not have the same effect.

My other point I think is similar to one made by the honourable member for La Trobe. When we look at the proposed pledge, we see that it does not in any way indicate an absolute commitment, which I think citizens of Australia should make to their country. The words in the schedule state that from this time forward, under God, `I pledge my loyalty to Australia and its people'. I think any new form of words should contain a commitment; an absolute commitment.

I respect very much the people who have come from other countries—my father did and I am very proud of his background and my heritage. Notwithstanding that, I think when people do take on citizenship it is a privilege, it is something that they can be very proud of. I think it is right and proper that in doing that they should make a commitment, an absolute commitment, and not leave unsaid—as I suspect the words in the schedule have been deliberately drafted to leave unsaid—the unresolved question of dual citizenship.

I have spoken to many of my constituents who have not become Australian citizens yet who, in my view, are very good citizens of Australia. For example, some people from Holland find it very difficult to enter into an oath or affirmation of allegiance because of their strong ties to their old country and indeed to its constitutional system, including the royal family. But in discussions with them, I believe their arguments cannot be sustained—particularly if the form of oath or affirmation that they are offered is one that does not in any way diminish or depreciate their own origins or background.

I would like to have seen included in an appropriate form of oath or affirmation an acknowledgment of the importance to these people of their previous nationality and country, and the acknowledgment and right of these people to continue to feel very proud about that. These people could then say that, having experienced the opportunity to be part of this democracy—a part of this country—they want to be citizens of Australia, absolutely committed to Australia. It could be made absolutely clear in that context that that is the basis on which they take up citizenship. I think perhaps that is one of the things which could have been incorporated in a proposed amendment.
I make another rather interesting point. In his second reading speech, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr O'Keefe) says in one paragraph:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is a parliamentary democracy committed to providing equality before the law, freedom of the individual, freedom of speech and religion, equality between men and women and equality of opportunity for all.

I embrace and support all of those valuable statements. However, if we look at the form of pledge that the legislation, if enacted, will bring into law, nowhere do we see those words. Why is that the case? We all know that the second reading speech will soon be forgotten. It certainly will not be read at naturalisation ceremonies throughout Australia in the future. For the life of me, I cannot understand why the government did not include in the form of words the actual words that characterise Australia. In my case, I would argue that as I make the oath or affirmation of loyalty I make an oath to support

equality, freedom, freedom of speech and religion, equality between men and women and equality of opportunity for all. I think that those words or similar words should be incorporated in an appropriate, contemporary form of commitment when one becomes a naturalised citizen.

PARA.TAB: I am troubled—I know that other speakers for the coalition have touched on this—by some aspects of the citizenship law anyway. I think that it is more than overdue that these provisions be urgently reviewed. I briefly give one example of one of the nonsenses that exist in the law at the moment. I have a constituent who came to Australia from Scotland at the age of four with his parents, brothers and sisters. The constituent attended school and university in Australia and qualified as an engineer from Melbourne University. His parents are naturalised citizens of Australia. His brothers and sisters are naturalised. After working in Australia following graduation, he went overseas, as many young professional Australians do, to gain experience and knowledge and has worked for several years in other countries—at times involved in programs that are, I think, associated with United Nations operations in Third World countries—gaining skills and also imparting skills to others.

Because he has been working overseas for more than five years, he apparently is no longer entitled to a permanent entrance visa to come back to Australia, which he has always done at least once or twice a year for holidays and to spend time with his family. He has been shocked, and so too has his family, to find that whenever he wishes to come to Australia, where he has lived since the age of four—he is now nearly 30—he has to make special application for a visa to come back in. At a couple of interviews that he has had, I believe that he has been more or less told that he should not regard any future application for a visa as something that would normally be granted forthwith; that he is now in a position where he is almost regarded as a foreigner—in fact, he is.

In discussions with this young constituent and his family, the constituent said, `The only reason I am not naturalised is that I never thought about it, having been brought up in Australia and regarding myself as an Australian. It is only now that I realise that I should have been naturalised before I embarked on my work and career overseas. I would like to become naturalised'. The point is that, to become naturalised, he has to apply to the minister, who has a discretion under section 13 of the act to consider applications by people for citizenship who have not lived continuously in Australia for, I think, one year out of the last two. The minister has the power to grant the right to take on citizenship to such people provided certain criteria are established. One is that the person has a commitment to Australia. Obviously, from what I have said, how could we not accept that this person, with his family involvement and all the rest, does not have a commitment to Australia?

Apparently, one of the clauses in the policy—and in the act as well, I think—says that the person has to convince the minister that the work done overseas is of importance and significance to Australia. There is a High Court decision that virtually says that, because of the policy that was put down by a minister for immigration in 1967, that contribution has to be at the highest level, such as at the diplomatic level. That is nonsense. If a young Australian working overseas—building dams and helping Third World countries—gaining experience, skills and contacts is regarded as not making a significant contribution to Australia, for the life of me, I wonder what on earth has gone wrong with Australia. Our young Australians are the ones we should be encouraging to get out, have a go, learn things about other nations, find things, find new markets and come back and help this country grow. That aspect of the constituent's problem does not appear to be recognised.

I have asked the minister for an urgent deputation so that the family can hopefully have a citizenship ceremony for their son by Christmas, which will also celebrate their 70th birthdays and their 25th year in Australia. To date, I have not heard from the minister whether he will see me so that I can at least put to him that the sort of service and experience of this young Australian, who wants to formalise his Australian citizenship by being naturalised, is of significant importance to this nation. One does not have to be a high commissioner, a diplomat or a general to make a significant contribution to his or her nation. Contributions come from a lot of areas on a lot of levels. I am hoping that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, will support me in my request to see the minister. I hope that I can persuade the minister. For God's sake, let this young Australian becomes naturalised. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Mr R.D.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1993 seeks to amend the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 to insert a preamble which will give recognition to the significance of Australian citizenship. It would also amend the Citizenship Act to abolish the current oath or affirmation of allegiance and replace it with a pledge of commitment. It also seeks to remove all reference to the Queen as head of state from the commitment made by new citizens on taking a grant of citizenship.

PARA.TAB: As I stand before this House, I can say, with all the frankness and humility I can muster, that I am an Australian and I am very proud of it. I am also an Australian patriot. I will defend its people, its institutions and its resources. I will also defend its history and its future. I proudly stand in this place and offer my country total loyalty and devotion and state publicly that I will never let it or its people down.

Whatever the constitutional evolution of Australia over the next few years, or the institutions it will provide to its people in the new world of the 21st century, I will continue to defend my country. I will stand by her and help her through these troubled times. I will not allow those who wish to dismantle Australia's institutions to bring about change for change's sake. Now more than in any other time in Australia's recent history, my country needs me as well as others to defend its institutions from sustained attack by those who do not see themselves as Australians but rather as some poor group of recreants having some sort of identity crisis.

It has been noted that a country's greatest patriots are those who dare challenge the authority of their own government. I will not allow those who attempt to dismantle Australia's institutions, who are vandalising our national symbols, to do so in the absence of any resistance. These people who see themselves as Australians lacking identity do not care about our history—a history of which we should be proud for it makes us what we are today.

Now, more than at any other time in Australia's history, we are required to defend our nation's institutions and symbols from assault by those who do not see themselves clearly as Australians. We are a country of uniqueness; a country of extremes. We are fiercely, proudly individual and we do not suffer fools gladly. It seems that some fools wish to continue to restructure our heritage and our history. The people who support the changes before us do not care about our history—a history of which we should be proud. Our history and our traditions make us what we are today. The poor fools looking for identity wish to change to help them attain some sort of Australian identity which, for the majority of Australians, we already have.

The Australian identity of which our opponents feel so ashamed is an Australian identity which fits comfortably with the majority of Australians. The anger within those opposite, who cannot call themselves Australian because of our heritage, must be very serious, for they constantly talk about their future vision of our country without recognising its history and its heritage. What absolute hypocrisy to claim that we are not fully Australian because we recognise our heritage and respect our history. Where do those who wish for identity aspire to when they seek to reduce our institutions to a babble of misbeliefs? What do these people actually think of when they watch Australians achieve greatness? Do they wish we were a republic? What do they think of when Australian cricket teams thrash England at cricket? Do they go into some sort of rapture of republicanism and try to wave the flag of their new identity? Recently Senator Schacht, at one of his party conferences, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I believe it is only a reality that we are dealing with—is that we have got to identify and create our own identity, a national characteristic, and one of those ways is declare ourselves a republic.

He said, `We have got to identify our own identity'. I thought we already had. Do these representatives of the Australian people really find Australia's history so repugnant that they refuse to accept that they are Australian until the institutions of our nation are reduced to rubble and ruin? I pity these poor souls for they must live their lives in a constant state of revolution and fierce devotion to an ideal that most Australians already have. Australia will evolve; to what, its people will decide—not to the rage of frustrated government members who wish to betray the very nature of Australia's heritage.

PARA.TAB: Our government system—one of the most stable in the world—has as its centrepiece its constitution and monarchical system where no one person has absolute power. It is a system of government that is envied by many in this world; a system which sees citizens of the world, with varying cultures and heritages, queue to become part of its freedom and prosperity; a system that has provided a safe and sure environment for its citizens for many years without war or other political upheavals that could not be solved by the people. Australians supposedly lacking in identity have created this. We do not lack identity; the frustrated speakers proposing this bill do.

The principles of being Australian are fairly easily understood by those wishing to accept Australianism. I remind those who wish to undermine our nation, its history and its heritage of this. To use the words of the FitzGerald report, Immigration—a commitment to Australia, our basic institutions and principles include: parliamentary democracy, although I must say this is questionable this year with the government's abuse of it; the rule of law and equality before the law; freedom of the individual; freedom of speech—in certain debates in our nation currently that can be questionable; freedom of the press; freedom of religion; equality of women; and universal education.

I look at these institutions and reflect upon the doctrine that the government has wished to impose upon us over the last decade, and I challenge those opposite to stop and allow the people of Australia to get on with making Australia the terrific place it has proudly boasted of since Federation. Now we are asked to change the oath or affirmation which most Australians who have sought citizenship have made without any reflection upon their own identity.

It is only those who lack an Australian character and identity who want us to look to our inner selves and seek some new order, like some strange sect, to establish a new identity. What is wrong with the current oath of allegiance? What is so wrong that we have to change the institution of allegiance? If we were a republic the endeavours of the government in this matter could be accepted, but the important point right now in Australia is that we are not a republic. This amendment threatens another of Australia's sacred symbols.
I agree with those who say that our oath should reflect our country's systems and its institutions. In fact, the FitzGerald report stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The status of citizenship is seriously undervalued . . . citizenship should reflect a commitment to Australia and its institutions and principles . . . key Australian principles and institutions must have the support of the immigrant, and citizenship must be a watershed in the immigrant experience.
How does this new idea of an oath become a watershed? It is more like a republican push by those opposite.

PARA.TAB: The legislation before this House, in my view, is premature and is proving to be unpopular. Let us face it, it is based on the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs which looked into this issue. It is designed to pre-empt the debate on constitutional change. Change for the sake of change by those seeking to find a new identity can, and perhaps will, create unpopular division within our community. If the Australian public wish to move down the republican track, then that is the appropriate time to review these types of institutions.

To attempt to push some sort of new world idea onto those choosing to gain the much valued Australian citizenship by reference to our current style or system of government is bizarre in the extreme. In his presentation to the Senate, Senator Bolkus remarked that the Queen remains a central point of our constitutional arrangements; yet to persist with this self-denial process is bordering on the extreme. We ask our new citizens to show allegiance to our great nation by declaring support for our system of government; yet our current masters, apparently lacking in Australian identity, suggest that it is totally okay to deny our current safe and secure system of constitutional government.

I refute the suggestion that the new oath is strong in emotion and passionate about our nation. If we are to change, then I strongly recommend that we review the wording to not only provide allegiance to our system of government, but also show some sort of passionate declaration for Australia. The current oath supports our institutional government system and declares unreserved duty to our nation. It may be argued that it is insufficient in its strength in declaring allegiance, and I tend to agree with that point of view.

The suggestion is to replace the oath or affirmation of allegiance with a pledge of commitment. We are either strongly declaring Australia to be our chosen nation, or we are not. Why is it that we have to weaken our pledge with some sort of wishy-washy pledge of commitment? As an example, the Americans make no apology for their system of government and they strongly state allegiance to their country. The American oath of allegiance reads:

SPEECH.PARA: I hereby declare, on oath, that I absolutely and entirely renounce and abjure all allegiance and fidelity to any foreign prince, potentate, state or sovereignty, to whom or which I heretofore have been a subject or citizen; that I will support and defend the constitution and the laws of the United States of America against all enemies foreign and domestic; that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the same; that I will bear arms on behalf of the United States when required by law; that I will perform non-combatant service in the armed forces of the United States when required by the law; that I will perform work of national importance under civilian direction when required by law; and that I take this obligation freely without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; so help me God.

There is no doubt what the American oath of allegiance is about. This bill seeks to remove an already insufficient declaration of commitment to Australia and replace it with a weaker commitment which declares nothing other than an observance of laws and the fulfilment of duties. One is tempted to ask, `What duties?'.

PARA.TAB: Where is the conviction of allegiance in this new pledge? Where is the declaration of loyalty to our great nation? Where is the commitment to the system of our government? We end up with some sort of lovely statement about holistic attitudes towards democracy and laws. Where is the Australian character in this proposed new pledge? For instance, the boy scout pledge is more committed. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: On my honour, I promise that I will do my best, to do my duty to my God, and to the Queen of Australia, to help other people and to live by the Scout law.

Even the end of the standard marriage vow says, `Till death us do part'. There is passion and commitment from these pledges. There is a very big commitment in these oaths compared with what is being proposed today. Rather than determinedly state without reservation a declaration of absolute allegiance and renounce all previous loyalty to other countries, this new order would have us pledge commitment to nothing but an absolute.

PARA.TAB: The coalition's position on this issue is very clear and well documented. We have stressed that it is essential that the requirements for obtaining citizenship should be strengthened to ensure that prospective citizens understand the true meaning and extent of their commitment to Australia.

Objections raised in the minority report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs deserve reiteration in this debate. One of those points is that the bill is another effort by the government to divert the attention of parliament from other more critical issues.

The minority report went on to say that the Citizenship Act of 1948 is in need of complete review. The act was described as an `abysmal document'. It was held to be inappropriate to make piecemeal amendments prior to such a full scale review.

Another point made was that it is not appropriate for the parliament in a piecemeal fashion to move towards such a change before the community debate has concluded and any such decision has been made. Australia is a constitutional monarchy and it is entirely appropriate that the oath require a new citizen to swear allegiance to our head of state. The FitzGerald report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The most important act in becoming an Australian ought to be act of becoming an Australian citizen.

How is it that these esteemed people can be so wrong and the new order driving us to a new nation can be so right? The ones that are wrong in this debate are the ones advocating rushing through change because they desire a new identity. If we are to change, why not seek public discussion and seek the opinion of those who would know best the advantages of being an Australian—Australians. The problem with this democratic concept is that the Labor Party does not respect or even acknowledge democratic principles.

PARA.TAB: The Citizenship Act requires a complete overhaul; not the partial, piecemeal, confused, politically motivated and divisive amendments that are being proposed by this bill. To proceed with it in advance of any future constitutional change would be divisive, pre-emptive and of questionable legality.

For all these reasons, particularly the point that the bill is premature at this time given the current state of debate over our constitutional arrangements, I oppose this legislation. I call upon those opposite, if they yearn for change in our future, to learn to respect our past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1993 is not so much about necessary or justifiable changes to existing legislation or processes; rather, it is another item on the anti-British agenda which our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is trying to introduce with what can only be regarded as indecent haste. His cause is, of course, futile. Despite one's best endeavours, one cannot change history even if one is the Prime Minister. It is useless and dangerous to say to people that they must ignore or cast aside part of their heritage because some people would like to pretend that things had happened differently.

PARA.TAB: I think that in a debate such as this it is important to acknowledge that some government members are also deeply concerned about their leader's agenda. Unfortunately, they have little opportunity to express their misgivings but I know that they will be supportive of the comments and attitudes expressed by members of the coalition parties and the community generally in regard to these matters. The Prime Minister and some members of his Labor government are seeking to change our national institutions and symbols despite the fact that the majority of Australians see no reason for change and are opposed to change at this time.

First it was our national flag; then the safeguards offered by our constitutional monarchy; now the oath or affirmation of allegiance sworn or declared by new Australian citizens. There is no good reason for the government to introduce this bill at this time. These amendments are premature in that they pre-empt the outcome of a significant and ongoing community debate, a debate which will have an enormous impact on the future of this nation.

Furthermore, these amendments are based on unsubstantiated assertions about supposed widespread community concern and dissatisfaction with the present requirements for, and processes involved with, the granting of Australian citizenship. But there is no hard evidence to back these claims; in fact, quite the contrary. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr O'Keefe) in his second reading speech tried hard to justify the need for this legislation. But he failed to come up with any reasonable explanation as to why, under current circumstances, the existing oath or affirmation should be replaced with the proposed pledge of commitment. This is hardly surprising, really. The parliamentary secretary talked about giving:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . proper recognition to the significance of Australian citizenship as a common bond which unites all Australians.
It already has; it already does. He said:
The government's view is that there is strong and growing support for ensuring that our national symbols effectively express our distinctive identity.
They already do. He said:
The government believes the time is right to change our citizenship law to reinforce the place of Australian citizenship as a defining element of our national identity.
It already is. The parliamentary secretary then went on to say:

The current Australian Citizenship Act 1948 is principally concerned about the process of acquiring and losing citizenship. This is inadequate. The act should also contain a preamble defining the meaning which the parliament and the people of Australia accord to citizenship.

Apart from the fact that one would have thought that the Australian Citizenship Act should be principally concerned with the process of acquiring and losing citizenship—what else would it be concerned about?—if the proposed preamble is meant to define the meaning which the parliament and the people of Australia accord to citizenship, then it falls far short of its stated objective. How can one hope to properly and adequately define in a few words the freedoms, security, rights, privileges and obligations that Australian citizenship bestows and that Australian citizens enjoy. It would probably be just as appropriate to say, `I love Australia' or, `I am proud to be an Australian'.

PARA.TAB: In any event, the preamble would not be needed if the government was not so keen to change the oath of allegiance. Both the existing oath and affirmation make it clear that, to use the parliamentary secretary's words:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . citizenship involves both rights and obligations, which are enshrined in the constitution and our laws.

I have great difficulty in accepting the premise that the proposed pledge of commitment will be any more `equally meaningful' to all Australians than the already existing oath or affirmation is already. What is more `equally meaningful' about a wishy-washy, watered-down pledge than a clear, concise and straightforward oath or affirmation? The parliamentary secretary also stated in his speech:

Australia is one of those few countries which actually relish its diversity. Under the umbrella of an overall commitment to the nation and its uniting values and institutions, a society of great richness and variety as well as remarkable harmony has evolved.

I remind him, and his colleagues who are supporting this bill, that all this has occurred over a period when new Australian citizens have been required to use the existing oath. How can government members now argue it is inadequate? By the admission of the parliamentary secretary, the existing oath has obviously served, and continues to serve, its purpose well; so why change it? Later in his speech the parliamentary secretary asserted:
Some residents are reluctant to apply for citizenship partly because they do not see the present oath or affirmation as being adequately Australian in character.

What sort of a shonky, ill-founded claim is that? How many are `some'—10, 20, 100, 1,000? For that matter, how much is `partly'? If, as the parliamentary secretary admits, the present oath or affirmation is only `partly' the reason for the reluctance of this undefined number of people becoming citizens, then what does the term `partly' actually mean? Is it a major factor or a minor factor amongst numerous other unidentified considerations? Such a statement is about as profound and useful as asking, `How long is a piece of string?'.

PARA.TAB: What does the term `adequately Australian' mean? How more adequately Australian can a statement be when it requires a new citizen to swear, or, as in the case of the affirmation, solemnly and sincerely promise and declare to be faithful and bear true allegiance to our constitutional Australian head of state, and to faithfully observe the laws of Australia and fulfil the duties of an Australian citizen? In fact, the words `Australia' and `Australian' are mentioned three times in the existing oath or affirmation and only once in the proposed pledge. How does one make something more adequately Australian by proceeding to delete two-thirds of the existing references to Australia? Furthermore, has the government considered that some who are partly deterred from applying for citizenship by the `inadequately Australian' wording of the current oath or affirmation, may in fact be significantly less in number than those who will find this new proposed pledge unacceptable? Where are the figures to back up the government's claims that more people will be satisfied with the new wording? The claim is obviously a hollow one.

Since 1984, I have represented the people of Casey in this parliament, and in that time only one person has expressed dissatisfaction about the wording of the existing oath. I have attended many citizenship ceremonies and have witnessed the pride, respect and dignity with which men and women of all ages and ethnic backgrounds repeat the words that formalise their decision to become Australian citizens. There is no doubt that it is a momentous, meaningful and significant decision. Few, if any, have taken it lightly or for the wrong reasons. The vast majority have made a considered decision. They know what they are doing and they accept what is required of them. Is the government now seriously suggesting that all these new citizens, or even a significant percentage of them, do not really mean what they say and are not taking their responsibilities seriously? Is it suggesting that they are swearing the oath or declaring the affirmation with their tongues in their cheeks or their fingers crossed behind their backs? That is certainly not my observation or experience. Nor is it the observation or experience of one of my constituents, Mr George Mohren, who knows more about this particular matter than most people.

George Mohren happens to have been a migrant. He arrived in Australia from Germany in 1960 and became an Australian citizen in 1965. At that time, the waiting period was five years instead of two as at present. George served for 27 1/2 years with the immigration department. He spent 18 of those years with the citizenship section. During that time, George personally conferred Australian citizenship on more than 25,000 people. He processed applications for citizenship from a quarter of a million more. Following his retirement in 1987, he has maintained his interest and involvement in the citizenship process in a voluntary capacity. Over the past six years he has assisted with the organisation and conduct of hundreds of citizenship ceremonies in the shires of Lillydale and the cities of Croydon and Knox.

When the government first mooted its intention to alter the existing oath and affirmation, I discussed the matter with George and sought his ideas on the proposed changes. He told me that, from a personal point of view, he was not in favour of them. As recently as yesterday, I checked with him again to see whether he had altered his opinion. He had not. His opposition to the proposed changes is based on his personal belief that they are not only inappropriate, but also demonstrably unnecessary. He should know because of his significant first-hand knowledge and experience of, and direct involvement with, thousands of new Australian citizens and the processes connected with the granting of Australian citizenship.

George Mohren has told me that over the many years he served with the citizenship section at the immigration department, and during the six years voluntary assistance he has provided to local municipalities since his retirement, he has `only very rarely'—those are his exact words and they are worth repeating; `only very rarely'—encountered people who have had objections to the existing oath or affirmation, and the requirement to bear true allegiance to the Queen of Australia, in particular. However, in all but one of these rare cases, people who were at first apprehensive finally overcame their misgivings and took the oath or affirmation. The only one definite refusal was on religious grounds. George Mohren also told me that most of the very few people he had come across who had some difficulty in accepting this condition of citizenship happened to be of Irish descent. He emphasised that this was not in any way a criticism or slur in so far as the Irish are concerned, but simply a matter of fact.

The fact that some people of Irish descent have difficulty in accepting the historical links which have resulted in the fact that the Queen of Australia is also, amongst other things, the Queen of Great Britain and Northern Ireland is not a new problem.In his work entitled The foundations of culture in Australia, the late P.R. Stephensen—Australian publisher, author and former Rhodes scholar—wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: The Irish element in Australia . . . never loved England, nor had any reason to love England . . . But to be anti-English is not in itself enough to make one a good Australian.

Our Prime Minister, for one, should contemplate these words very carefully. It is not appropriate or acceptable to be tempted to change something that the vast majority find inoffensive simply to cater for the few whose attitudes are influenced by events which may have occurred—or for that matter may still be occurring—in faraway places. If we fail to resist such temptations, then we are effectively inviting those who have old scores to settle to bring their prejudices with them to Australia.

PARA.TAB: We cannot afford to make such an enormous error. We cannot, and should not, tolerate minority views based on historical dislikes of one nationality for another. Perpetuation of hatreds founded in the past contributes nothing to our nation's future. This is Australia and we are first and foremost Australian citizens. We are a multicultural nation, but that does not mean we should be anti-British, anti-Irish or anti-anything. We should simply be pro-Australian. Otherwise debates on matters of national identity degenerate into a sort of `my heritage is better than your heritage'. That is not only unacceptable, but also most unwise. We must accept that, whilst differences may enrich us, dissension will make us poorer.

It is paradoxical that some of those people who protest longest and loudest, albeit incorrectly, that we are still an outpost of empire, contrive to ensure that we will return to this former status by continually insisting on allowing past differences and difficulties which have existed between other nations to influence our Australian attitudes and way of life. This applies particularly in regard to the requirements for and of Australian citizenship.

In this context, it is alarming to find so many government members and senators speaking in support of this bill on the basis that Australians should not be required to express their allegiance to an English monarch. Australians are not required to do any such thing, and neither should they be. Australians owe allegiance to the Queen of Australia, as is entirely appropriate and certainly in accordance with the provisions of our Australian constitution.

How can people become loyal and law abiding citizens of a country if they are not prepared to be bound by that country's constitution, or to accept and acknowledge that country's lawful head of state? In swearing allegiance to the Queen of Australia, Australian citizens are in fact swearing allegiance to the Australian Commonwealth. There is no excuse for confusion in this regard, except that the government seems intent on creating it for its own republican purposes.

It is also alarming to hear comments and arguments such as those expressed in another place by the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht), who accused the opposition of wanting to use an oath of allegiance, that is—to use the honourable senator's words—`clearly written for the 19th century'. What is so wrong with that, senator? Every day we open this parliament with a prayer which was clearly written for several centuries prior to the 19th century, but that does not mean that it has lost its significance and is no longer relevant for today.

Contrary to the impression the government is endeavouring to create, the changes proposed in this bill have nothing to do with any real or identifiable need to change the current requirements for the granting of Australian citizenship, but everything to do with the anti-British and pro-republican views of the Prime Minister and others. It is not a question of improving our Australian identity but of attempting to destroy those elements of our heritage, including our national institutions and symbols, which reflect our historical links with Britain.

The motives behind this government's growing agenda for unwarranted, unwanted and inappropriate changes to our national institutions and symbols are so transparent that they hardly need restating, except that it is important and necessary to remind people that, contrary to the principles of democracy, the Prime Minister wants his republic so badly that he is determined to impose the will of the minority on the majority—whether we need it or not, whether we like it or not and whether we want it or not.

The fact is that we do not need it, we do not like it and we do not want it. The majority of Australians have, at least for the time being, rejected the republican notion. In introducing and supporting legislation such as this bill, the government is counting its republican chickens well before they are hatched and should not be surprised to find—as it most assuredly will—that in so far as this matter is concerned it has managed to lay a very large, and rotten, egg indeed.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Why is it that the selection of projects to be funded under the community, cultural, recreation and sporting facilities program, according to the Auditor-General's report that was tabled in this House yesterday, was made in your office and no record was maintained?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. The Auditor-General made it clear that no political bias in the grants could be proved. The grants were made in total accordance with the guidelines and selection criteria. I would like to read those to the House so people are aware of what those guidelines were. The selection criteria were:

ANSWER.PARA: .a demonstrated community need for the proposed facility;
.evidence of the capacity for on-going management and maintenance of the facility;
.evidence of a firm financial commitment from other funding sources for the project;
.a demonstrated consideration of access for people with disabilities, and the provision of child-care facilities where applicable . . .
There was also a timetable for completion. The guidelines continued:
Priority will be given to the needs of:
Those issues were taken into consideration when the grants were allocated.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. What does he hope to be the result of the APEC leaders meeting in Seattle? What implications may the meeting have for Australia's future trading prospects, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region?

—I think the word `historic' is often overworked but I do not think that in applying it to this meeting in our wildest imagination we could say that it was. It is a gathering of the leaders of the Asia-Pacific community, representing half the production of the world. The leaders are from the United States, China, Japan, Korea, Thailand, Indonesia, Australia, Canada, New Zealand, Singapore, Malaysia, et cetera. This grouping is coming together at a time when we are seeing substantial growth in the Asia-Pacific area. We should recognise that it is already a more integrated area than the European Community or even NAFTA. More goods are traded within the area, one country to another, than are traded within North America or within the European Community.

PARA.TAB: APEC was an initiative of this Labor government in 1989. Now it is an organisation of great importance to Australian interests. Already, three-quarters of our exports go to APEC countries, which are a source of two-thirds of our imports, and nine of our 10 top export markets are APEC countries. So this is obviously where we already are in terms of growth, exports and imports. So the challenge now for the APEC area is how to become more closely integrated and how we can maintain rapid growth rates, increasing the velocity of trade.

The Seattle meeting, for which I am leaving this afternoon, will help that process. The meeting will be conducted without officials and pre-cooked communiques. The preceding ministerial meeting, which the Minister for Foreign Affairs will be attending, will set the scene for the consideration of a number of practical, new initiatives, including the establishment of a trade and investment framework which will help our trade facilitation agenda and consideration of the report of the eminent persons group, on which Neville Wran represented Australia.

At their meeting the leaders will actually have an unprecedented opportunity to give APEC the boost to its consolidation that could only come from the engagement of the leaders of these countries and to underline the support for the multilateral trading system which has been so material to the growth of the Asia-Pacific community countries. The leaders, while we are there, will also take the opportunity to urge a successful outcome in the closing moments of the Uruguay Round of the GATT negotiations, to put more pressure back on France and the European countries to make the concessions that need to be made to bring the Uruguay Round to a close and to look ahead to explore the ways in which we can develop a closer sense of community in the Asia-Pacific by such things as standardisation of policies, foreign investment policies, taxation policies, food standards, professional standards—all the things that can make the velocity of trade faster and investment opportunities better.

This century has been dominated by the politics and economics of Europe. This very day in the press we saw the United States Secretary of State, Mr Christopher, make clear that, if the Europeans wish to go on in a selfish way in terms of opening up market access and opportunities for the rest of the world, the United States will look more closely to APEC. This was quite a statement, because Secretary of State Christopher indicated that Europe has only two-thirds of the trade that the United States has with the APEC area and it is the APEC area which offers the greater potential for the United States in the event that Europe starts to close up its markets. In any event, Europe is growing far more slowly than is the Asia-Pacific area.

I believe this meeting does offer a great opportunity, and I congratulate President Clinton in extending the invitation and hosting the meeting. I am particularly pleased because the meeting follows from a proposal I made last year and have since discussed with many regional countries.

The consequence is that in trade and investment terms this Labor government has thought about Australia's position in the world not just in multilateral bodies like the GATT and the Uruguay Round and in the establishment of the Cairns group in the prosecution of GATT issues over the course of these last seven years but, with APEC, in taking it first to an information stage as a sort of mini-OECD of the Pacific area and now taking it to a more executive body. It is Labor thinking out aloud and broadly for Australia, thinking about its long-run position in the world, not the next two, three or five years but the next 50 or 100 years—that is, developing the kinds of relationships in Asia and the kinds of structures in the Asia-Pacific which Australia can be a more natural part of than it has been to date.
This leaders' meeting which President Clinton is hosting is indeed a truly historic occasion not just for the United States but for all Asia-Pacific countries, not the least Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon members of a delegation from the parliament of the United Kingdom. On behalf of the House, I extend a very warm welcome to our visitors.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Given the fact that the minister maintains that there was no political bias in grants under the community cultural, recreational and sporting facilities program, could she please explain to the House how Labor electorates got on average $257,000 in grants whereas coalition seats got $141,000 in grants? Could she please explain how Labor marginal seats got on average $326,000 compared with coalition marginal seats which received half of that at $163,000? Could she please explain how her office made these grants and whether it is true, as the Auditor-General has found, that documentation is not available to establish the reasons for the grants?

—As I said in response to the first question, the grants were made on a needs basis. It is obvious, I would have thought, when one looked at the criteria for need, as I outlined in my earlier answer—particularly, for example, the criteria of large youth unemployment and migrant areas—that there would be some obvious areas which would have greater needs than others. For example, under those criteria, the western suburbs of Sydney would have a greater need than the electorate which included Vaucluse.

—Can the Treasurer inform the House what the cost would be to Commonwealth revenue of the abolition of the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and the tax on foreign source income? What would be the effects of such measures on the economy as a whole?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. The taxes to which the honourable member refers are changes which were brought in during the 1980s to repair the structure of revenue collections in Australia which, of course, had fallen into total disrepute under the administration of our predecessors—particularly the honourable member for Bennelong and his close adviser, the now Leader of the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: One of the approaches which the government took during the 1980s was to ensure that there was a greater degree of fairness in the system, that there was a neutrality in terms of particular kinds of income and capital, and that they were essentially treated on a comparable basis so that the efforts to which so many people went to try to disguise income as capital or to rearrange their remuneration in a way in which they received non-cash benefits were essentially eliminated and the tax system was made much fairer.

When the honourable member asks what the cost would be of the elimination of these taxes, it is not just the amount that these taxes bring in in their own right but the extent to which they prevent avoidance and evasion in other ways. To answer the honourable member's question, over the last four years the CGT brought in an average of $482 million a year; in 1992-93 the FBT brought in $1.3 billion; and the foreign source income has brought in $60 million. We have a total there of about $1.8 billion. The abolition of these taxes, of course, would lead to much greater revenue losses than those which are indicated by these figures as we would see a return to the kind of pre-1983 habits of individuals and businesses as they tried to avoid their proper responsibilities with regard to taxation.

Whilst the government was making these reforms, we had the support of the Leader of the Opposition. For instance, in 1987 he said on capital gains and fringe benefits, `I'd go for near uniform taxation of all forms of income'. In other words, in the mid- to late-1980s the Leader of the Opposition agreed that this was the right way to go to make the tax system fairer.

I think we can only lament massively that the Liberal Party has now abandoned any sense of responsibility or revenue neutrality as far as its own tax policy is concerned. Indeed, it is becoming increasingly clear that there has been a total disintegration as far as tax policy is concerned on the other side of the House. On Sunday's Meet the Press program the shadow Treasurer said that it was no longer opposition policy to abolish sales tax, payroll tax and fuel excise, which honourable members will recall were the centrepiece of the changes those opposite thought were so necessary at the time of the last election. They have now decided that sales tax, payroll tax and fuel excise do not matter, even though they ranted and raved mercilessly during the election about the iniquitous nature of these three taxes.

But, intriguingly, the shadow Treasurer was totally silent on what he intended to do about company tax. The House will recall that at the time of the last election the opposition wanted to put up company tax to 42c in the dollar. When asked about this particular issue, of course, the shadow Treasurer was noticeably vague and essentially silent. We now know why he was so vague on that issue: today we learned that it is Senator Bishop's policy to get rid of the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax.

So we see the shadow Treasurer as someone who is hedging his bets. He is going to be a shadow Treasurer for all seasons—a shadow Treasurer for any old leader who happens to come along. So he has it in the back of his mind that, when Senator Bishop comes along as his leader and he has to accommodate the abolition of the fringe benefits tax and the abolition of the capital gains tax, he will need some alternative revenue source. What better than to stick to the idea of maintaining company tax at 42c, as the opposition proposed at the last election? If that policy of company tax at 42c were retained, it would raise from Australian companies $2.7 billion more than would the rate of 33c, which they now pay under this government, would raise.

So here we have it: the shadow Treasurer just hedging his bets a bit, waiting, preparing himself for the time when Senator Bishop comes here, and knocks over the Leader of the Opposition, who no longer stands for anything anyway. He has a ready-made solution to accommodate Senator Bishop as she proposes to wreck the taxation system once again by the abolition of these very important and fair taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories inform the House whether she wrote to honourable members asking for comments on funding proposals, categorising seats as `safe Labor', `marginal Labor', et cetera, as shown in this attached document sent to former Treasurer Willis? I ask: if the grants were needs based, why did marginal Labor seats get a higher average grant than safe coalition seats?

—I ask the honourable member why his electorate got $250,000 in grants. Would the honourable member deny that that was a need in his electorate? Taking the electorates nearby his—namely, Bendigo and Burke—Bendigo, for example, had six grants worth $422,000 and I believe Bendigo is considered a marginal Liberal seat. Next door to that was a marginal Labor seat, and I hate to confess to my colleague that his electorate got only $408,000. As I said, those grants were based on needs and particularly on the important role that many of these centres play in their regions.

—I ask the Prime Minister whether his attention has been drawn to recent criticism of the government's native title legislation. Can he say whether certain people will be disadvantaged by the legislation and what effect the legislation will have in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of criticisms, coming principally from the opposition.

—On a point of order, Mr Speaker: the standing orders relating to questions say quite clearly that questions cannot anticipate discussions upon an order of the day or other matter and cannot refer to debates in the current session. I assumed that I drew that to your attention and that of the Prime Minister yesterday. I believe that the question is therefore out of order.
—As I had considered this a very important issue that might come up, I have taken the opportunity—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—How did you know?

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable member for O'Connor rightly pointed out, he raised it with me himself. I took the opportunity to acquaint myself with the procedures as outlined in House of Representatives Practice. At page 519, under the heading `Anticipation of business', I found that Speaker Snedden in particular, when asked on this matter, had ruled that questions framed in the way that this particular question was framed—I was listening carefully to it—were appropriate. Indeed, the words that were used in part of the question to the Prime Minister were almost a direct lift from House of Representatives Practice. I therefore find that the question is in order.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just talent.

—I am aware of criticisms coming principally from the honourable member for Flinders who is the opposition spokesman on Mabo. I heard him this morning on AM declaring, amongst other things, that the Commonwealth bill recognises the Western Australian bill as a fait accompli. He made three assertions and he is wrong in all of them. First, he said that the bill recognises that Western Australia can legally convert common law title to a statutory version under section 208 of the bill. The bill does not enable the Western Australian government to convert native title to statutory rights. In fact, there is every possibility that the Western Australian legislation will be invalid because of its likely conflict with the Racial Discrimination Act. What is more, the Western Australian bill will be clearly in conflict with clause 21 of the Commonwealth bill, which makes certain future actions impermissible to the extent that they affect native title.

PARA.TAB: All clause 208(3) does is provide that, if the Western Australian legislation were to be valid, it would not have the effect of removing from native title holders the rights they would otherwise have under the Commonwealth legislation; for example, the right to negotiation before a mining lease was issued over this land. Secondly, the honourable member for Flinders says that, faced with this fait accompli, the Commonwealth bill introduces a retrospective law basically to get Western Australia. The honourable member is as wrong here as he is in the first instance; that is, there is no fait accompli since the Commonwealth bill does not recognise that Western Australia can validly convert native title to statutory title. The focus of the bill is not on Western Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fait accompli.
—Did you fail French, Alexander?
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy will not interject across the chamber.

—Not all of us have had elocution lessons. He is an authority on these things. The focus of the bill is not on Western Australia but on any state legislation which would be incompatible with native title.

PARA.TAB: Thirdly, the honourable member says that clause 195 anticipates that the Commonwealth legislation—or large chunks of it—is going to be knocked off by the High Court. That is wrong again. The clause is purely a technical measure, as the explanatory memorandum makes clear. In fact, a similar provision was in the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill which was recently before the House. Not surprisingly, this did not attract the criticism of the honourable member for Flinders.

Mabo has attracted the attention of the honourable member for Flinders because it is his job to try to basically fudge the ground between the Commonwealth's principled legislation and that of Western Australia. More than a year since the High Court decision has been handed down the federal opposition still does not have a policy on Mabo. The first policy that the honourable member for Flinders produced was the government's policy, the government's draft bill. It is attractive to the Liberal Party, which is without policies, and, on this issue, bitterly divided.

It is going to be very interesting because tomorrow is a very big test for the few remaining liberal moderates—the advocates of traditional liberalism—against the romper stompers of the New Right. I remind honourable members of an address the honourable member for Wentworth made less than a month ago to the New South Wales Liberal Party. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: We are the party which has always fought racism when it matters, and it always matters.
If you scratch a Liberal you find a person who is genuinely opposed to racism in any form.

Tomorrow we will see if the Liberal Party can pass a scratch test. We will see exactly what your attitude is. The few remaining moderates will know whether they are in a party that tolerates them only so long as they are ineffectual or whether they will have to join the Puplicks, the Macphees, the Peter Baumes or the Viners on the outside of parliamentary life to establish themselves as moderates within the moderate stream of traditional liberalism in this country. They will find out, and the electorate will find out, whether the Liberal Party really has disavowed the extremist policies which lost it the last election.If the honourable member for Flinders and the Leader of the Opposition are any indication, it has not made any progress at all. What we are seeing, as we have all the way through, is simply a moral and political vacuum. We have seen an organisation which Ian Hancock, the academic writing the history of the Liberal Party, said recently lacks a heart, a soul and a mind. That is a succinct summing-up of our opponents.

PARA.TAB: This bill will present a real challenge to the Liberal Party. It has no policy. The Leader of the Opposition has been going around Aboriginal communities, accepting their hospitality, and they have been accepting him as someone who is looking after their interests, only to find that the Liberal Party is now considering pilfering their proprietary right, under the kind of legislation offered by Western Australia.
