So this is a test for moderates in the Liberal Party. Stand up and be counted on an issue of great national and cultural significance, or go down with the right-wing romper stompers who put you asunder at the last election.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Can the minister inform the House of progress on discussions with the Chinese about wool tariffs? What has been the reaction to the government's package of reform on the wool industry? What evidence is there that rural Australia is picking up?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. Indeed, the House should be aware that last week the Chinese, following discussions with Australian officials, made a very important announcement that they would drop the tariff on processed wool into China by five per cent. We consider this to be a very important first step in the revision downwards of tariffs that have made it, to date, uncompetitive for processed wool to be taken into that country.

PARA.TAB: The decision is important because it needs to be understood that it was made against a background of the Chinese government saying that it would not reduce any tariff until such time as it acceded to GATT. We, as a nation, were supporting its accession to GATT. But we were able to change the view from being reliant on accession to GATT to one in which the Chinese government was prepared to look at it in the context of the commercial opportunities between the two countries.

Following representations made by the Prime Minister to the Vice Premier of China in the middle of this year—and more recently when Madam Wu, representing the Chinese government, met with the Minister for Trade and me last month—there was an indication on the Chinese government's part that, in the context of joint ventures, it would be prepared to review the tariff level. Our approach, as a government, was not just to address this issue from the point of view of government to government—of getting the tariff down once China got into GATT. We sought to marshall the forces of the commercial interests and to convince the Chinese that it was not just a tariff problem associated with GATT, but it was in fact an impediment as a cost input miltitating against further expansion of its textile industry. Against that background, we developed with the commercial interests in this country a delegation to go to China. That is what resulted in this very important step.

It is a very good result for this country and, as I said before, it is a first step. But Chargeurs, the company that has invested very heavily in expanded wool processing activity in Wagga, has described it as an excellent result and an important boost for the wool processing industry in this country.

So it is good news for the wool industry. It comes on the back of very good news so far as the price of wool is concerned. We have seen the 10th consecutive week of increase in the price of wool. That comes on the back of the decision of this government—supported, I might add, by the opposition—to give certainty to the industry by announcing a new package of reforms.

I have just returned from overseas where there is very strong confidence in the future of the wool industry. I am working with the growers, the processors and the international trade to ensure that there is effective promotion.

As to the wider rural prospects, I simply draw the attention of the House to the optimistic reports that came from the NFF's conference yesterday, where it sees significant bright spots on the horizon. I believe that there is a significant, strong future for agriculture in this country and we will develop the policies that will help bring that about.

In conclusion, whilst I am on the issue of the NFF conference, I simply remind the House that today that conference also endorsed this government's package on Mabo. It urged the opposition to get behind the package and support it. One can only hope that the opposition heeds that advice.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also direct my question to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware of the recent decision of the Industrial Relations Commission to grant a supplementary payment of $8 per week to workers on minimum award wages? What impact will this have on the economic recovery now under way?

—I was very pleased to see the Industrial Relations Commission agree to an $8 increase in supplementary payments for workers on minimum award rates of pay from 1 December. This is a moderate, affordable wage increase and one which is consistent with economic growth and low inflation.

PARA.TAB: It is worth recording that inflation in this country at the moment is 2.2 per cent. It is there by virtue of the government's anti-inflation policies which include an incomes policy of now nearly 11 years standing and a firm but sympathetic monetary policy which understands that the twin objectives of economic policy are economic growth with the maintenance of low inflation. An $8 a week increase in supplementary payments for those on minimum award rates will be combined with the tax cuts of the day before yesterday of $8 to $10 a week for people on middle incomes.

The rest of the community will also be securing, under the decentralised wage system established by the government, wage increases, which are not of the minimum variety, of minimum award rates of pay so that middle income wage and salary earners will have wage adjustments coming through the decentralised system of enterprise bargaining and wage bargaining as well as an $8 to $10 a week tax cut. So there is an $8 to $10 a week tax cut, as provided for in the election campaign as part of the One Nation statement of tax cuts, and on top of that now is an $8 increase as a supplementary payment for those on minimum award rates.

A core point of the government's industrial relations policy has been to maintain the award system—to leave a safety net underpinning minimum award rates of pay so that we did not see people fall below what are now these statutory minimums. But the opposition in the last election campaign was for going for individual wage contracts, which was basically ripping up the basic award minimums, taking away the safety net and letting wage and salary earners fall through it into relative poverty. This was the opposition's policy until the nation woke up to exactly what it was putting.

I am sure that our British delegates in the gallery will have heard all this before. The fact is that the game is the same in both countries in this respect. That is, there needs to be a fair go for those on minimum incomes. If we do not give them a fair go, they do not have the purchasing power to keep the economy going and, at the same time, the capacity to give those on the middle rungs of the income ranges the chance to get out and bargain, to lift productivity and share that productivity between profits and wages. If that were not happening, we would not have an inflation rate of just over two per cent with very low interest rates, with bill rates under five per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't think the recession had something to do with that?

—When the opposition had a recession, we came out of it with 11 per cent inflation. We have come out of this one with two per cent inflation. In fact, we have come out of it with 1.5 per cent inflation, with interest rates under five per cent. So we are doing something right.

PARA.TAB: Let me conclude on this point: let every Australian working person understand that the government has delivered on its promises in the election campaign. That is, it has agreed to the $8 minimum adjustment to minimal award rates of pay. It has paid, in this very same week, tax cuts of $8 to $10 a week for those on middle incomes—

TALK.START.PARA: —L-a-w.
—I warn the honourable member for Moncrieff.

—so that we have affordable, sustainable rates of pay in this country, sustainably low inflation and a fair tax system which is not lifting the burden of tax on people by the operation of inflation through the tax system. Again, let people take note that after I stood up in the election campaign and said that we believed in a safety net, the award system, minimum rates of pay and sensible adjustments, we have delivered on every single dot point. We have also delivered in respect of taxation. Had we had the Leader of the Opposition as Prime Minister, people would be now going through a massive decrease in incomes.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Tourism. Can the minister inform the House what new tourism statistics show about the level of consumer confidence in Australia's economic recovery?

—I thank the honourable member for Richmond for his continuing interest in the development of the Australian tourism industry. The opposition will be disappointed to acknowledge that Australia is in its seventh consecutive quarter of economic growth, especially given the predictions in the past of double dip recessions which have not come true. A new survey carried out by Access Economics for the Australian Tourism Industry Association paints a very optimistic future for the Australian tourism industry, and for further signs of growing confidence in the Australian economy. This survey indicates that tourism industry operators are expecting not only improved sales and profits but, most importantly of all, stronger employment prospects. That, of course, is good news for young Australians.

PARA.TAB: The reason for this continuing very strong growth in the Australian tourism industry is not only an increasing number of international visitors, but an improvement in domestic tourism activity. For the first eight months of this year we had a 15 per cent increase in the number of international visitors coming to Australia. In addition to that, I am advised that for the June quarter the number of visas issued by Australia's high commissions and embassies is 21 per cent higher than for the same quarter last year.

Given the fact that 10 years ago when this mob opposite left office we had only 950,000 international visitors coming to Australia each year, on these figures I would expect that, for the first time, in 1993 we will break the three million barrier. Three million international visitors will generate more than $8 billion in export earnings, and could create up to 200,000 more jobs than we had 10 years ago when those opposite left office.

The growth has been most spectacular in the Asian region where the Prime Minister and the government have been very keen to enhance Australia's image. From countries such as Korea and Taiwan we have had a 70 per cent increase in the number of international visitors for the first eight months of this year compared with last year. From south-east Asia as a whole we have had more than 40 per cent growth.

It may be of interest to honourable members to know that on the domestic front there is very strong evidence of further growth in consumer confidence, especially when we realise that spending on tourism is considered to be discretionary expenditure by Australians. The figures which have been released today by the Bureau of Tourism Research show that in the June quarter this year we had a 16 per cent increase in travel within Australia, and a 22 per cent increase in business trips—a further sign of a healthier business economy as a result of those seven quarters of consecutive economic growth.

As we look at these tourism figures, we can see that by increasing the number of international visitors we are generating more export earnings. The domestic figures show that increasing numbers of Australians, including business people, are travelling, and that is a further sign of the economic recovery which this government has encouraged.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The failure of administration in the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories as exemplified by the blatant misuse of taxpayers' money for political purposes.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the Auditor-General reported to this parliament in audit report No. 9. The report is entitled Community cultural, recreational and sporting facilities program, a program which has been run out of the office—I say `out of the office' deliberately—of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly). The first responsibility of any minister is to administer the department. As this Auditor-General's report illustrates, there has been a humiliating failure of administration in this department—and by this minister.

PARA.TAB: The suspicion is that up to $30 million of taxpayers' money has been spent on a vote buying exercise by the Australian Labor Party. It was not motivated by public interest or community need, but by self-interest and political need. It was motivated by the desire of this minister and this government to use taxpayers' funds—the funds collected from taxpayers—to buy their way back into office at the 13 March 1993 election. This is not some charge made by the opposition; it is a charge made by the Auditor-General, an independent statutory officer, who has the responsibility to report to this parliament on expenditure by government and the way that proceeds. In the report brought to this parliament yesterday, the Auditor-General:

SPEECH.PARA: .. . . found that the Department's administration. . . was weak:
.insufficient information was sent to the Minister—
.the objectives of the program were unclear
.the procedures for processing applications were poor—
.documentation supporting the . . . process was inadequate
He found there was not enough consultation. He also said:
.projects were not monitored systematically—
.certain administrative procedures left the program open to fraud and the program fraud control plan was out of date—
.there is poor performance information.

It is quite clear from the report by the independent Auditor-General that this program was not administered in any significant way, it was open to fraud, relevant documentation was missing, the objectives were unclear and the minister failed—in dereliction of her duty—to properly administer her department.

PARA.TAB: But there is a darker side, a darker side still than this hopeless administration, this pathetic performance as found by the Auditor-General. There is a darker side that indicates it may not just have been incompetence. It may have been a case of bias as well. The Auditor-General went in to have a look at this program because of allegations by Senator Baume—the then shadow minister for the arts, heritage and sport—in Senate estimates hearings and by the opposition generally, that it had been politically directed. When the Auditor-General went in to see whether or not this could be proven or disproven, he found that the relevant documents—the documents that would disclose the basis on which grants were being made—did not exist.

We have already seen, in relation to question time, that the minister was asked a very simple question. She was asked whether or not she would disclose to the parliament the documentation that had been generated in her office in relation to the applications, the approval of applications and the grants of applications. She was asked whether she would provide to the parliament the information that the Auditor-General said was necessary for this parliament to properly discharge its duties. This minister was unable to come into this parliament and disclose that documentation. I say to the minister, `If, by the end of your reply on this matter of public importance, you have not given an unequivocal commitment to table all of those documents, there will be but one conclusion'. The conclusion will be that she has something to hide because she has done something wrong. If those documents are clear and plain and disclose, as she was maintaining, that this program was administered in the proper way, and if they disclose that this was being done on an open needs basis, there is nothing to hide from. There would be no problem whatsoever in bringing those documents in and reporting to the parliament.

The Auditor-General was prohibited from seeing those particular documents—prohibited from reporting to the people of Australia and this parliament as to whether or not this program had been efficiently administered. So all he could do was go to the results, and I tell honourable members that the results of this particular program are deafening. The Auditor-General said that, in relation to $30 million of approvals in 1992-93, although the Labor Party held only 53 per cent of seats, it got 73 per cent of the grants—53 per cent of the seats but 73 per cent of the grants—and 66 per cent of the value of the money that was approved.

TALK.START.PARA: —This will come home to haunt you.

—The honourable member for Burke would have been in there. He was in a Labor marginal seat; he would have been handing out money as if it were going out of fashion. No wonder he is going red. He had better talk a bit louder than that if he is going to cover up this particular scandal.

PARA.TAB: The average that was given to Labor seats was $257,000. The average, over the whole of Australia, that was approved for grants to coalition seats was $141,000—a difference of $110,000 per electorate. There are only about 100,000 people in each electorate. What gives the absolute lie to the pathetic defence that was mounted by the minister was that she said, `Well, we were giving it out on only a needs basis. We were doing it only on a needs basis. The Labor electorates got more because they were more needy'. But do honourable members know who got the most money of all? It was not the safe Labor seats; the Labor marginal seats just happened to get $326,000 on average.

Do honourable members know what went, on average, to the Liberal marginal seats or the coalition marginal seats? It was $163,000. Think about that—$163,000. What is the difference between $163,000 to coalition marginal seats compared with $326,000 for Labor marginal seats? I will tell honourable members. It is exactly half, to the dollar. This needs based funding component just happened, to the dollar, to give $2 to every Labor marginal for every $1 to every Liberal marginal seat. Is that not an extraordinary coincidence? By the time we got through the needs basis, it just happened to be $2 to $1—exactly to the dollar even when we are talking about hundreds of thousands of dollars.

This was not allocated on the basis of deprivation. It was allocated for one base political reason: the government decided to use the taxpayers of Australia to buy itself back into office. These results speak volumes. When the Auditor-General went into how the program was actually administered, do honourable members know what he found? He found that it was not the department that was actually going through the applications and making the decisions but the minister's office. The department was not making the recommendations. All of this was being boxed up in the minister's office. Here is a finding that the Auditor-General actually made. In section 2.19 he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that in the latest round of approvals the Minister's office asked for details of the electorates in which the applications were located but was not prepared to put its request in writing when asked to do so by the Department, willy nilly can only lead to speculation about the basis for the selection process.

I will tell honourable members what the speculation is. The speculation is that the minister had this little cabal inside her office that had taken over the process that was asking about electorates. As the shadow minister for sport actually tabled some minutes, it was writing out to members asking them about proposals in their electorates, and classifying the electorates up the top in the case of the safe Labor seat of the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis). So one got this invitation to come in on the basis of the categorisation of one's electoral standing.

PARA.TAB: The other thing is to see what role the department took in this actual process. The department had only one thing to do. When the application came in the department put the application into one of three categories and then passed it over to the minister's office for approval. Category 1 was those projects which were well documented with a clearly demonstrated need; category 2 was those projects with minor deficiencies in information with a community need; and category 3 was projects lacking in relevant information for which community need was not adequately demonstrated. So if the application was well documented and there was a community need, it was category 1. If there was a community need but a minor deficiency, it was category 2. If it was lacking in relevant information, it was category 3.

Those applications that lacked information in category 3 had a higher success rate than those in category 1, which were projects properly and well documented with a clearly demonstrated community need. Applications that were actually properly documented and had a community need had a nine per cent chance of success. Category 3 applications, which lacked relevant information and did not show community need, had a 13 per cent chance. One message came out of this: if people want to get something out of the minister's office, they should not document it; they have a much better chance if they have not documented it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just send them the cover.

—As the Leader of the Opposition says, I suppose the minister's defence will be that she endorsed only the cover of the application rather than the contents. We have seen all this sort of thing before. This is not new when it comes to this minister. This is a bit like the letter from the New South Wales minister that suddenly did not appear but happened to appear. It is like the time the then Prime Minister—remember Mr Hawke—was accused of crass politics over new federalism and the tape that allegedly cleared the minister could not be provided and nor could the transcript. If people actually wanted to get into this scheme, they did better if they did not document it properly and they could not show that there was an adequate community need. I will tell honourable members why. This was not being distributed on the basis of community need at all. This program was all about buying votes for Labor candidates with taxpayers' money so that Labor candidates could get elected to control the disbursement of funds, to disburse them, to get elected, to control the disbursement of funds, to disburse them, to get elected, to control the disbursement of funds.

PARA.TAB: Under the One Nation program this particular program actually had a boost of about $18.75 million as a job creation scheme. For whom was it a job creation scheme? Labor candidates in marginal electorates! That is where the jobs were coming from out of this particular scheme. No jobs were being directed on a needs basis. Jobs were being geographically distributed to ensure that public money could be used for the benefit of candidates in marginal seats.

When the minister replies she should not try to attack the Auditor-General. That is the trick of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). Whenever he gets an adverse report by the Auditor-General, his trick is to stand up and attack the Auditor-General. We know the government's view on the Auditor-General. The government is so intent on ripping money out under that Centenary House lease deal that it is prepared to let the functions of the Auditor-General wind down to enrich the Labor Party. However, it should not attack the Auditor-General.

This was a case where there was ministerial incompetence, administrative failure, money gleefully ripped-off on geographical and political grounds and where the relevant documentation that exists in the minister's office which, it is said, justifies these particular grants cannot be released. The people of Australia have every right to ask themselves what this minister has to hide. Why is it that this minister cannot come clean with the public? Why is ministerial accountability missing?

The Auditor-General said that questions concerning the degree to which ministers are accountable were the subject of much public debate. Whatever the outer limits may be, it is generally accepted in modern government that ministers are responsible for matters in which they have a personal involvement or where they fail to correct systemic failure within their portfolio of which they were aware.

The minister failed to correct systemic failure. In fact, the minister implemented systemic failure to ensure that this was decided in her office, that it was distributed on grounds that advantaged her politically, to lock out the people who really did need these things and to make sure it was done for her self-interest rather than the public interest. The minister has been fingered by the Auditor-General and she stands condemned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs KELLY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —This Auditor-General's report is a report on a program which, clearly, serves a great need in this community, and one has to understand that when reading this report. Clearly, the program distribution is based on identified need.

PARA.TAB: The accusations made by the shadow minister for finance, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), are not correct and are not substantiated by the Auditor-General. The Auditor-General quite clearly says that his analysis does not demonstrate one way or the other that projects are approved on party political grounds.

I agree with many of the recommendations in the report, which do need to be taken into consideration if and when we have a new program. I take those recommendations very seriously. When honourable members read this document they will see an attachment outlining the response of my department giving a commitment to take on board the considerations.

However, it should be remembered when looking at this issue of the management of this program that, currently, 99 per cent of the costs of this program go straight to the community. One per cent of total funding goes on administration. Looking at the implementation of these recommendations, it has to be remembered that if more money is put into the administration of this program then there is less money to go to the communities in need. That has to be remembered when looking at any future planning of this program, if indeed a decision is made to continue this program.

The main thing that is forgotten in this report is the focus of need in the community. Can anyone in this parliament really say that the Australian community did not need that sports facilities program? Can anyone really say that? Thousands of communities across this nation have benefited from this program. It is a program where there was a clearly identified need. When that is linked with the guidelines and the selection criteria, which everyone gets when applying for a grant, it can be seen that priority will be given to the needs of residents in the new suburban areas. Many of those areas are often in Labor seats. With residents in inner urban areas, there are some Labor seats again. Youth in the community, communities in rural areas, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities, communities with high unemployment—unfortunately some of them are Labor seats as well—and communities with large migrant populations, these factors are taken into consideration with the distribution of funds.

One of the recommendations of the Auditor-General that I do have some problem with is that the Auditor-General recommends that we do not have small grants. I think that would be a problem because many small grants—grants of $10,000 or $15,000—through this program have been incredibly valuable. It is important that we do not disregard the value of those programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the documents.
—Why won't you mention the documents?

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The honourable member for Bennelong and the honourable member for Mayo!

TALK.START.PARA: —The Auditor-General has not alleged political bias. Clearly, the criteria have been set out in every application. Regional areas, isolated communities, high ethnic areas and high Aboriginal areas would obviously have to be considered as priorities for funding. The shadow minister referred to the issue of categories. As honourable members will be aware from a reading of the Auditor-General's report, of the applications that we receive, the department—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The interjections from the front bench on my left might cease. This matter of public importance has been put forward by the opposition. It would be helpful for proper discussion if the minister were to be heard in silence.
—It would help if she addressed the documents.
—Order! The honourable member for Bennelong will not test my patience.

—I would like to address the specific process. The applications go to those in the Australian community who feel they are in need of community facilities. The applications then come to my department and it eliminates the ones that do not fit in with the guidelines and the selection criteria. The three categories that were referred to in the Auditor-General's report refer to those applications which are eligible. When funding is allocated from any of those three categories, they are all eligible. In the last round, 55 per cent of category one applications were funded, 20 per cent of category two, and 15 per cent of category three. Therefore, if an application were submitted which fitted into category one, it would have a much better chance of being successful than if it were in category two or category three. Often the application may have been very good in category three but there may have been some slight technical problem with it. In discussion with the group, we could come up with a solution to the problem.

—As the honourable member pointed out, many applications were from migrant groups. I think the Auditor-General makes a relevant point about the application forms because they may well have been unduly complex for some groups.

PARA.TAB: It is very important that, once we receive applications and they are put in their various categories, I then consult with various groups—sometimes local councils, sometimes members of parliament. I think it is appalling for honourable members to say that they should have no role in this process. They are horrified that there should be any consideration of any link between the application and an electorate. I would have thought it was quite reasonable to be able to inform members of parliament which electorate these grants go to.

Clearly, once we get rid of the smokescreen, once we get rid of all the allegations that are not substantiated by this report, we will see what this is really about. This is really about the opposition saying it does not approve of this program. It wants to abolish this program. It ought to tell every one of those thousands of groups in the community that it does not support this program, that it does not support identifying community needs and that it does not support fulfilling those needs throughout the community.

I would like now to refer specifically to the report. I would like to go through the case studies that are specifically referred to in the report. Rather than just go through all the superficial accusations made by the shadow minister, the honourable member for Higgins, I would like to go through the specific cases because, after all, this is a program directed at specific cases where there is a need in the community.

The report refers to what it says are a number of anomalies. It refers to eight projects which it believes were approved outside guidelines. In a couple of these cases the points raised highlight potential inadequacies in the department's follow-up procedure, and of course these will be rectified in the future. However, after a detailed look, it is difficult to see how these cases can be construed as anomalies.

Let us take the one which is called `Payment in excess of program limit'. That in fact refers to a project in Western Australia called Altone Park. The report says that the amount of money allocated exceeded the program guidelines. What is clear is that in round three it received $100,000 and in round four it received an additional amount of $250,000. It did not go over the limit. The same thing goes for Hindmarsh Stadium. As in the first case, that project received a grant of $100,000 in round three and $250,000 in round four.

The next case study is headed `Evidence in support of grant payment'. That case refers to the Hunter Caravan Project. According to the Auditor-General's report, insufficient evidence was provided in support of payment. The report recommends improved procedure for payment of grants, and these recommendations of course will be accepted for future programs.
One of the real classics is the issue of Westfield High School, which is a school in the western suburbs of Sydney. It applied for a grant of $50,000—

TALK.START.PARA: —Get back to the report.

—This is specifically on the report. A $50,000 grant was provided to assist in the construction of a sports medicine facility. The audit office says that this was simply a substitute for state funding. The reality is that without that money that project would not have gone ahead and that school would not have become the centre for sports in the western suburbs of Sydney. That $50,000 has been a catalyst for producing a school of incredibly high quality in relation to sports education, and that $50,000 has gone into producing facilities not just in one electorate but for the whole region.

PARA.TAB: That goes to the heart of this issue. Many of those projects are not confined to one electorate or another; they service a whole region and service a need for a whole region. One can go through all the other examples. The opposition says that, in terms of commercial facilities, we should not have funded an area like the St George rugby league Jubilee Oval. Without those funds, would that oval have been completed? The answer is probably no. The same goes for many other examples. So the needs of the community are at the heart of this matter.

I conclude my contribution to this discussion by referring to some of the positive aspects remembering, first of all, that in each of those examples referred to—specific examples of so-called anomalies—one can demonstrate that there were not anomalies. In the Auditor-General's report specific recommendations were made where we can obviously improve some of the administration, and we will do that in future grants. But at no stage in this report does the Auditor-General acknowledge the real needs of the communities in Australia. That is what those opposite lose sight of in this debate. It is about time we put a focus on the demands of members of the Australian community, no matter where they live and no matter what electorate they live in. That is the point of this matter. To make my point, I mention a small grant—$30,000 in relation to the Armadale Bowling Club in Victoria which, I understand, is a Liberal party seat. I quote from a letter that I have just received:

SPEECH.PARA: We will now be able to significantly increase our bowling activities to the enjoyment of many who cannot now indulge in any other recreational pursuit.
That message of the Armadale Bowling Club will be repeated throughout this nation. Every member of this House should be congratulating the government for this program, not criticising it.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! Before calling the honourable member for Ballarat, I remind honourable members that all interjections are out of order. The chair shows some leniency because this is a chamber of robust debate, but honourable members should not ignore the fact that expressions that would otherwise be unparliamentary should not be introduced in debate by way of interjection and they should show such care.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was unparliamentary?
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo wants me to be precise. I ask him to withdraw the expressions `lie' and `corrupt' that he directed towards the minister during the debate.
—Yes.
—A nod is as good as a wink is it? Nod, nod; wink, wink.

—Order! The parliamentary secretary has also not assisted the chair by her continuous interjections. She might witness the rest of this matter of public importance in silence. I call the honourable member for Ballarat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson Mr M.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) might take a Bex and have a good lie down. Guess what she has not done? She has not read the report. That is right; she has not even read the report. Half of the people who are making noise on the other side have not read the report.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. The honourable member for Ballarat has just made a sexist aspersion against the honourable member for Prospect by saying that she should take a Bex and have a good lie down—something that I find offensive. I ask for it to be withdrawn.
—Order! The honourable member for Gilmore will resume his seat. I call the honourable member for Ballarat.
—The honourable member for Gilmore should take a Bex and have a good lie down. Is he happy now?
—Order! The honourable member for Ballarat will get to the subject of the matter of public importance.
—Guess what this report says on page xiii? It states:

SPEECH.PARA: What the program is trying to achieve —
wait for it—
is not entirely clear.

We know what it is trying to achieve and we know what it has achieved: it has put a lot of money into marginal seats that the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) and her government were going to use for their own re-election purposes. The key points of the report are as follows:

The ANAO noted some anomalies in the approval of grants (worth $29.5m in 1992-93) by the Minister but was unable to resolve them because the reasons for decisions were not adequately documented. For the same reason claims that decisions on the allocation of grants were politically motivated could not be put to rest.
But it gets better.It continues:
ANAO considers that it is in the interest of a Minister—
this minister—
to document the reasons for individual decisions to allay such allegations and to provide accountability for decisions.

The minister has been asked on at least half a dozen occasions to provide the information. The ANAO has said that she should provide it. She refuses to do so, and the only inference that can be drawn is that what we have been saying—what the Auditor-General has alluded to—is absolutely correct and this has been done for no other reason than for straight political purposes.Then the minister was asked to explain her actions. Wait for this. The report states:
The Government also said that the selection decisions were made personally by the Minister in order to protect public servants from criticism from unsuccessful applicants.
That is very magnanimous. But listen to this. The report goes on:
Once the successful applicants are selected the Minister's office advises the Department. The Department then prepares a formal submission to the Minister together with letters to all applicants.
Wait for it—it continues:
The Minister signs those to the successful applicants . . .

And guess who signs the unsuccessful ones? It is the department she is trying to protect. It just goes on and on. This is an absolutely phoney program. Guess what every major sporting organisation in this country has said to me in my travels around Australia? They have said, `This program is no more than a political whitewash for the ALP'. Do honourable members opposite know who is saying that? It is their own supporters.

PARA.TAB: This whole thing has come purely from the minister's office. It is not a departmental decision making process; it has come from the minister for the minister for the government—no more, no less. It is probably the most obscene allocation of taxpayers' funds that we have seen in this country for a long time. I have a fax from the minister, then the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, addressed to the `Hon. R. Willis'. Guess what it says? It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Could you please look at the attached and pass on your comments by Friday afternoon.

Under that there is the word `Confidential'. Guess what it has after that? It has a list of the projects that have come from the electorate of the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) for him to comment on personally. At the top of the page it has `Gellibrand', then it has `Ralph Willis', then it has `ALP', and then it has the words `Safe Labor'.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Prospect throws herself emotionally into the air. How many of my colleagues got a fax from the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories asking for a comment about the projects in their electorates? I ask them to put their hands up. Not one of my colleagues; not one single person.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Cleary?

—I do not know; did the honourable member for Wills get one? No, not even Phil got one—not even the de facto Labor Party member got one. This is just a further example of the fact that it was a great political fraud, a great political con. This whole program, and the allocation of it, smells. It is a political stench that makes the environmental kit look like kids's stuff. This minister has gone too far this time. I am absolutely amazed that the honourable member for Prospect can sit there and blatantly laugh about the expenditure—
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I was not blatantly laughing at the expenditure; I was laughing at the clownish behaviour of the speaker on his feet.
—The honourable member will resume her seat.

—The honourable member for Prospect, in the period of the worst recession in this country since 1930, with one million unemployed, can laugh about the fact that $30 million has been used by a political party for its re-election. If the honourable member thinks that is funny, then she, quite frankly, should resign.

PARA.TAB: The minister was talking about category 3 which seemed to have an extraordinary amount of ministerial influence in it. But these were the category 3s that did not have a lot going for them, according to the department. Perhaps they had one thing written beside them: marginal Labor seat. That is why category 3 got such a big push from this minister. This can be very easily resolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —You give your money back.

—That is the sort of ignorance that we see from those opposite. If they look at the figures, in my electorate I did not get the amount that the marginal Labor seats got. The honourable member for Page should have a look at his figures before he makes ignorant comments like that. To show how silly the government is, the money has also gone into coalition seats that the government thought it could win. That makes it smell even more. That is what makes it all so terribly sinister.

PARA.TAB: The minister should comply with the request of the Auditor-General. Then we will be happy and he will be happy. I am afraid that if she does not do so, then she very seriously needs to look at her position and whether she can, in all honesty, continue to remain on that front bench.

TALKER.NAME: Mr O'KEEFE
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) was wrong in one statement she made in her presentation. She said that everybody recognised how worth while and important this program is. The minister was wrong because in the opposition's Fightback package the money for this program was ruled out—scrubbed. One thousand communities around Australia who received, in general, small grants, but grants which produced multiplier effects, knew damn well that they were not going to get the money under the opposition's programs and policies. The opposition does not like the program even though everybody else in Australia does. That is why it is carrying on like this today.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the program. Firstly, it was a worthwhile program. The social significance was dramatic with those 1,000 jobs in those 1,000 communities where funds were made available. Jobs were created by works programs going on the ground straightaway in exactly the way that we required to get the economy moving. I commend the minister for making this happen in a hurry.

Secondly, how can those opposite say in this parliament that badly needed sports, recreation, health and exercise facilities in marginal seats or non-marginal seats on either side of this House were not required in the Australian community? Of course they were required. I will come to some of the op-position's people and how embarrassed they are going to be about this in a minute. The minister has a sheaf of letters from a number of communities, councils and groups saying, `Thanks very much'. So let us get to the point.

We are not really on about the program; we are on about the distribution of the funds. Let us go to a serious analysis of this question of the distribution of the funds. The claim being made is that Labor marginal seats got more money. So what? Let us have a look at it. We are the government and, of course, we have more marginal seats than the opposition. Big deal! If the opposition had been the government it would have had more marginal seats. More importantly, where are they? Go to the western suburbs of Sydney, go to the outskirts of Melbourne, go to the rural and provincial areas where we have the marginal seats, and that is where we will find that the need exists. It is not like Toorak and it is not like North Shore where people have lovely, indoor, heated swimming pools and all the facilities. The need is in the seats where residential areas are growing quickly. Young families cannot afford to pay the rates that councils need to produce these facilities. They are the communities that need this seed funding, and they are the funds that came through this program.

The minister touched briefly on the example of Westfield High School in the western suburbs of Sydney. There was a $2 million development for which the federal government's grant was a grand $50,000. The Auditor-General somehow thinks that there is something wrong with getting a project going with a grant of $50,000. The project is producing jobs and benefits in the community. Most interestingly, New South Wales Premier Fahey and his education minister, Mrs Chadwick, the opposition's colleagues, are roaming around the west of Sydney claiming credit for the project and saying what a wonderful project it is in the west of Sydney. Who produced it? The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories.

Let us go to the claim that Liberal marginal seats were not funded. I was disappointed to learn at question time today how ineffective I am as a local member in central Victoria. In my seat on the north-western outskirts of Melbourne I am surrounded by three marginal Liberal seats. Those three marginal Liberal seats got nearly three times the funds that I got in my electorate. Surprise, surprise! One of those seats was that of the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson). I want to touch on the reason why there may not have been more funds in Liberal seats. Let us look at what happened in Ballarat. It might be something to do with the fact that those opposite opposed our program and did not even support their own community groups' applications.

TALK.START.PARA: —You be very careful.
—Yes, I will be very careful. The honourable member knows very well that in Ballarat those involved could not sort out between themselves which one would be the swimming pool project.
—Have you seen my submission to the minister?

—I have seen the submissions. When the submissions came to the minister's office from the honourable member's community, the honourable member did not know which one to support. It was not until the minister took the responsibility and knocked heads together that the honourable member then started writing his letters.

PARA.TAB: Let me give another example. In the very safe Liberal seat of Corangamite there is a lot of yardage for the Labor Party in funding a program in the downtown suburb of Colac. I apologise to the honourable member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) for calling Colac a suburb. Colac is a lovely town and he came from there originally. In Colac members of the community decided that they wanted to apply for funding for the swimming pool project. There was a strong community base of support. They went to the Liberal member and asked for support for that project. But he said he felt the program was a waste of time and he was opposed to it. He was not even prepared to write a letter of support to the minister about that program.

The local Labor Party branch—surprise, surprise!—then made representations to us and put that program into the community psyche. If those opposite are going to make claims that we are ignoring their requests, because of political bias, they should check the performance of their own members in representing their constituents.

There was also an implication that with the small claims—the category 3 projects—the minister in some way or other was imposing her own priorities, or those of other people, on the department. I will give an example from my territory—not my electorate but the township where I live. I saw the recommendations from the department concerning the area, about which I have local knowledge. I made representations to the minister's office because I felt that the department's recommendations on a couple of those grants were out of kilter with the needs of the community. As a result, the minister was prepared to seek more information.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why weren't we given the same opportunity? You have just put yourself right in.

—I am not putting myself in. I commend the minister for being prepared to listen and make judgments about what is important at the local level. Let us look at what happened in the safe National Party seat of Murray. There was a project concerning the Kyabram Plaza Theatre. When people in Australia visit Kyabram and look at that project they will say wow. It was not recommended in representations from the other side. The recommendation was to give the whole grant to the Echuca Council for a swimming pool.

PARA.TAB: I took the view that at least a small amount of money ought to be given to Kyabram. I live in the region and I know what is going on there. I made recommendations to the minister's office—and she was prepared to listen. I hope that one day the minister will visit it and see what those federal funds produced.

This is not just a `worthwhile program'. For very few dollars—in my view—it is one of the best the federal government operates. It produces tremendous multiplier effects by creating jobs and facilities that are badly needed in some areas, and it is a program in which the minister has been prepared to take local advice over centralised bureaucratic advice.

When honourable members opposite go through the Auditor-General's report, they will find that he has made a heap of mistakes. They have rushed in and attempted to seize on them without checking whether their own people have made representations on behalf of their constituency. I do not think that this matter of public importance is important at all. (Time expired)

DEBATE.TITLE: CRIMES (SEARCH WARRANTS AND POWERS OF ARREST) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Mr Kerr, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr The Hon D.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the bill is to amend the Crimes Act 1914 to implement the recommendations of the Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law to make much needed reforms to the law relating to search, arrest and related matters for the investigation of most Commonwealth offences. These areas of the law have been the subject of careful examination by the Law Reform Commission in its report Criminal investigation and more recently by the Review of the Commonwealth Criminal Law established by Mr Bowen as Attorney-General and chaired by the Rt Hon. Sir Harry Gibbs GCMG, AC, KBE. The bill closely follows the recommendations made by the Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law in its fourth and fifth interim reports.

PARA.TAB: The review committee made recommendations to modernise Commonwealth law to ensure that technological advances are taken into account by these laws, as is the increased awareness of the need for parliament to state clearly the balance considered appropriate between the community interests in effective law enforcement and the maintenance of individual rights and freedoms. To date, laws

SPEECH.PARA: in this area have been contained in numerous Commonwealth statutes, state and territory laws applied by the Judiciary Act, police instructions or general orders and case law. This has lead to a considerable degree of uncertainty and inaccessibility of the law. Indeed, recent public concerns about the Victorian government's Crimes Amendment Bill highlight the need for this parliament to make specific provision for laws relating to search, arrest and related matters in the investigation of Commonwealth offences. As the law currently stands, without this legislation, Commonwealth investigators are required to use state powers.

PARA.TAB: All these amendments will not initially supplant all other Commonwealth laws in this area as was envisaged by the review committee; those other laws are being carefully examined and brought into line with the provisions proposed in the bill. It is intended to ensure that other officers, particularly those not subject to the training, discipline and accountability of members of a police force, have no greater powers than police. Until that review is completed, those laws which relate to the investigation of specific offences against Commonwealth law such as customs, quarantine and fisheries offences will continue to operate for police and inspectors appointed under those acts.

The bill provides for a comprehensive scheme for obtaining and executing search warrants, including telephone warrants, stopping and searching conveyances, arrest and related matters such as personal searches, taking and destroying fingerprints, and holding identification parades and other identification procedures. It sets out the powers and obligations of police when carrying out any of these procedures and spells out the many safeguards to protect the rights of individuals.

I now mention some important features of the bill. The bill precludes the issue by lay justices of warrants for search or arrest in relation to Commonwealth offences. Only magistrates and justices of the peace or other persons employed in a court who are authorised to issue search warrants and arrest warrants, as the case may be, will be able to issue such warrants. Further, the bill recognises three different types of search to which a person can be subjected and lays down clear criteria and procedures for their conduct. Practical difficulties which might otherwise flow from the removal of the power of lay justices to issue warrants are to be met by the introduction of telephone warrants. Easy access to magistrates or court employed justices of the peace is assured by the ability to use telephone, facsimile or other electronic means. The bill creates a number of new offences in relation to applications for search warrants made by telephone and other electronic means. There is also a general offence, applicable to all warrants, of making a false statement in an application for a warrant.

The bill prescribes in considerable detail the procedures which a police officer must follow to obtain a search warrant. The intended scope of the warrant must now be clear on its face. For example, if it is contemplated that a warrant obtained to search premises also authorises the search of persons at those premises, the warrant must clearly state this. Furthermore, to prevent the unnecessary execution of warrants on homes at night, the hours during which the warrant may be executed must be specified in the warrant.

If a police officer applying for a warrant suspects that, in executing the warrant, it will be necessary to use firearms, the issuing officer must be told this and the reasons for this suspicion so that he or she can take this into account in deciding whether to issue the warrant. This is particularly directed to situations where, given the nature of the offence and the character of the suspects, it is more likely than not that violence will occur and it is anticipated that special weapons squads will be used. It is not, of course, intended to preclude the use of firearms where this is necessary in the circumstances as they develop when the warrant is being executed.

The bill requires that a copy of the warrant be made available to the occupier of the premises or to the person to be searched. The force used in the execution of the warrant cannot exceed that which is both necessary and reasonable. Search warrants will authorise the seizing of evidence of the offence to which the warrant relates as well as evidence of any other indictable offence. A warrant to search premises may, at the discretion of the issuing officer, also authorise the search of people at, or near, the premises when the warrant is executed who are suspected of being in possession of evidence or dangerous items. Any person searched must be shown a copy of the warrant.

The bill puts beyond doubt the right of police to be assisted by non-police experts. This will be particularly useful when the execution of the warrant involves operating computer equipment to locate evidence of an offence. The bill permits the operation of equipment so that any incriminating evidence may be secured and retrieved but ensures that appropriate care is exercised to minimise damage to equipment. However, if damage is caused as a result of insufficient care in its operation, compensation may be payable to the owner of the equipment.

The bill preserves the law relating to legal professional privilege. The current guidelines developed between the Australian Federal Police and the legal profession in relation to seizure of documents from solicitors' offices will continue to apply.

The bill classifies personal searches as `ordinary', `frisk' and `strip' searches. A search warrant issued in relation to a person may only authorise a `frisk' or `ordinary' search. Procedures for any form of personal search, either under warrant or conducted after arrest, are strictly circumscribed to ensure both the effectiveness of the search and the maintenance of the privacy and dignity of the person searched. Strip searches may only be conducted after an arrest if authorised by a police officer of the rank of superintendent or higher.

Generally, searches must be conducted by a person of the same sex as the person being searched. Strip searches cannot be conducted in the presence of any person of the opposite sex except where a medical practitioner of the same sex is not available or where the other person is a parent, guardian or personal representative and the person being searched does not object. The existing power of police to stop and search vehicles in emergency situations contained in sections 10A and 10B of the Crimes Act, which were also based on the recommendations of the review committee, will be re-enacted.

The bill introduces into Commonwealth criminal law a general offence of failure of a person to give his or her name or address to a police officer who has reason to believe that the person is able to provide information about a Commonwealth offence. Such an offence exists in many specific enactments, but there has been no general provision such as exists in many other jurisdictions. The bill gives effect to the review committee in recommendations to repeal sections 8 and 8A and to replace them with more detailed and precise provisions about when arrest without warrant is permissible.

The power of arrest without warrant by members of the public—that is, citizens arrest—is limited by the bill to suspected indictable offences in specified circumstances. Although the power to apply for, and issue, warrants for the arrest of persons for Commonwealth offences continues to derive from state law under section 68 of the Judiciary Act, the bill imposes a number of additional procedural requirements.

The bill provides for a scheme for the taking of identification material, including finger, hand and foot prints, voice recordings and handwriting samples, from a person in lawful custody for an offence. A police officer of the rank of sergeant or higher may take identification material if the person gives written consent or if that police officer believes on reasonable grounds that the taking of material is necessary to establish the identity of the person, to identify the person as having committed the offence or to provide evidence of an offence. There are limits on the retention of the material.

The bill expressly preserves other laws, including state and territory laws applied to Commonwealth offences, by virtue of section 68 of the Judiciary Act, relating to the taking of forensic samples. Although this is a very necessary bridging provision to ensure that Commonwealth investigators have continuing access to law enforcement powers, the Commonwealth has reservations about some aspects of the Victorian Crimes Amendment Bill. Accordingly, I foreshadow that I will be bringing before the parliament early next year a proposal relating to the taking of forensic samples as they relate to the investigation of Commonwealth offences. The bill also regulates the holding of identification parades and the carrying out of other identification procedures. It provides for the return of items seized, whether under warrant or not.

The bill is designed to make public the powers of police and the rights of individuals in the important areas of police investigation with which it deals. In the past, many of the areas covered have been dealt with in police instructions or general orders, which are not generally available to the public. This is incompatible with modern concepts of open administration and access to justice. I believe the bill makes a significant advance in clarifying the powers of police and the rights of individuals in these important areas of police investigation. I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill. I commend the bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mrs Sullivan) adjourned.
Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr The Hon D.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to complete the process of bringing Australia's maritime zones into line with those to which Australia is entitled under international law, as reflected in the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. The bill makes changes to existing law in four principal areas. These are the establishment of rights in an exclusive economic zone, adoption of a revised definition of the continental shelf, assertion of rights in a contiguous zone and adoption of new international legal provisions for the drawing of territorial sea baselines.

PARA.TAB: The principal legislation to be amended is the Seas and Submerged Lands Act 1973. The bill amends, in a consequential way, a number of other pieces of legislation. At present the Seas and Submerged Lands Act refers to the 1958 Geneva conventions on territorial sea and continental shelf. References to those conventions are no longer appropriate. In 1982 a new United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea was adopted and signed by Australia. Australia has not yet ratified the convention. That convention, however, now has 59 ratifications and is likely to enter into force in the near future—it needs 60 ratifications to do so. It is, apart from the provisions relating to mining of the deep seabed, generally accepted as reflective of international law. The government considers that in relation to maritime zones the convention should govern Australian practice.

At present, consultations are taking place under the auspices of the Secretary-General of the United Nations with a view to overcoming some of the difficulties that have arisen under the convention in relation to the provisions dealing with deep seabed mining. If these consultations are successful, Australia and other developed states will be in a position to give serious consideration to ratifying the convention and hence ensuring that it is universally accepted as the law on the subject. It is therefore appropriate, at this time, for Australia to amend its domestic law to bring its practice in relation to maritime zones into conformity with that provided for in the 1982 convention. As I indicated earlier, Australia considers the maritime zone aspects of the convention to be reflective of customary international law.

Australia has, over the years, gradually asserted its various maritime entitlements under international law. Thus, in 1983 certain territorial sea baselines were proclaimed and in 1990 a 12-nautical mile territorial sea was established in place of the previous three-nautical mile territorial sea. As long ago as 1979 Australia established a 200-nautical mile fishing zone. The current bill will complete the process of bringing Australia's maritime zones up to date. It replaces operative provisions in Commonwealth legislation which refer to the 1958 conventions with references to the 1982 convention.

The bill makes clear that Australia asserts the full rights to which it is entitled under international law in a 200-nautical mile exclusive economic zone. As stated in the preamble to the bill, the rights that Australia has in such a zone include not just sovereign rights over both living and non-living resources but also jurisdiction as provided for in international law in relation to the establishment and use of artificial islands, installations and structures, marine scientific research and protection and preservation of the marine environment. The sovereign rights and the jurisdiction which a coastal state possesses in its exclusive economic zone in regard to these matters are set out in detail in the 1982 law of the sea convention, the relevant parts of which form a schedule to the bill. It will be for future legislation to deal expressly with matters such as pollution control in the exclusive economic zone.

The bill also adopts the definition of the continental shelf in the 1982 convention. The 1958 convention defines the outer limit of the continental shelf in terms of a depth of 200 metres or beyond that to a depth capable of exploitation. This open-ended definition has proved unsatisfactory and customary international law has recognised that the limit of the continental shelf is the edge of the continental margin and that it does not include the deep seabed. The 1982 convention contains in article 76 a precise definition of the continental shelf. This is a minimum 200 nautical miles regardless of the physical configuration of the shelf. Beyond that distance, where the configuration of the continental shelf allows, however, the limit may extend to a distance not exceeding 350 nautical miles from the baseline or 100 nautical miles from the 2,500-metre isobath. This limit is calculated either by reference to the depth of sediments or the distance from the foot of the continental slope, defined by gradient.

Adoption of the 1982 definition will enable Australia to claim a larger total area of continental shelf than under the 1958 convention. The gains made by adopting the new definition outweigh any potential minor losses and will bring Australian legislation into conformity with internationally accepted principles.

The bill, also for the first time in Commonwealth legislation, deals expressly with a contiguous zone. This zone extends from the limit of the territorial sea to a distance no greater than 24 nautical miles from the territorial sea baselines. It is a zone in which a coastal state can exercise rights of control to prevent infringement of customs, fiscal, immigration or sanitary laws and to punish infringement of the above laws committed within its territory or territorial sea. It is envisaged that specific legislation such as the customs or quarantine legislation will in due course be amended to assert more fully the rights to which Australia is entitled in such a zone.

The bill amends in a consequential way a number of acts as set out in schedule l. These amendments mostly relate to the definition of `continental shelf' in those pieces of legislation so as to remove references to the 1958 convention. One amendment of particular note is the alteration of the adjacent area boundary under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act in relation to Tasmania and Western Australia. This will ensure that the operation of that act extends to all the areas of continental shelf which Australia is entitled to claim under the 1982 convention definition. The existing adjacent area `picture frames', which are used in certain offshore area legislation, do not extend far enough in those two areas. The relevant parts of the 1982 convention are set out in schedule 2 to the bill and will form part of the revised Seas and Submerged Lands Act.

The passage of this legislation reflects the need for Australia with its significant interests as both a coastal and maritime state to position itself to take advantage of developments in the law of the sea. Australia's action in this regard will promote further consolidation of coastal and maritime state rights and obligations as set out in the 1982 convention.

I mention that the bill does not affect the offshore constitutional settlement. The states and Northern Territory are consulted in relation to maritime issues and I expect this to continue.The bill will have no direct financial impact. I present the explanatory memorandum for the bill. I commend the bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mrs Sullivan) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 28 October.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr The Hon D.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill is a portfolio bill which will make minor amendments to the Commonwealth's anti-discrimination legislation, the Privacy Act 1988 and the High Court of Australia Act 1979. I will only outline the significant parts of this bill, as a number of the amendments it contains are merely technical or made as a result of other legislative amendments.

PARA.TAB: Last year, amendments were made to the Racial Discrimination Act 1975, the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 and the Disability Discrimination Act 1992 to simplify and streamline the procedure for enforcing determinations of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in the Federal Court. Briefly, that procedure provides that the determination, on being registered in the Federal Court, becomes enforceable as an order of the court after 28 days, unless the respondent to the determination applies for review of the determination within this period. I am concerned that this strict 28-day time limit may cause injustice in some circumstances, so I have introduced amendments to allow the Federal Court to review a determination outside this 28-day time limit in exceptional circumstances. The bill will make a number of amendments to the Privacy Act.

The procedures for making a representative complaint and for enforcing determinations under the Privacy Act will be replaced by new provisions modelled on last year's amendments to the Disability Discrimination Act, the Racial Discrimination Act and Sex Discrimination Act. In addition, the amendments I have just outlined to allow a respondent to seek the leave of the court to have a determination reviewed outside the usual 28-day period will be included in the Privacy Act.

The bill will also clarify that compensation awarded by the Privacy Commissioner to a complainant as part of a determination can include compensation for loss or damage suffered by way of injury to feelings or humiliation. This will bring the Privacy Act provisions into line with the position under the Crimes Act 1914—in relation to spent convictions—and the Disability Discrimination Act, the Racial Discrimination Act and the Sex Discrimination Act. These amendments will ensure greater consistency in the legislation administered by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

The bill will amend the rules under the Privacy Act governing disclosures of credit information by credit providers to state and territory government authorities administering schemes which assist low income earners to obtain mortgage credit. It was brought to the government's notice that the Privacy Act, as it is currently structured, does not sufficiently cater to the information needs of a number of states that operate, and effectively underwrite, mortgage assistance schemes. The amendment will resolve the information needs of the governments without unreasonably infringing the privacy of individual borrowers.

I am introducing an amendment which will delay the commencement date of the superannuation amendments which were inserted in the Sex Discrimination Act in 1991. These provisions were to commence in June this year in order to give superannuation funds time to develop options to allow existing members to transfer to non-discriminatory schemes. The guidelines to be formulated by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission to assist funds to develop non-discriminatory options were not finalised in sufficient time. Accordingly, I have introduced an amendment to delay commencement of the provisions until 1 July 1994 to allow time for the funds to be in a position to comply with the new regime.

The amendments to the High Court of Australia Act 1979 will change the administrative structure of the High Court by amalgamating the existing offices and responsibilities of the clerk of the court and the registrar into one office which is to be called the `Chief Executive and Principal Registrar'. This will streamline the administration of the court by avoiding duplication of the functions currently performed by the clerk and the registrar. The Chief Justice has specifically requested and approved these amendments. I commend the bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.
Debate (on motion by Mrs Sullivan) adjourned.
Consideration resumed from 28 October.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill gives effect to the decision announced in the budget to change the safety net arrangements applying to general patients under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The PBS, which for more than 40 years has been providing the Australian community with access to necessary medicines, enjoys international recognition for its success. A number of adjustments are being made to the PBS through the 1993-94 budget to further improve its cost effectiveness and operating efficiency. The PBS safety net, which was introduced in 1986 to help people who need a lot of medicines, will remain available. There will be no changes to the safety net arrangements for pensioners and other concessional beneficiaries. Changes are being made, however, to general patients' entitlements under the scheme.

PARA.TAB: In 1992 the use of medicines under the free safety net for general patients increased by more than 150 per cent over the previous year.With an ageing population and the development of new drugs, the costs of operating the PBS are increasing every year. In 1992-93, for instance, costs increased by 25 per cent over the previous financial year to around $1.5 billion. This cost must eventually be borne by the taxpayer. As well, there has been a growing tendency for people to stockpile medicines. In 1992 more than 70 per cent of the annual number of prescriptions for general patients were supplied in the last two months of the safety net period.

This bill introduces a number of changes to address these issues. The safety net scheme has been simplified for general patients by eliminating the second free limit and increasing the first concessional limit to $400 per year indexed. Once a general patient and members of his or her family have this amount recorded on their prescription record form, pharmaceutical benefits will be available at the concessional rate of $2.60 indexed for the remainder of that calendar year.This replaces a more complex two-step safety net system under which a general patient qualified for concessional benefits after spending $312.30 on pharmaceutical benefits in a calendar year and then for free benefits after spending a further $52.00 in that year. This change is expected to reduce outlays by $12.4 million in 1993-94, $32.0 million in 1994-95, $33.4 million in 1995-96 and $34.9 million in 1996-97. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mrs Sullivan) adjourned.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1993 seeks to amend the Australian Citizenship Act 1948. Firstly, it seeks to insert a preamble, to quote the government, `giving recognition to the significance of Australian citizenship'. Secondly, it seeks to amend the citizenship act to abolish the current oath or affirmation of allegiance and to replace it with what I believe is a very wimpish pledge. Thirdly, and consequent upon that second amendment, it seeks to remove all reference to allegiance to the Queen as head of state from the commitment made by new citizens on taking the grant of citizenship.

PARA.TAB: So far as the last of those three objectives in the bill is concerned, this is not the first time that a Labor government has attempted to delete reference to the Crown from the oath and affirmation. It was attempted in 1973 and again in 1984. On both those occasions the attempt was defeated in the Senate. In 1984 it was defeated by the coalition with the support of the Don Chipp led Australian Democrats. How the Democrats have slipped since then. I understand that the Democrats have supported the introduction of this wimpish pledge. The Democrats' role in this will be watched very closely by the Australian community because the government is attempting to initiate a premature debate on the republic and this bill is a segment of that debate.
