I say to those opposite that constitutional change in this country can occur only if the Australian community says it wants a change. I think the government has been inclined to overlook this. It has stimulated a debate on the changes to the constitutional monarchy that we function under in Australia, it has commenced this debate on the republic and, in many instances, it has moved to a position without any consultation with the Australian community. The government must be reminded that that constitutional change—if it is ever to occur—can occur only if it has the support of the Australian community.

The changes that are being proposed by this bill have drawn a great deal of criticism. One of those who has expressed very grave concern about the changes which have been announced—not just in the legal sense, but more particularly in the symbolic sense—is the very respected clergyman, the leader of the Anglican Church in Australia, Archbishop Peter Hollingworth. He recently wrote that what is being proposed in this bill `is a matter of deep symbolic and civic importance to us as a nation'. He wrote:

There is good reason for changing words or formulae if they give a wrong impression, or the original meaning has changed or if there is widespread objection based on conscience. But does the existing Oath of Allegiance offend in these ways?
The swearing of an oath goes right to the heart of human belief. To take an oath is to highlight the solemn seriousness, power and efficacy with which a person's own word become endowed.

SPEECH.PARA: He makes the point very well, and I agree very strongly with the sentiments expressed in that quote. The situation in the USA is quite different. We need to examine some of the things that Australian citizenship entitles us to and compare them with that of other countries. I want to remind the House of the rights and responsibilities that citizenship of this great country provides, and of the privileges it endows on the citizens of Australia.

PARA.TAB: Some of us are fortunate enough for it to happen naturally because we were born here. Immigrants who become Australian citizens achieve the same basic rights as Australian born citizens. They must enrol and vote in elections; may apply for appointment to any public office; may stand for election as a member of parliament; may apply to enlist in the defence forces or for those government jobs for which citizenship is required; may apply for an Australian passport; may re-enter Australia without the need for a re-entry visa when they travel overseas; have the right to be protected by Australian diplomatic arrangements while travelling overseas; and may register as Australian citizens their children who are born overseas.

Those accepting citizenship are expected to undertake a number of responsibilities in return for those rights and privileges. Those accepting citizenship are expected to be loyal to Australia and its people, to share in the belief of the democratic process, to respect the rights and liberties of other Australians and to uphold and obey Australia's laws. They must serve on a jury if they are called upon to do so, and they must help to defend Australia should the need arise.

The tragic part about this bill is that it is denigrating and devaluing the rights of Australian citizenship. I am really not suggesting that we should follow the example of America and its pledge of citizenship word by word, but certainly it is an extremely important issue in the US.

Let me compare the US situation with our existing situation here in Australia. To become an American citizen, an applicant must have been physically present in the United States for at least half of the required five-year residency period. Every applicant for what the Americans call naturalisation—we use the term `citizenship'—has to go through a two-stage process. First of all, the applicant has to demonstrate an understanding of the English language, including an ability to read, write and speak words in ordinary English language. People who are aged or have particular disabilities are exempted from that criterion. Secondly, the applicant for citizenship has to demonstrate a knowledge and understanding of the fundamentals of the history of the country, the principles and the form of government of the United States.

At the first stage hearing in the US citizenship approach, the applicant may be represented by a lawyer or a social service agency. There is a 30-day wait after the preliminary hearing and, if that preliminary hearing is favourable to the applicant, there is a final hearing before a judge who then administers an oath of allegiance. The American oath of allegiance is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: I hereby declare, on oath, that I absolutely and entirely renounce and abjure all allegiance and fidelity to any foreign prince, potentate, state or sovereignty, to whom or which I have heretofore been a subject or citizen; that I will support and defend the Constitution and laws of the United States of America against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the same; that I will bear arms on behalf of the United States when required by the law; that I will perform noncombatant service in the armed forces of the United States when required by the law; that I will perform work of national importance under civilian direction when required by the law; and that I take this obligation freely without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; so help me God.

The important part of that oath, which I believe needs to be quite clearly stated in any oath of allegiance in Australia—which is why I so strongly support it—is the fact that Americans declare on oath that they renounce and abjure all allegiance and fidelity to any other state or sovereignty.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the government here is attempting to move the debate on the republic further forward. Its proposals weaken the current citizenship oath. A wimpish pledge is really no substitute for an oath. That is why I raised Bishop Hollingworth's comments about that. I believe an oath has much greater strength in the legal process and requires a much greater commitment by a person making that oath of allegiance.

In this form the pledge significantly weakens the commitment required of new citizens. To me, the pledge does imply much less commitment than an oath or an affirmation. The wording of the proposed pledge itself contains absolutely no reference to the head of state, to the constitution or to any other of our basic institutions. The Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), who is at the table, may not like it, but Queen Elizabeth II is still the Queen of Australia under the law. Whilst she is the head of this country, I cannot understand why any government would seek to remove her name and a pledge of allegiance to her, because it is written into the laws of the country.

This pledge makes a vague allusion to Australia and its people. That may be fair and reasonable. We are really talking about making a commitment by an oath. What we should be talking about is making a commitment by way of oath to the head of this nation. So long as the Queen remains our head of state, and our constitutional arrangements remain as they are, the oath or the affirmation of citizenship should continue directly to incorporate these facts. That is the way our present laws and our present structure operate.

If the Assistant Treasurer is suggesting for one moment that the Queen will be removed as the head of state of this nation, I tell him quite clearly that he must take it to the Australian community. The Australian community will decide whether the constitutional changes that the Labor Party is suggesting are enacted, not some minister who thinks he will change the oath of allegiance to a pledge and try to weaken the structure by chipping a little segment away here and a little segment away there. If the government were at all honest about this, it would have come up with a referendum and said, `Righto, we will ask the people of Australia whether in fact they want that removed from the citizenship oath'. I am pretty sure the Assistant Treasurer knows what the answer would be to that.

I also want to refer to the promotion of this pledge by the government at the taxpayers' expense. This government promotion at taxpayers' expense will not be done at some small cost. The bill provides for $230,000 to be spent in the 1993-94 financial year. That is probably the commencement budget for it; there will be ongoing expenses to fund an information program and to introduce the new pledge and the preamble to the Australian community. It is really using that as part of its advertising campaign. It is a slush fund for the Labor Party to promote its ideas about the constitution of this country and the way this country should be run.

I can assure honourable members there are many more important things than an advertising campaign on this issue which asks the Australian community whether it agrees with it or not. Some of those important things, particularly in my own area—which is one of the highest unemployment areas in Australia—are jobs, jobs and more jobs. With over 7,000 people unemployed in my electorate, that $230,000 might have been better spent in doing something about some employment for those people who are out of work. In continuing with this promotion of the republic as a first chink or a second chink, without going back to the Australian community to ask whether it agrees with the line the government is taking, is quite outrageous.

If the government had any courage it would put this issue to the public in a referendum and ask whether or not the public really wants these changes. The government has tried to slide this in through the side door to get it through. When people take the opportunity to become Australian citizens and read this wimpish pledge they will have to make, they will say, `Well, it doesn't look as though the government feels any requirement to have a statement for which we are bound. The head of state of Australia is Queen Elizabeth II, so why should we worry about it'. There is a constant wearing away of the public's perception, and this is another move towards that.

The wording of the whole pledge, to me, does not really cover the commitment and the sorts of responsibilities that people becoming new Australian citizens feel. I have been to many celebrations where people have undertaken this solemn oath to become an Australian citizen, and they regard it very highly. They understand that they are taking on new rights and new responsibilities. They also understand and expect that certain privileges are attached to it as well. I put to the House that in fact we should be moving to a much stronger position on the oath of allegiance. I quote to the House some words which I have put together. They read as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: I swear by Almighty God (or in the Affirmation, I solemnly and sincerely promise and declare) that I will be faithful and bear true allegiance to Her Majesty Elizabeth II, Queen of Australia, her heirs and successors according to law.

I hereby declare on oath that I absolutely and entirely renounce and abjure all allegiance and fidelity to any foreign prince, potentate, state or sovereignty of whom or which I have heretofore been a subject or citizen and that I will support and defend the Constitution and laws of Australia and fulfil all of my duties as an Australian citizen.
I make this obligation freely without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion, so help me God.

I think that would put a lot more strength back into the oath of allegiance and would impress upon people coming to this country that we want their absolute loyalty to Australia. That is what happens in many other countries. When people are welcomed into a country and decide to take the gigantic step of becoming a citizen of that country—as they do here in Australia—we want them to pledge and swear an oath of allegiance to be absolutely loyal to this country. I know that, after having spoken and visited many Americans, they take this extremely seriously. They make an absolute commitment to their country. The newcomers to the United States of America and Australia become amongst the most loyal residents and loyal citizens of their new nation. I hope that is where we would end up. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the bill be now read a second time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Gear) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS REFORM BILL 1993Cognate Bill:INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS COURT (JUDGES' REMUNERATION) BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 28 October, on motion by Mr Brereton:
That the bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industrial Relations Reform Bill, which is now before the parliament, is arguably the most important piece of legislation to come on for second reading debate in the current parliament. It is perhaps coincidental that this bill is being debated in the same week as the Mabo native title legislation introduced by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) yesterday.

PARA.TAB: The opposition welcomes this chance to debate this very important measure. At the outset, I would like to say, on behalf of the opposition, what great importance it attaches to reforming Australia's industrial relations system. Having said that, I have to say to the House on behalf of the opposition that we are profoundly disappointed that this bill does not live up to the rather flamboyant, exaggerated, high flown title that it carries.

It is described as an industrial relations reform bill. But anybody who has read the bill or followed the debate about industrial relations that has gone on in the community over the past few months would recognise that, far from this bill being an industrial relations reform bill, it is a trade union pay back bill. This is a bill paying back the trade union movement of Australia for the enormous support that it gave the government in the March election only eight months ago.

If you think, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I exaggerate that description out of a sense of political bias on these matters, let me invoke the language of Jennie George. Jennie George, as everyone in this House would know, is the Vice-President of the ACTU. The final terms of this bill were not settled between the government, the employers and the trade unions; but between the minister and the executive of the ACTU. They were the people who made the final decision as to what was going to be in this bill.

When Jennie George was having a debate with Bryan Noakes of ACCI about the contents of the bill and she was told that the employers had some objections, her reply was very revealing. She said, `What the employers have got to understand is that we won the election in March and this bill is a payback for the commitments that were made by the government in the course of that election campaign'. The first thing that we should do in this debate is put aside completely the cant, the humbug and the hypocrisy that this in some way represents a reform to Australia's industrial relations system.

The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) would have won more marks with me, with the media of Australia and with the employers of Australia if he had said, `Look, brothers, this is blatantly a payback to the trade union movement for the support that it gave us'. Instead we had all of this nonsense about how he struggled, he strived, he thought, he stayed up late at night burning the midnight oil, he looked at numerous submissions and, at the end of the day, he finally reached the top of the hill and said, `I've reached a balance. The balance is fair. The balance is reasonable. I have struggled hard. I have given the employers a bit here and I have given the trade unions a bit there'.

I say through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to the minister: that really is nonsense. By his coy reaction—if this minister can have a coy reaction, and I do not mean that ungraciously—we can see he knows darn well that what I am saying is absolutely true. This bill is yet another chapter in the long history of this government paying its political dues to the trade union movement of Australia.

In his speech to the Institute of Company Directors in Melbourne in April, just after the election, the Prime Minister said that this bill was meant to trailblaze deregulation of the labour market; that this bill was meant to genuinely open workplace bargaining to the non-union sector. The real test of this bill is the way it answers two questions. The first is: does this bill genuinely open workplace bargaining to non-unionists? The second is: does this bill deal equally with those who have a role in the industrial relations system of this country? I believe that this bill fails both of these tests.

The bill fails an even more important test: does it make a contribution to relieving the biggest social problem this country has at the present time, the problem of high unemployment? Much and all as this bill grieves me because of what it does to the secondary boycott law—and I will come to that in a moment—much and all as it grieves me because of the clayton's way in which it deals with the issue of workplace bargaining, and much and all as the opposition repudiates the obsessive use of the external affairs power in the constitution, the thing that above all condemns this bill is that it will make unemployment worse. This bill will add to the unemployment problem of this country because it will make Australia's labour market even more rigid—it will add greater inflexibility. It will import new minimum standards that make it dearer, more complicated and more expensive to employ Australians. That is a fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —Slave labour.

—I am glad that the honourable member for Lilley has joined this debate because he is the head of a committee that discovered the problem and then made a recommendation in the opposite direction. He was head of a caucus task force that identified one of the reasons for unemployment in Australia as the rigidity of our labour market. Did he recommend any change? No, he recommended that we spend more money on the problem. He will vote in favour of a bill that will make unemployment worse.

PARA.TAB: If government members are true to their most solemn political obligation to the unemployed of Australia, if they really care about those out of work, then they will vote against this bill. I have said before tonight that the best thing the minister could do is to forget about this bill—do not proceed with it; adjourn it indefinitely. The minister will be doing the unemployed a favour and he will be earning a few marks for himself in industrial circles in this country.

One of the reasons Australia has 11 per cent unemployed, and the United States has six per cent unemployed, is that our labour market is infinitely more rigid and inflexible than that of the United States. The United States has passed through the same recession as we have passed through and it basically has the same attitude to many things as we have. There has to be a reason why our unemployment is so much worse. Why is it that we have such high unemployment? Why is our unemployment level so much worse than that of a country like the United States, especially when we bear in mind that the United States has a much greater urban underclass than Australia has? The collapse of family life and social infrastructure in the United States is much further advanced than it is in Australia. The extent of poverty and so forth goes much further than in Australia. Yet it has a lower rate of unemployment. Why is that?

One of the reasons—and I commend this to the honourable member for Wills (Mr Cleary) and to the honourable member for Lilley—is the very simple proposition that in the United States it is not as complicated to employ people as it is in this country. What virtue is there in making it ever more difficult, complicated and expensive to employ people when the inevitable consequence of that is that the government makes it unlikely that employers will take on new staff? Has the government ever stopped to wonder why over the last 10 years there has been a huge rise in the number of part-time employees in this country and a sharp fall in the number of full-time employees? One reason is the great influx of married women into the work force and the great social change that is a consequence of that.

Another reason is that it has become so complicated and expensive to employ people on a full-time basis. I would have thought that a government seized of that problem would have said to itself, `If we're going to change the industrial relations system, one thing we must do is not make it more expensive to employ people because that will add to unemployment. We ought to make it less expensive and less complicated'. The problem is not the level of wages. I have not argued for some years—I say this to the minister very directly—that the problem in this country is the level of wages. That is not the problem.

Manufacturing employees in Australia are, relatively speaking, paid lower rates of remuneration than they are in comparable places such as the United States, western Europe and Japan. The problem is the on-costs, such as the redundancy requirements, the superannuation guarantee levy, the termination requirements, the training guarantee levy, and all the other on-costs. The government cannot expand some of the great service industries of this county because of the prohibitive costs of running some of those industries at what are not normally regarded as the usual working hours of nine to five, five days a week. They are the things that make it expensive to employ people in Australia.

I would have thought that people are interested in reducing unemployment. That, I hope we all agree, is the big problem. It is certainly the problem that the people of Australia are worried about. We can get worked up about Mabo, the republic and other things, but I commend to all members of this House the Newspoll survey of a couple of days ago which showed that unemployment was at the top of the list of concerns for the people of Australia. Whether one votes Labor or Liberal, whatever one thinks of this bill, the real test of whether we are doing anything about the problems of this country is how we address the issue of unemployment.

I do not pretend that I have a magical answer to unemployment; I have never pretended that. I do not pretend that we can get rid of unemployment quickly. It is a very slow, difficult, arduous task. One of the things we should not do is make it more expensive for small businesses in this country to take on full-time staff. That is one of the things this bill does. That alone is enough to condemn it. Why, in the name of logic, in the name of helping people who have jobs, does the government make it harder for people who do not have jobs to find work? Basically, that is what this piece of legislation is going to do.

Government members can make speeches, as undoubtedly they will during the debate, saying we are concerned with hacking away minimum standards. That is the usual rhetoric, but that really will not be addressing the fundamental issue: why make it more difficult and more expensive to employ people? The major reason I do not like this legislation is that it will make unemployment worse. That is about the most serious indictment of any piece of legislation that can be made in the current economic climate in Australia.

There are three principal areas covered by this legislation. The first destroys the effectiveness of a law that I was personally responsible for as the minister for business and consumer affairs in the Fraser government in the late 1970s. I can remember having a discussion with the then President of the ACTU, Bob Hawke, who later became Prime Minister of this country, and Paul Munro, the Federal Secretary of the then Australian Council of Government Employees, who, by coincidence was a colleague of mine at the Sydney University Law School in the late 1950s and early 1960s. I can remember Bob Hawke saying to me, `If you pass this legislation, there will be blood in the streets of Australia. It is anti-worker legislation'.

We did not take too much notice of that and we passed that legislation. There has not been blood in the streets of Australia. However, over the last 16 years there has been a situation where, if a trade union puts a secondary boycott on a small business calculated to bleed it to death, that small business can get immediate injunctive relief, as it has a perfect right as an Australian corporation to do. If a person is in business and puts a secondary boycott on another business to drive that business to the wall, that business can get immediate injunctive relief and it ought to have the right to do so.

What those on the other side are doing with this amending bill is trying to establish a situation where trade unions are, in blunt terms, above the law when it comes to secondary boycotts. The government is going to strip away a protection, particularly for small business, that has been available and has worked well for the last 16 years. The government is taking it away because the ACTU has told it to take it away. It has been on the ACTU's hit list for 16 years because that law gave protection to the corporations of Australia that were the sharp end of union thuggery. I do not say that all unions behave in a thuggish fashion—I have never said that—but some do, just as some companies do. There should be a law that stops them both, and for the past 16 years there has been. If this bill goes through, there will be a law stopping the thug companies, but there will not be a law stopping the thug unions.

Is that fair? Is that Australian? Is that the sort of governing for all Australia that the Prime Minister promised on the night of 13 March this year? Of course it is not. It is payback time for the mates. That is what this bill is all about. The government is paying it back in very large measure. Those opposite can talk about a procedure where after 72 hours we can go to law and get injunctive relief, but they must understand that some small businesses are broke in 72 hours if the supply of their product is cut off. Do those opposite not understand that we cannot have a secondary boycott on businesses for that period without them being bled white? Those opposite understand that very well, and that is why they are voting in favour of it. That is precisely what the ACTU wants. The ACTU wants to be able to blackmail companies into caving in because those companies will know that for 72 hours they bleed to death, and at the end of it there is nothing worth going to court to save—it is all gone.

Anyone who has had a modicum of contact with small business knows that that is the reality. I can only say through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to the Democrats who sit in another place, `Heed the words of your founder, Don Chipp. You, the Australian Democrats, are supposed to, inter alia, defend the interests of small business against large corporations'. Large corporations can survive for 72 hours. If we are running a tiny operation we cannot survive for 72 hours. That particular provision is anathema.

The second great layer in this bill is the wholesale use of the external affairs power of the constitution to import further ILO conventions into the laws of this country. Echoing some of the sentiments that were expressed in the previous debate, may I say how absolutely ironic it is that the Australian Labor Party is going around this country saying, `We have got to become a republic in order to establish Australian independence because it compromises Australian independence to share our head of state with a number of other countries'. Yet in the same breath the Labor Party is trading away day by day the sovereignty of this country by invoking international obligation after international obligation. Ever since the Labor Party has been in power it has embarked upon a pattern of conduct designed to use the external affairs power in order to distort and alter the domestic political balance in Australia. The external affairs power was never intended to be used for that purpose.

I have no arguments at all with the use of the corporations power. That was projected in our own alternative policy taken to the last election. I have no problem with that. The Commonwealth parliament was given the power over corporations in the constitution, and as interpreted by the High Court I regard that as a totally legitimate use of the power. The external affairs power was never intended to be used as a stick with which to beat the states and to alter the federal balance.

I find it a supreme irony, contradiction and hypocrisy that these strident Australian nationalists, under this government, can now go to a UN committee and have a human rights claim adjudicated. I am all in favour of adjudicating human rights claims, but should they not be adjudicated in Australia? We abolished appeals to the Privy Council in 1986 in the name of Australian nationalism, sovereignty and independence; yet this mob, five years later through the back door, has handed over sovereignty to United Nations committees. Some of the representatives on those committees do not even come from democratic countries; they come from dictatorships.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.

—They do. I am glad that the minister agrees with me. Under this government—and the minister has confirmed it—we got rid of appeals to the Privy Council in order to assert our independence, but the minister is perfectly happy to go cap in hand to United Nations committees to have human rights claims adjudicated. What the minister is doing with this bill is in precisely the same genre as that kind of conduct. So these great robust nationalists are, day by day and week by week, handing over sovereignty to bodies that have no relevance at all. We trenchantly oppose this ritualistic use of the external affairs power.

PARA.TAB: The third area of concern is the area that was supposed to be the hallmark of the minister's period in office. This minister was going to do what nobody else had done. He, a member of the Australian Labor Party, was going to genuinely infuse workplace bargaining for non-unionists into the industrial relations structure. Of course, he got no further than anybody else because, when the crunch came, Martin and Bill rang up the Prime Minister and said, `Look, we backed you to the hilt in the last election. You wouldn't have got there without our help. Don't you think for a moment that you are going to take any kind of power away from us'.

The most important thing that has to be said about workplace bargaining is that there is nothing in this bill that alters one iota the monopoly that the trade union movement has over the bargaining process under Australia's industrial relations system. There are 71 per cent of workers in the private sector in Australia who do not belong to trade unions. What this legislation essentially says in relation to those people is, `Yes, you can do workplace bargains with your employer, and those employers can do workplace bargains with you, provided you go through four hoops'.

The first hoop is that the starting point for those negotiations has got to be the totality of the existing award—the no disadvantage test. That may rob a firm and its employees of the flexibility to reach a deal, for example, that would defer the payment of penalty rates for a period of 12 months on the understanding that if the company reached a particular profit performance it would get a bonus and a share of the profit. As I understand it, that would not be allowed under what the minister is proposing. Yet many people who follow these matters would regard that as eminent commonsense because that would not observe the totality of the existing award.
The second hoop is that the union has to be notified, even though the people being dealt with do not belong to the union. Any union that has any kind of award coverage in the area has to be notified.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not true.
—It is true. We will come to that in the committee. The third hoop is that we then have to go off to the Industrial Relations Commission.
—That is true.

—Yes. When we get to the Industrial Relations Commission we have to argue our case. The minister will not deny this: any union that has an award linkage can come along and argue against it, even though none of the people covered by the agreement belong to that union. That is true, is it not? Of course it is true. We have a situation where 50 people employed by Wayne Swan Pty Ltd do a workplace deal with the owner of Wayne Swan Pty Ltd. None of those employees belong to a union; they cannot bear the union. In fact, with Wayne Swan's help the union organiser came to his shop and said, `Look, can we talk to the employees? Can we talk to the men and the women whom you employ?' He says, `Righto'. Being a generous sort of bloke he says, `You can talk to my employees. My employees will say, "Get lost. We don't want to talk to your union. We can look after ourselves"'. Wayne Swan says `Ta-ta' to the union delegate. He sits down and he negotiates a deal. He goes along to the Industrial Relations Commission and says, `Look, we all want this deal. The 50 of them want it, I want it, and it is good for everybody'. The Industrial Relations Commission says, `Yes, but we have got to hear from the union'. Wayne Swan says, `Oh, you must not do that. They threw him out'. The Industrial Relations Commission says, `That doesn't matter. They have a right to come along and object'.

PARA.TAB: The minister is saying that he is serious about extending workplace bargaining. He is shamed by that—he has that coy grin again. He knows darned well that that does not amount to genuine workplace bargaining. He has not tried seriously to bring in workplace bargaining. Every man Jack who understands this system knows darned well that what he is introducing is a phoney, clayton's form of workplace bargaining.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you hate it.

—No, what I hate is humbug. If the minister had said that this was a deal to pay back the trade unions and made no pretence about it, he would at least have marks for being honest. I do not hate unions or unionists; I hate humbug—as does the Australian public. This bill is an exercise par excellence in Brereton humbug. So, far from it being some kind of monument to his political skills, it will be a monument to his political humbuggery. He knows that—as do people who follow these debates.

PARA.TAB: This legislation does not deliver on any of the promises made by the Prime Minister. It is loaded in favour of the trade union movement. That does not surprise me. It strips away the secondary boycott protection that has worked so effectively over the last 16 years. It follows the depressing pattern of pawning Australian sovereignty by handing over, through the external affairs power, more authority over the affairs of this country to international bureaucrats.

This legislation also establishes, quite unnecessarily, another court structure. I would have thought the last thing we wanted was another layer of courts. The Federal Court of Australia, through its industrial judges, is doing an excellent job. Even if the minister is obsessed about altering the secondary boycott law—which obviously he is—he does not need to establish another court to do that. He could make the changes—we will vote against them—to the secondary boycott law but leave it in the Trade Practices Act or transfer it to the IR act. We do not need a labour court. Why do we need another court when we have a million people out of work? Specialist courts are always a little suspect because the concern is that they will do special deals for special groups.

One of the concepts of equality of law ought to be, as far as possible, that all Australians, irrespective of our station in life, are subject to the ordinary laws of this country, administered by the ordinary courts. The idea of establishing some kind of special court ultimately leads to the suspicion that some kind of special deal will be done.

This legislation is depressingly disappointing. The opposition—as the minister will conclude from what I have had to say—is not going to support the bill. We will be endeavouring to amend the legislation. I hope that in another place, where the balance of power is held by the minor parties, there will be some accommodation of some of the amendments that we will propose.

One of the amendments that I will put forward—and move during the committee stage—deals with the clauses dealing with the termination of employment. Those clauses say that people's employment cannot be terminated on a number of grounds. One of the reasons a person's employment cannot be terminated is that that person belongs to a trade union or engages in trade union affairs—with the permission of his employer—during his employer's time.

I do not have any argument with that proposition; the belief that people should not be sacked because they belong to a union. It was part of our policy that unionists could not be victimised by reason of their union membership. But I would like it to also operate the other way. I cannot see any reason why a fair-minded minister would not agree to add to the criteria in that clause a simple provision that somebody cannot be sacked for not belonging to a union. I would hope the minister would nod his head in agreement because it is a fair, simple and even-handed proposition. If it is good enough to say, `Don't sack people because they belong to a union', why is it not good enough to say, `Don't sack people because they do not belong to a union.'?

I do not want anybody to tell me that does not happen; it does. It happens all the time. It happens in the Australian Public Service. I have correspondence from some people who applied to be interpreters in the Public Service. They got a reply from the department saying, `We are very sorry, but we have done a deal with the public sector unions saying that we will entertain applications only from people who are members of the union'. This happened in the last 18 months. I say to the minister, `Do not say that sort of thing does not happen'. It happens hand over fist—which is why there is almost 70 per cent union membership in the public sector; de facto compulsory unionism is operating. We are not very impressed with this bill. Mr Deputy Speaker, you may have got that idea. We think the minister has paid his political dues but has failed his industrial relations obligations. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Swan Mr W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Industrial Relations Reform Bill because it will accelerate the move towards enterprise bargaining, continue to make Australia a more productive and competitive nation and lead to the generation of more jobs in the future. I also support it because, at the same time, it maintains the Australian Labor Party's commitment to a fair and just system of industrial relations. It does so by providing a strengthened and enhanced award safety net.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that this bill provides for a more flexible framework for enterprise bargaining, contrary to the assertions from the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). It will do that by ensuring that formal enterprise bargaining is available to the widest possible range of workplaces. We have seen this recently. Since October 1991, more than 1,200 enterprise agreements have been ratified by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Around 37 per cent of workers under federal awards are now covered by agreements. In Queensland recently there has been a dramatic extension of enterprise agreements.

In the state jurisdiction, where there are provisions which mirror the federal legislation, the number of agreements has increased by something like 400 per cent in total since March. Those agreements cover workplaces such as the Cairns Post, the Southern Cross Foundry in Toowoomba, Driza-Bone on the Gold Coast, the Nerada tea packing factory, and so on.

I make those points to illustrate that this trend towards greater flexibility in the workplace, with workplace bargaining and enterprise agreements, is already well down the track in the work force. It is a pity that members of the opposition do not talk to some of the businesses and employees that have negotiated genuine bargains within the existing framework. This package today will accelerate that progress and further accelerate the spread of enterprise agreements in the work force.

I find listening to the honourable member for Bennelong today to be profoundly depressing. He puts forward unsubstantiated, ideological fundamentalism, claiming that the total cause of unemployment in our community somehow is the industrial relations system. He says that all the economic problems in our community are caused by wages, the trade unions and the industrial relations system. I find it even more depressing that he is joined in this endeavour by most of the economic commentators in the daily newspapers and most of the spokespeople and ideologues representing business organisations.

It is very important to separate fact from fiction. The honourable member for Bennelong gave us an enormous amount of fiction and very little fact. He had the hide to complain about us adopting ILO minimum standards when he does not mind jetting off to Geneva every year to visit the ILO. If he is going to complain about ILO minimum standards and all such concepts in this legislation, he should forfeit the trip to the ILO and say what he really stands for. He stands for no minimum standards, individual contracts and slashed wages. He would take this country down the low wage, low productivity path of the American system that he eulogised in the House today.

This country grew in the 1980s. We had employment growth when we had a reasonably highly unionised sector. The Americans did not have our rate of employment growth; and they do not have a unionised sector. He cannot argue the point that differences in employment growth in this country and the United States relate to the industrial relations system. People in the Liberal and National parties misquote all sorts of figures from the United States and misquote academics such as Professor Gregory, trying to prove that the wage system is somehow responsible for our level of unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: The most important fact that we need to acknowledge is that the work force in this country over recent years has already made very significant sacrifices. Real unit labour costs in this country have fallen by something like 10 per cent in the period since 1983. If award wages had maintained their real purchasing power since 1983, then a fitter in the metal industry would receive at least $55 a week more than the award currently provides for. The point is this: the work force of this country has already made very considerable sacrifices in the interests of making this country much more productive and much more internationally competitive and in the interests of generating jobs and doing something constructive about long-term unemployment.

PARA.TAB: What do we get from the opposition in this House? Do we get any acknowledgment from the opposition that the work force in this country has made those sacrifices under the existing system—the system that it claims is causing unemployment? The answer is no; there is no acknowledgment of that at all. The opposition will not be happy until it has abolished the award system, minimum rates of pay and most of the conditions that we take for granted in this system. What it really wants is the low wage solution. It wants to force wages down to the equivalent of wages in some of the developing countries in our region. The opposition eulogises the need to have Asian levels of taxation, spending, social welfare safety nets and a low wage developing system that is found in countries like Bangladesh. The opposition has no ideas about how we can make this country more highly productive—a high wage, high productive, advanced, sophisticated manufacturing trading nation. We do not find, in any of the proposals put forward by the opposition, any strategy at all to further that objective.

The opposition simply never acknowledges the intrinsic worth, dignity and hard work of the Australian work force. It simply does not acknowledge that through the last 10 years we have developed the dual system: a system of enterprise bargaining based on an award structure. This bill builds on that great achievement—and it is a great achievement of the 1980s. It builds on that so that we can create more jobs and make this country more internationally competitive in the years ahead. This gradualist approach that has been put in place by the Labor government in this country is the envy of many of the other countries, because it is producing the sort of employment growth and productivity growth that this country needs to become an international trading nation. This commonsense, gradualist approach is rejected by the opposition, because it has a completely different agenda. Its agenda is to deliver the big bang in industrial relations, to follow the Jeff Kennett solution and to follow what has been implemented in New Zealand under the conservatives.

Fortunately—and honourable members would not know it from anything mentioned by the opposition in this House—the overwhelming majority of the Australian work force and of the Australian people, and most sensible leaders of business, acknowledge that our approach is the way to go and that the approach of the opposition is simply caught in some 1890s time warp. All the opposition advocates is some laissez faire approach to economics, which simply says that labour is no different a factor of production than a nut or a bolt. It never acknowledges that labour has some intrinsic worth which makes it a fundamentally different factor of production—a factor which has to be judged in terms of fairness and skills formation. That is the fundamental ideological divide that exists in this debate. Fortunately, as I said before, the recent election determined that the majority of the Australian people support us and so do those leaders of the business community who are not the ideologues supporting the Liberal and National parties. I shall cite a few of those people. I quote from an article in the Age of November 4 which reported some comments made by Mr John Prescott, the Chief Executive of BHP. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Chief Executive of BHP, Mr John Prescott . . . dismissed the need for big changes in industrial relations.
Did opposition members hear that? The head of BHP dismissed the need for big changes in industrial relations. The quote goes on:
The BHP chief broke from employer ranks by endorsing the existing industrial relations system and warning against calls to abolish award wages and to shift to pure enterprise bargaining.
The report of Mr Prescott's comments further states:
`I think we have fundamentally, a very good system,' Mr Prescott said.
It's a system in transition and there has been a remarkable degree of common thinking and common purpose in (its) refinement and development over the last several years.
I think the challenge for Australia is to improve the system we've got—
not the big bang approach of Jeff Kennett or the big bang approach in New Zealand—
and to change it in some material way as quickly as possible. But you can only do that at the pace at which the practitioners are developing new skills.

TALK.START.PARA: —John Prescott did not mention Jeff Kennett. You are misleading the House.

—That is true; he did not mention Jeff Kennett but plenty of other employer organisations have. Mr Noakes has said that the Victorian experiment is regrettable and lamentable. I could quote that if the honourable member for Bennelong would like as well, because the opposition is running a million miles an hour away from Jeff Kennett and the New Zealand experiment. The Age article went on:

SPEECH.PARA: He warned that changing to a totally different system could cause "a great deal of disruption" and industrial law should not get too far ahead of actual developments.

The case for gradualism in industrial relations has been endorsed by practical people who have the responsibility for implementing a system of industrial relations which will make this country far more productive so that we can generate the jobs that we require.

PARA.TAB: Let me deal with the case put by the honourable member for Bennelong—the case that argues that the cause of our unemployment in this country and of the relatively higher unemployment in this country vis-a-vis the United States is somehow caused by our system of industrial relations. I will quote from a recent paper written by Professor Bob Gregory who had this to say about the case for gradualism and the case against the assertions put by the honourable member for Bennelong that the cause of out levels of unemployment were high relative wages. In a paper called Structural changes and the Australian labour market, published in a book which also had an article by the honourable member for Bennelong called The future of work published by ACOSS, Professor Gregory said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the labour market is the key market in which the greatest differences have emerged among OECD countries over the last two decades.
. . . Australia may well be at a watershed of labour market reform, and the nature of this reform may be the crucial and irreversible policy choice over the next two years.
. . . recent labour market experiences in Australia, New Zealand and most of OECD Europe seem to suggest that the effects of adverse labour market shocks are not easily reversed.
We need to think carefully before adopting policies of radical change—there are dangers associated with a rapid and too radical deregulation of the labour market.
He went on to say:
U.S. experience suggests caution before accepting some of the more optimistic forecasts of the benefits that will flow from radical deregulation.

Why would Professor Gregory say that? Firstly, he says that the deregulated so-called flexible US labour market has not delivered significant productivity growth in the last 25 years. I thought that productivity growth might have been something that the honourable member for Bennelong and the coalition parties were interested in. But the great US system that they laud and bow before has not delivered any significant productivity growth in the last 25 years.

PARA.TAB: Professor Gregory asks this very legitimate question: in light of US experience, can we be sure there are any significant productivity increases in the offing if Australia significantly deregulates its labour market? The answer is, of course, no. Secondly, and perhaps more importantly, Professor Gregory says:

SPEECH.PARA: The better employment record of the U.S. relative to Australia, does not seem to flow from relative wage flexibility.

He cites as an example the Australian cost of female part-time employment per hour relative to male full-time employment, which is far in excess of most other countries—especially so with respect to the US. He says that in the United States women working part time are paid 40 per cent less per hour than men who work full time. In Australia women are paid five per cent less. In relative terms, female part-time employment is the fastest growing segment of the Australian labour market and the growth rate is far in excess of that in the US. In other words, female wages have risen faster in real terms in this country. It is in that area that the growth of employment in this country has been greatest. So how does the opposition's equation work? It simply does not work. When analysing the United States, Professor Gregory goes on to cite many other examples. Also his analysis of New Zealand disproves the case that the opposition puts for the big bang, Jeff Kennett-New Zealand type industrial reform. The very severe real wage cuts in New Zealand in recent times have not produced any significant employment gains at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not arguing that at all.

—So you are not arguing that; that is very good to know. New Zealand has had an employment growth of only 10,000 over the last two years despite severe cuts in real wages. What is the opposition really arguing? How low does it want real wages to fall in this country? Barry Hughes, the Chief Economist of CS First Boston, has suggested that if we wanted to have significant wage reductions, which would generate significant employment effects, we would have to cut wages in this country by the order of 30 per cent. A 30 per cent cut in wages to the average wage earner would be something like $10,000 a year. Is that what the opposition is suggesting? Is that the magnitude of the cuts that we need in the country if we are to produce the sort of employment gains that the opposition claims to stand for? Is it advocating a 30 per cent cut in the wages of average wage earners—$10,000 a year? The fact is that the overseas experience of the sort of deregulated labour market that the Liberal and National parties worship is simply that they have not produced the alleged employment gains which would come from a complete deregulation of the labour market.

PARA.TAB: Let us have a look at what the opposition has had to say about its policy over the years. I quote from the Age of 1 November comments from the opposition's spokesman, the honourable member for Bennelong. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The federal coalition has vowed to make sweeping changes to the government's controversial industrial relations legislation, including scrapping the proposed new Labor court, if it wins the next election.
In an interview with the Age Mr Howard also indicated that the coalition's industrial relations policy at the last election would remain "substantially the same"—
Is that the case?

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely.
—Does that mean that the coalition still stands for the abolition of the award system?
—No. That was not in the policy.

—Yes, the coalition does, because that is what the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) stands for. He believes that we should be abolishing the award system. The Australian of 2 October 1992 quotes the Leader of the Opposition as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: You take the Kennett legislation, it's pretty much ours, and in that sense it's quite possible that the two of us could do it in tandem,—
Jeff Kennett and the Leader of the Opposition in tandem—
and other States will have to say, `Well it seems to be working pretty well there, Victoria's getting a bit of a break on us'.

Those opposite will say, `We had better all do the same'. So the honourable member for Bennelong went into panic mode and repudiated the fact that their real intention is to abolish the award system and real minimum standards. They went into panic mode and denied that it was their policy. Of course, they might have been able to get away with it if it were not for the fact that the Western Australian election came along. The Western Australian government has gone straight down the road delivered by Jeff Kennett, straight down the road delivered in New Zealand and straight down the road that the coalition parties in this House want to go down, because it has now brought in a $275 a week minimum award wage. The current rate for a contract cleaner in Western Australia is of the order of $360 a week, so, if it suits the employer at the time, all the award is simply swept away and huge wage cuts and cuts to conditions are immediately made.

PARA.TAB: Let us be very clear about what the policy of the Liberal and National parties remains in this country. It remains individual contracts without the industrial umpire. That is the agenda—to force the wage levels in this country down to those of developing countries in the region—because those opposite do not have a vision to make this country a high productivity, high wage, sophisticated trading country in our region. They have simply no agenda for that at all.

I would like to conclude by talking a little about the concluding remarks of the honourable member for Bennelong. I would like to deal with the question of access to the system by non-unionists, because there was no other area where the honourable member for Bennelong was so misleading than in this area. The fact is that unions have no right of veto under this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that.

—No, but the honourable member for Bennelong suggested it. When the honourable member makes the comments in the community he suggests it. He suggests and implies that there is some right of veto from unions. The fact is that all that is required is that, if unions do not have members at a workplace, relevant unions must be given an opportunity to be heard when the application for approval of the agreement is before the commission.
—Why?
—Why?

—Why not? What do they have to hide? Why would an employer or a group of employees have anything to hide if it is such a justifiable agreement, if it is one that meets the standards and demands of the time? What is wrong? What they have to hide is that employees will have to take the pay cut or the sack. That is what this provision is there to deal with. It is there to protect the weaker elements in our industrial system who have no bargaining power. It is there to protect those people, and it is there to protect employees who are in a weak bargaining position from unscrupulous employers.

PARA.TAB: Does the opposition ever acknowledge that? Of course not. The opposition continues to claim that employers are dissatisfied with the current system. It is pretty hard to find some evidence of that. For example, Professor Isaac has done a survey in recent times. He has produced a booklet called Small business and industrial relations: some policy issues. Where is all this dissatisfaction with the current rigid system as alleged by the opposition? The fact is that the survey done by Professor Isaac of well over a thousand small businesses in our community—

TALK.START.PARA: —But he is part of the club.

—The honourable member for Bennelong says he is part of the club. I think it was partially funded by his mates in an employer organisation, actually. But the honourable member for Bennelong is not a member of that club either. The club that he is a member of is the Bangladesh club—get the wages down as low as he possibly can. It is not surprising that responsible elements of the business community will not be part of that.

PARA.TAB: Professor Isaac found that the vast majority of firms are not opposed to being covered by awards and that enterprise bargaining is not seen by a substantial majority of employers as a favoured arrangement. Only a small minority—around 15 per cent of firms—expressed preference for individual contracts; that is, small businesses think there is a lot of flexibility that can be delivered to their businesses and their work forces through the current system. The improvements we are making to that system today will further enhance that process. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, honest to goodness, the honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan) has given us a real example of rhetoric and innuendo but he was very weak on valid argument. The Industrial Relations Reform Bill that we are debating in this House today is about a whole lot of things, but reform is what it ain't about, except if one accepts that it further entrenches the power of one side of the debate, that is, the trade union monopoly—this bill certainly does that. This bill is about protection, employment—it is not about unemployment; it is about employment—lack of freedom of association, privilege, sovereignty and bureaucratic mechanisms.

PARA.TAB: On 21 April the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) showed, in a speech to the Institute of Company Directors, that he had really listened well to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Treasury. He got the idea stuck in his brain somewhere that if his government started to free up the labour market, to remove some of the protection of the rules and regulations that surround the labour market mechanisms in this country, we might do something about encouraging employment and reducing unemployment. He held out some hope for Australia but, unfortunately, the Prime Minister was very busy at the time. The Prime Minister was running around in the middle of the republican debate, in the middle of a disastrous budget, and spending heaps of hours trying to come to grips with this thing we call Mabo.At the same time, Mr Kelty, the Secretary of the ACTU, was extremely busy all over Australia with the regional development business and also spending time with the board of the Reserve Bank—and the Prime Minister and Mr Kelty sort of let the debate get away from them.

What really happened was that the powerful secretaries of the powerful unions got themselves together and said, `What the Prime Minister promised the nation in his speech of 21 April ain't our agenda, baby. We funded the government's election campaign and put troops on the ground in the thousands to make sure the ALP got back into power and we are not going to have any of this deregulation garbage, my friends'. What happened was they hit the ACTU congress and—boy!—the Prime Minister rolled over so quickly, Kelty rolled over and it was not on.

The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) got stuck with it—and did he get stuck! The ACTU congress tore him apart. So what did he do? He backed away at a million miles an hour. We saw him going like a scalded cat. What happened? We got this bill as a result. This bill is about protection, is it not? At a press conference following the recent Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting John Major said on behalf of himself, our Prime Minister and other heads of Commonwealth governments, `We want growth. We want jobs. We don't want protection'.

But what is this industrial relations so-called reform bill all about? It is about protection. The minister's second reading speech, his press releases, the bill and the explanatory memorandum all say that this measure is about protection, enhancing the award system, ensuring that trade union bureaucrats are protected from any action that might occur as a result of their flagrant abuse of our laws of freedom—protecting them from the normal laws that other Australians must adhere to—entrenching union power and making sure that all these small employers with their small work forces and medium sized companies that would like to do some genuine reform now come under the control of the trade union bureaucracy. That is what it is all about. It is about protection; it is about protecting the employed at the expense of the jobless. This bill does not offer one jot of employment.

Sections 45D and 45E, a piece of law placed in the Trade Practices Act, have been very positive for Australia, with our unique conciliation and arbitration system and the so-called non-necessity for enhancing in legislation a right to strike, but has placed a tremendous burden on employers, because unions can take any kind of action whatever on the political environment or on any front and can attack a company's suppliers or a company's buyers with impunity without that act in place. So what will we do? The minister will move it to the Industrial Relations Commission. He will water it down and totally remove political strikes, environmental action and `others' from any consideration.

So unions can take political action on any front about any issue that they like and there will be no consequences. And the government expects employers to have to put up with that. The government expects our economy to grow. It expects people to invest in new plant and equipment and new jobs while they are attacked under this kind of a mechanism.

The minister constantly talks about a safety net. But it is an award—a bureaucratic mechanism which sometimes goes up to as much as 100 pages of minute detail about working conditions of men and women of a particular craft, trade or job description in a plant or across the whole industry. The award is not a minima, but the minister is trying to make the award a minima. On 21 April the Prime Minister said, `We want to simplify awards. We'll simplify them and over time they will shrink, and in fact they will disappear'.

What have we done with this legislation? We have made the award system even stronger so that it will live forever. The award system is nothing but a bureaucratic mechanism for deciding how people work and how they are paid. There is nothing free or simple about it. Certainly, it does not provide real protection for jobs because it discourages employers from employing.

Under this bill we will add a labour court. That will really protect people. I can tell the House that the legal profession is not in favour of a labour court. Why not? Because it believes, rightly, that it is competent in the jurisdictions and that the general court can deal with all sorts of matters fairly and equitably on behalf of all Australians. But no, we need a special court to deal with unfair dismissals.

What do we need? Does a judge of such a court have to have been unfairly dismissed or does he have to have been an unfair dismissor to be qualified to sit as a judge of the industrial relations court? What about that, Mr Deputy Speaker? Is that on the cards? Is that what we need? Is that what we are looking for? Will that help Australia's disastrous unemployment situation? Will that help our balance of payments problem? I do not really think so. In the Weekend Australian of 30 and 31 October 1993 an editorial said, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: Promoting union power, boosting public spending and introducing new regulations will see unemployment rise, not fall.

That will be the result of the Industrial Relations Reform Act 1993. Terrific stuff! The OECD, in a statement about the variation between labour markets country to country and how they react to changes in circumstances, said, amongst other things:
The more flexible are real wages the more quickly unemployment has tended to fall following a recession—
ours has not fallen very quickly, has it?—
and the less has been the tendency of unemployment to trend upwards over time.

The OECD research tells that the more flexible a labour market is the lower level overall of unemployment in that particular economy and the less chance of unemployment sticking during a recession for very long when the recession is over. Ours is not changing because we have a regulated labour market which we will now even further regulate. Professor Judith Sloan, in response to this issue, said:

. . . in terms of absolute numbers, the age group with the highest numbers of long-term unemployed are in fact those in the 20 to 24 and the 25 to 34 age groups. In combined terms, in 1992, there were nearly 140,000 long-term unemployed persons aged between 20 to 24 years old . . . We also know that approximately one-third of the 20 to 24 year old long-term unemployed have never held a job.

Never held a job! I fear for our youth because we are, as a result of the directions in which we are going, developing a class of young people, a generation, who may never work. Quite frankly, that frightens the life out of me. If it does not frighten the government, then it ought to; the government ought to be desperately worried about it. But what does it do? It says, `Let's see whether we can tax people more to provide some more unemployment programs to deal with this problem we created because we have to have a regulated labour market; because we have to protect the people who helped get us re-elected'. Very simply, that is what it is all about. The government has to help protect those people who got it re-elected.

PARA.TAB: This bill has a no disadvantage test. In practical terms that says that, if one wants an enterprise agreement of any form, whether it is a consent agreement or whether it is an agreement for a non-unionised shop, in any case there is a whole great number of hurdles that one must pass. In fact, there are something like 16 separate obstacles that the company and its employees must jump before they can actually get to a certified agreement. That is eight up on what it was before this reform bill came in. So we are dramatically adding to the bureaucracy. Along the way we hit this thing called a no disadvantage test so that the totality of the award is examined but so also are each of the individual items of an award. The whole action becomes so bureaucratically ensconced that the chances of anybody actually using it, the chances of this providing flexibility, are now gone.

Investment in Australia is falling. Investment in real jobs, in real manufacturing plant and in real machinery is not rising. There is no real hope for next year or the year after, and this legislation does not help the case along either. The Secretary to the Treasury, Ted Evans, had a few things to say about the labour market, and amongst them he said:

The crucial reform is to allow employers and employees to strike genuine enterprise bargains to improve workplace efficiency, free of the unwanted interference of unions and without the constraints imposed by a system of multiple and highly prescriptive awards.

SPEECH.PARA: Wow! He continued:

PARA.TAB: The aim is not to cut the unions out—but unions would lose the protection of the award system, just as employers have lost the protection of the tariff wall. And like the employers, the unions would be forced to survive by meeting the genuine needs of their members.

SPEECH.PARA: Is that such an awful concept? I think not. That really is what unions should be about. The honourable member for Lilley seemed to imply that we on this side of the House had no regard for unions. That is demonstrably untrue. I am one who believes that unions do have a proper place in an industrial relations system, but that place should be determined by their ability to sell their services to their potential members. It should not be there by right, regulation or statute. That is what is wrong with this legislation, on top of our current industrial relations legislation.

PARA.TAB: The Industry Commission had a few things to say in its draft report of 20 September on regional labour costs. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission considers that greater recognition needs to be given to the particular conditions faced by workplaces in different regions when enterprise bargaining is undertaken. This would be best achieved under a system with:

PARA.TAB: no restrictions on the terms and conditions covered by enterprise agreements (other than general minimum employment standards); and
freedom for employees to choose who may negotiate on their behalf at the workplace.

SPEECH.PARA: That does not sound like much of an awful concept either, but this legislation rejects that absolutely. Alan Wood in the Weekend Australian of 30-31 October said:

PARA.TAB: The Keating Government this week failed a crucial test of its economic policy, integrity and resolve. The industrial relations reform Bill introduced into Parliament on Thursday by the responsible minister, Mr Laurie Brereton, is an abject surrender to naked trade union power and the unsavoury politics of partisanship and privilege.

SPEECH.PARA: He went on to say later in the article:

PARA.TAB: Professor Garnaut spelt out the message for a Labor Government bluntly: to achieve full employment means abandoning traditional commitments to deficit financing and wage regulation as a means of social justice.

SPEECH.PARA: He is right. Freedom of association, I tell you! It never ceases to amaze me that we talk about rights of employees and rights of men, women, cats and dogs, animals, and everything else, but our industrial relations legislation never provides a right for an individual not to be a member of an association. It always provides for a person's right to be a member of an association. This bill, in two places, makes sure that no-one is disadvantaged by being a member of a union. It says, firstly, that a person cannot be unfairly dismissed because he is a member of a union. That is fair enough; I happen to agree with that. The bill should also say that a person cannot be unfairly dismissed because he refuses to join a union, but it does not say that.

PARA.TAB: The bill also says that it is an offence against the act to induce an employee to leave his membership of a union, but nowhere does it say that it is an offence against the act to induce an employee to become a member of a union. Freedom of association is a nonsense. This bill is not about freedom of association; it is about attempting to get the 39 per cent of the free market work force which belongs to unions up to 70 per cent or 80 per cent. This bill is about trying to regulate people and to force them into joining unions to preserve the power of the current system.

I give notice that it is my intention on a subsequent sitting Thursday to reintroduce my private member's bill, which I introduced in 1990, entitled the Industrial Relations (Membership of Associations) Bill. It deals with the right of freedom of association in a fair and equitable manner. We also come to the issue, very briefly, of privilege. The preference clauses in awards, which were there before this bill, will still be there after the bill. We talk about freedom, but the preference clauses say that, notwithstanding what one may do with a work force which is partially unionised and partially non-unionised, nonetheless, the commission may bring down awards—the basis of the system of those opposite—which includes preference, if one is a member of a union. It is another act of nonsense.

We address sovereignty when the minister uses the ILO conventions under the external affairs powers of the constitution to enshrine certain minima in place. I find it unconscionable that those opposite argue vociferously that we should replace a foreign queen with faceless—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tanner Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very good to see that the mask has finally come off those opposite since the federal election. The opposition, which has previously been arguing the line about flexibility, now acknowledges that its real policy is lowering wages, particularly for those who have got weaker market power. The New Right commentators in the newspapers and many people on the opposition benches are effectively arguing that this would enable employers to have more money to invest and, therefore, create more jobs. It is laudable that the opposition is interested in the issue of employment but, unfortunately, it has to recognise that not everybody agrees with its analysis. We do not accept the proposition that lowering wages for many workers in the community—mostly the lower paid and the lower skilled—would lead to higher employment.

PARA.TAB: There are many fallacies underpinning that suggestion. We need to look only at the massive shift during the 1980s, and continuing now, to the profit share in the economy, to see some of the waste that has occurred with investment funds in our society by some of the more well-known, so-called entrepreneurs. Australian workers do not necessarily have any faith in that sort of approach. I would suggest that, in our economy, demand is the primary generator of employment. Employers put more workers on when they have work for them to do that their existing staff are not able to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with that.

—I thank the honourable member for Bennelong. Demand drives employment and growth. Deregulation would simply mean that the wages for the lower skilled would fall, as they have fallen in areas such as the United States, by as much as 20 per cent. It would not create more jobs for those types of workers because there is a dwindling number of jobs of that type required by the present economy. It would ensure that there is effectively a transfer of income from the lower skilled, lower paid to the higher skilled and higher paid. There would be a zero sum game with respect to demand in the economy because demand would fall in certain areas and rise in others. If anything, the pattern of change in demand that would occur could be marginally negative because of the higher propensity for the better off to spend on imports.

PARA.TAB: Even if it did work, even if the approach advocated by the honourable member for Bennelong were the correct path, it would still mean that the cost of solving the unemployment problem in the community would be paid for by those least able to bear that cost—the lower paid, those on the lowest incomes in the work force. Those who would suffer reduced wages as a result would be the ones who would foot the bill for solving the unemployment problem. Even if the honourable member for Bennelong were right—and I do not concede he is—we should contrast that with the prospect of tackling the problem through the taxation system, which the Liberal and National parties do not support because of the constituencies they represent. By tackling the problem through the taxation system we can solve the problem and also ensure that the economic burden of solving that problem is borne by those who can bear the cost.

If we do it by lowering wages, the honourable member for Bennelong and I will not pay any of the cost because our wages will not go down. But if we do it through the taxation system we will, as higher income earners, help to contribute to the cost. The honourable member for Bennelong has compared our level of unemployment with that of the United States. He conveniently forgets to mention the level of unemployment in Britain which now has a totally deregulated labour market. The only significant regulation in the labour market in Britain is restrictions upon trade unions, yet it has a level of unemployment that is very similar to ours, like most of the other OECD countries.

As the honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan) has most effectively outlined, we have comparisons with New Zealand and my home state of Victoria where we are not as yet seeing any great signs—I confess it is early days yet and we have to withhold judgment to some extent, but I will be watching with interest—that the approach of the Kennett government is producing any substantial improvement in the employment situation. At this stage I can see perhaps the ghost of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) leaping off the empty bench over there saying, `What about Asia?'.

I am very pleased to talk about Asia because, contrary to the mythology that is very widely spread around the place, our system in Australia is not unique. In fact, the Asian tiger countries have regulatory structures which, in many respects, are quite similar to ours. The notion that we have this vast deregulated world out there is utterly wrong. The reality in countries like Hong Kong, Malaysia, South Korea and Singapore is that they all have various types of regulatory frameworks in their labour markets, much of it similar to ours and that of the United States. None of them are identical to any other labour market regulatory structure.
