The major differences between theirs and ours are, firstly, that enforcement is very ordinary in some of those countries; so, naturally, in certain respects some of the deregulatory structures are more ignored in the breach than followed. Secondly, in a number of those countries, particularly in a country like the Philippines, there are substantial subsistence sectors of the economy where there is family based employment and not wage employment and, therefore, regulation of this nature is not relevant.

I would like to cite a few examples of these regulatory structures. The employment act in Malaysia sets minimum wages and conditions, including regulation of hours, a minimum overtime rate of time and a half, annual leave, sick leave, maternity leave and public holidays. Does that sound familiar? These are exactly the sorts of things that are covered in our awards. In some instances, these provisions are more generous than those applying in Australia.

In Malaysia, for example, where hospitalisation is involved, sick leave of up to 60 days per annum is the entitlement of employees. Obviously some of these other provisions are less generous—for example, in regard to hours—than provisions in Australia. There is a trade unions act under which unions must be registered, as is the case in Australia. There is an industrial relations act and an industrial court with conciliation and arbitration functions including, in certain circumstances, functions of compulsory arbitration—something which we are led to believe is unique to Australia.

In South Korea, union membership has doubled to nearly two million in the past few years. There is a very large number of smaller unions and a small number of very large unions. The labour union law in South Korea requires that employers bargain with the union where that union has members present. The labour relations commission is a tripartite body for resolving disputes. In the period 1987 to 1989, following substantial improvement in the level of democratic participation in South Korea, there was a massive upsurge in industrial disputes: from 276 in 1986, to 3,749 in 1987, to 1,873 in 1988, to 1,616 in 1989.

Even in the Philippines there is a labour code which specifies minimum conditions regarding hours, overtime, rest days, wages, annual leave, termination and the like. There is a fairly well developed system of voluntary and compulsory arbitration in place. Obviously there are differences. Obviously these systems are not exactly the same as ours. But what is happening in these countries is that, as they are developing, the regulatory structures are reflecting the demands and needs of ordinary workers. Wage levels are rising in exactly the same way that these developments occurred following the industrial revolution in Europe.

To suggest that we are so odd, that we are so much out of step with the rest of the world, is simply wrong. That is only one of the numerous myths and fallacies surrounding this debate. We hear that 70 per cent of the private sector is non-unionised. I accept that figure. But we have to look behind that figure and ask why, what is actually going on out there. It is partly a product of the fragmentation of the production process. By definition, unionism is much more related to large workplaces than to small workplaces. It is much harder to sign people up; it is much harder to service them in a smaller workplace, particularly where there are only two or three employees. There is a change in the structure of the economy which is driving the reduction in private sector unionism.

Many places are part unionised. In many workplaces that I as a union official used to deal with, we de facto represented non-union members because half the people were in and half were not. We took that on board and said, `Let's hope that gradually we might persuade some of them to join'. Many have refused to join or decided not to join because of fear, sometimes justified and sometimes not, of employer intimidation. As I said in this place before, this culture of `Don't join the union, don't call the union; you know what happens to people who do that' is widespread.

There are also many people—and this is a failing of the union movement, partly due to limited resources—who have not joined because nobody has asked them. There are thousands and thousands of workplaces out there. Unfortunately, the union movement resources—contrary to the sort of blather of the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles)—are limited and they are inevitably heavily concentrated on representing the interests of existing members.

It is very difficult when someone is in a union, as I was, covering something like 50,000 workplaces to go out to all of them and say, `Hey, would you like to join?'. In the recruiting work that I have done I have often found that individuals will be signed up as members simply because I have turned up. They say, `Yes, we would like to join. It is good to see someone has fronted up'. So there are logistic restrictions as well.

It is said that the award system is an impediment to efficiency. Where are the concrete examples? Where are the dozens and dozens of concrete examples where workers, unions and employers cannot resolve the problems that do exist? I have been involved in numerous discussions where difficulties have arisen with award provisions. I concede that there are circumstances in workplaces where a particular provision in an award can generate a problem. Every time we have been able to work through it and work out a solution that everybody is happy with. Why is it such a problem? Where are the examples where that cannot be done?

The workplace industrial relations survey that was conducted a couple of years ago, which was the most comprehensive of its kind ever conducted in this country, returned a result where seven per cent of employers surveyed said that the award system was an impediment to change and to improvement in their workplace. In a very large proportion of non-unionised workplaces, far more so than unionised workplaces, many of the totem issues of industrial relations reform—such as demarcations, penalty rates and so forth—are not relevant. In the average small office we do not have demarcations because there is only one union. We do not even have penalty rates as an issue because people work nine to five; it is just an ordinary pattern. In lots of these places all of this deregulatory propaganda is simply irrelevant to the reality.

The use of international conventions is something that some of the fundamentalists of the opposition, and some of the weirder groups it tends to be associated with, are getting absolutely phobic about. A few weeks ago I noted that Max Walsh in the Age suggested that, because of the reliance of this legislation upon ILO conventions, whenever an ILO convention changes the law in Australia will automatically change. Max Walsh should stick to talking about things that he knows something about. That suggestion is absolute nonsense. Any change in an ILO convention that forms the basis of this legislation will have to be ratified by the federal government and then that change legislated by this parliament for it to have any effect in Australia. The ILO conventions, as has been the case with other international obligations, under our constitution only give this parliament the power to legislate on matters that the vast majority of parliaments across the world already have the power to legislate on. That is some conspiracy, some threat.

It is also suggested that there is a huge demand for enterprise bargaining out there. All these companies have thousands of workers saying, `Free us from the shackles of union tyranny; we want to get out there and bargain equally with our boss'. It is absolute nonsense. In many instances, companies, particularly smaller companies, actually appreciate the award system because it gives them a level playing field on which to operate vis-a-vis their competitors. They want to pay a fair community standard related wage; they do not want to exploit people. Many employers are perfectly decent human beings who want to pay a reasonable rate. They actually use the award system as a means of ensuring that community standard.

I would now like to quickly turn to a very brief description of the sort of reality that occurs in workplaces, is the subject of this bill, and is the real basis of what we are legislating for. A typical workplace would be a small wholesale company, which employs 20 workers and is non-unionised—a union has never been there. There are numerous grievances: staff shortages, poor chairs and equipment, minimal training, employees often do not get lunchbreaks, the boss is pretty obnoxious, he has a son on the payroll who sexually harasses some of the female staff—that sort of thing happens all the time—there is an office manager who is blueing with the supervisor, things of that nature. Under pressure, the boss says, `We have to make some economies'. He sacks the cleaner. He tells the female office staff—not the males, but the female office staff—`You are now going to clean the toilets after hours with no extra pay, and you had better like it or lump it'.

If opposition members think that that sort of approach to `enterprise bargaining' is unusual or bizarre, they should think about the sort of thing that happened in a major Melbourne law firm that I had the misfortune to deal with not so long ago. After the Kennett legislation was introduced, the firm's employees, who were on a 35-hour week, had flashed up on their computer screens, `As of next week you are on a 37 1/2-hour week'. The managers of the firm did not even have the decency to tell them in person; it was up on the employees' computer screens—`As of next week . . . a 37 1/2-hour week'. That is the sort of enterprise bargaining that we often see in some of these companies.

I will continue with my description of this typical workplace. This is based on a number of years of experience, which I suggest is a bit more in-depth than many members on the other side have had. Staff members have not had a pay rise for a couple of years. They are frightened of losing their jobs. Finally something breaks and they get the union in. A few staff members join the union and some side with the boss because they think, `Beauty, here is a chance where I may help ingratiate myself a bit'. A few issues are taken up. There is a bit of a resolution of a couple of matters. The boss listens to reason on some issues and then a few months go by.

Commitments are reneged on. Arrangements to cover the switchboard during lunchbreaks, for example, are allowed to lapse. The promised new chairs do not eventuate. Other things are not followed through. Then the woman who happened to complain about sexual harassment mysteriously gets sacked. Her exemplary record of over five years is not taken into consideration. She worked lots of extra hours. She recently had additional duties lumped on to her because the company was understaffed in that area. She was not trained properly for those extra duties. She had made a couple of mistakes because she was not properly trained and, bang, she is gone.

The union is too weak at that workplace to do anything about it because it has, say, half a dozen members out of the 20 employees. They are all frightened for their jobs. So an unfair dismissal application is lodged—that great, incredibly threatening process that the honourable member for La Trobe referred to. After a few months of procedural wrangling there is a settlement: a couple of weeks pay and a reference. That is the typical outcome of an unfair dismissal case. The worker is advised by the union, `We could keep going but the case could take a year or more; you could be appealed if you win; you do not really want to go back there anyway after what has happened; you do not want to be exposed to all that again'. The end result: very little. That is the typical situation in Australian industrial relations—the reality of what this bill relates to.

The reality is not the militant builders labourers and wharfies of mythology; it is not the metal workers and the like going out on strike on trivial issues. Deregulation will not hurt the militant minority. The reality of Australian industrial relations is the little people—the forgotten people, the people who are protected by the award system, most of them not in unions and with minimal bargaining power—particularly in times like these.

The employment contract is not just another contract, as implied by the honourable member for La Trobe. It is the fundamental social relationship in our community. I would like to quote from a submission of the ACTU to the Hilmer inquiry which very effectively states this. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: In labour markets, alone amongst all markets, the `things for sale' are simultaneously workers—people in society. The thing being sold is indivisible from the seller, and thus comes associated with a complex dynamic web of social interactions which lie outside the simple market transaction.

The Liberals want to deregulate the labour market in order to give more power and more income to their constituency, the people who are better off, and to take it from our constituency, the people who are less well off. This legislation is based on the award system. It enhances the award system. It provides for greater flexibility. It provides all the flexibility that employers need and it will help to ensure that Australia remains something approximating a decent society.

PARA.TAB: Some years ago when the honourable member for Bennelong was the Leader of the Opposition, he came up with this concept of One Australia. That did not do him all that well with the migrant communities in Australia because they soon saw through what it was about. I suggest to him that, in advocating the position that he is putting forward this afternoon, he is actually putting forward a position about two Australias—about gradually increasing the gap between the haves and the have-nots: the people on low wages or low incomes in our community and those who get better remuneration. Ultimately, this legislation is about ensuring that we retain some basic human decency in our society, that that gap does not get too big and that, at the end of the day, we remain one Australia—a single community where there is equity maintained in the employment relationship and the society at large.
Debate (on motion by Mr Wakelin) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca) raised as a matter of privilege the fact that on 11 November he had been served with a writ issued on behalf of a Mr A. Robinson. The honourable member explained that the writ followed a letter that he had written to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) on 20 August concerning budget announcements relating to Comcar.

PARA.TAB: The substance of the honourable member's complaint is that the issuing and serving of the writ was deliberately intended to intimidate him as a member and was an attempt to seriously curtail his continued representations on behalf of his constituents. There is no doubt that intimidation or attempted intimidation of a member in connection with the performance of the member's duties as a member can be punished as a contempt. There are precedents for references to the Committee of Privileges in connection with threats to sue members on account of correspondence that they had written.

Without expressing any opinion on the substance of the matters raised by the honourable member for Bowman, I acknowledge that the issue of members' correspondence with ministers is an important one and, accordingly, I am prepared to allow precedence to a motion in respect of this case.
Motion (by Mr Sciacca) agreed to:

That the matter of ACT Supreme Court Writ of Summons (No. SC 617/1993) issued on 21 September 1993 and lodged by Gary Robb and Associates, Solicitors, 29 Torrens Street, Braddon, ACT on behalf of Anthony Robinson as plaintiff against the Member for Bowman as first named defendant be referred to the Committee of Privileges.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS REFORM BILL 1993Cognate Bill:INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS COURT (JUDGES' REMUNERATION) BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wakelin Mr B.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will start my remarks tonight with the quote from Ted Evans, the Secretary to the Treasury. It is a very significant quote which really indicates the changing times in which we live. It also represents the high standard of independent advice given to us by the Public Service. Two or three weeks ago, Mr Evans said:

SPEECH.PARA: There are now very few economists, at least, who would deny a relationship between labour costs and unemployment—indeed, doing so would require abandoning some of the most basic tenets of our economic training. That said, there are very few, any more, who would see a reduction in nominal wages as the preferred solution to an unemployment problem. Though it might be noted that there are many areas of the economy—the rural sector and self-employed generally—for which reductions in nominal incomes are the long accepted alternative to unemployment. Such solutions are not preferred in the formalised labour market but we should be quite clear that that reflects a choice. Recognising that should be of considerable assistance in designing the alternative measure of intervening in the market.

It is that line of reasoning, basically, that motivates those who put a premium on increasing the flexibility of labour markets and it is in that process that the greatest hope of increasing the aggregate rate of growth lies.

The whole range of the microeconomic or structural reform issue under consideration, and others yet to be broached, reflect a similar reasoning. Those who reject such approaches simply fail to recognise the changes in the world environment that we face.

The increasing ease of transfer of technology, of information, of capital and even of labour mean that the competitive production of manufactured goods can be expected to occur in an increasing number of locations around the world—not just, as now, in Asia. If we, Australia, wish to have a manufacturing future, we have no choice but to compete with such producers. We can only do so if we continue to improve the competitiveness of our own production processes. Because the scope to do that within individual firms is limited, at least in the short run, there is a need for the cost reduction process to be spread throughout the economy so as to affect all inputs to production. That is the essential story behind the structural reform agenda; it is the same story that will lie behind our future growth rate and hence our success with the unemployment problem.

It is a very lengthy quote, but I think it is very significant because it comes right to the core of the issue of costs and our competitiveness as a nation. There is no doubt that industrial relations is a vital area and it is in our national interest to make sure that we get it right.

PARA.TAB: The title of this bill—the Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993—is somewhat of a misnomer, as has been referred to before by my colleagues on this side of the House. My speech tonight will focus on two or three main areas. It will focus on the politically selective process and its weakness, not in a partisan way or in the context of the adversarial political process that we insist on embarking upon in this House—and no doubt it has many positives. But I will try to look beyond what we do in this chamber to what the national interest really entails.

As has been stated earlier, the government has very much a vested interest in this bill because of its traditional links with the unions over the 100 years of its history. But it does not have a monopoly on morality. I was encouraged by what the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) had to say when he spoke on this subject in debate on a private member's bill two or three weeks ago. At that time, I thought he was somewhat more bitter in his approach. But this time he seemed to apply a little more reason and I see that as a sign of some encouragement.

He talked about the constituency that he represents, about Asia, our productivity, our competitiveness, and rising wage levels in Asia. He also talked about employer intimidation. Being an employee, I understand something about the intimidation and the power of the employer. Nevertheless, it was not enough to persuade me to go the way of many within the union movement.

He mentioned the fact that we in this place would not suffer if there were to be pressure on our wages; we would maintain our wages and we would all be okay. I have to say that if my wages have to alter in order to achieve full employment in this country over the next few years, then so be it. I am not frightened of that. I think it is important that we face that problem. As Ted Evans has said, we have to make a choice. We must never forget that we do have that choice. I agreed with what the honourable member for Melbourne said when he spoke about fair community standards for everybody—the employee and the employer.

The honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan) talked about Bangladesh and slavery—some pretty extravagant stuff. I really did expect more from the honourable member for Lilley. I think the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) mentioned before the suspension of the sitting that he had expected more of a senior member of the Labor Party from Queensland. To compare the employers of Australia with the people of Bangladesh is surely right over the top.

He then talked about slavery. Are we really going to suggest that, in 1993, we are into slavery in this country? I suppose if we were living in the year 1836, with the abolition of slavery and the emancipation of slaves—a very important time no doubt for the people of that period—maybe there would be some basis to his remarks. But I could not abide what the honourable member had to say.

The honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) said, `We won'. That was the bottom line—`We won. We are here. We are doing it. You blokes can please yourselves'. That is what they say about the winners—`We can smile and the rest of you can please yourselves'. We will not talk about the fear, the deceit and the fact that the Labor Party's policies were pretty well non-existent.

I want to talk about the adversarial nature of the union movement because the union movement relies on this adversarial notion. It relies on convincing people, through fear, that they must join them because they will save them from their bosses. I have experienced some pressure from employers, but not to the extent that warrants the excessive stuff that we hear from unions.

In that context, I want to talk about a couple of old hands in the union movement: Charlie Fitzgibbon and Laurie Carmichael. Over the last 10 years or so, they have been talking about concentrating more on wealth creation, having a little less of this adversarial nonsense, and thinking about how the unions might try to give a fair go to all Australians—particularly our young people, among whom there is 30 per cent unemployment. As I have said, the union movement relies far too much on adversarial combat to promote its cause. I think that we should listen to those elder statesmen of the union movement—the Charlie Fitzgibbons and the Laurie Carmichaels—to make sure that we bring balance to the union movement.

I think it was the honourable member for Lilley who mentioned the waste of the entrepreneurs in the 1980s; that somehow the squandering of this capital was to blame for some of the current problems that we face. We should not ever forget that it was under the ALP's financial policies of the last 10 years or so that these entrepreneurs flourished and eventually many of them flopped. Are we going to blame the $3.5 billion loss of the State Bank on those entrepreneurs? Surely not. Surely it has to be a shared responsibility between—and, being a former bank clerk and reflecting on the loss of that $3.5 billion and the opportunities that will not be there in South Australia that should be, it saddens me—the state government of the day, the management of the day, and, to a degree, the federal government. I understand that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), had a fair idea of some of the problems with the Reserve Bank well before they hit the light of day.

The Labor Party likes to talk about these entrepreneurs as though they are some scourge of the planet. The problem is that it does not offer any alternative. It was not that long ago—and I am old enough to remember—when many in the Labor Party saw the USSR and eastern Europe as their heroes. We do not hear that sort of enthusiasm these days.

When talking about the Labor Party, I always enjoy going back about 10 years to a conversation with a former federal Labor minister. He talked about the problems of fixing wages and the issues of the employer-employee relationship. He had a call one day in Canberra from a minister, who will remain nameless, from a state, which will remain nameless. The union representative had an appointment with the minister. He turned up on the Monday or Tuesday morning and, hey presto, who should walk in with the union representative but the managing director of the company. Very soon, the minister found out that there was a nice little deal on offer, if he would be in it. To his eternal credit, he would not be in it. It is never quite as pure and as sweet as some would like to paint it.

I come to my background. Maybe it would explain a little of my culture to the House and to those who might be participating in the debate. I come from small business, fundamentally, and I have employed a few people from time to time. I reached a point probably seven or eight years ago where I could not afford to employ people. The hassle was simply too great and the margins were too slim. I was in agriculture and we expect variations in business. However, the reality is, if employers are pushed too hard, if it is made too difficult for them to employ, and if incentives to employ are taken away, how in blazes are we going to get our young people back into work? Surely we should be looking at our employers and encouraging them as much as possible. Whether they are big, small or indifferent, right across the whole scale—particularly small business—surely we should be giving our employers every opportunity to employ. It is not just federal government, there are state governments involved in this as well.

I come back to my theme of a politically selective process and touch on the wool reserve price scheme. Mr Speaker, you may well ask: how does that end up in the Industrial Relations Reform Bill? It goes like this: I accepted the wool reserve price scheme was based on the false expectations of the market. However, let us compare the way that was handled in the last few years with Australia's wage reserve price scheme known as the award system. As a wool grower, I and many of my colleagues returned to the open market with a 50, 70 or 80 per cent cut to prices which sent many of us to our financial end. We, as a parliament, insist that those who survived pay off the debt—interest and all—for their sins of being productive. Yet we maintain a labour system with one million unemployed and about one million underemployed. We pay billions of dollars to people who would prefer to work if the opportunity were there and a tax system and a whole range of processes in our various systems to ensure that they realise their full potential.

Before honourable members opposite cry foul and start talking about the poor, the oppressed and the terrible coalition, I must say that I have only once, to my recollection, ever earned an above average wage—present times excluded. Recently, when I challenged a local AWU representative to work alongside me in any shearing shed at any time, his response was that his shearing skills may invoke the wrath of the RSPCA. So that contest never eventuated. I am a worker; I am a member of a union through choice. There are many times when I disagree with my union and it with me. I do believe in the advantages of group discussion and sharing the load, but I also believe in commonsense and realism as far as economic reality goes. I belong to the Liberal Party because it has a belief in the role of business, particularly small business. Presently, regional Australia is doing it tough in many areas and this budget has imposed a heavy load. The government's policy of deregulation in many other areas is imposing a heavier load.

Australia's potential has to be the main responsibility of this parliament. I have no objection to minimum standards for employment. Those standards should be there and I think it is part of the civilised ethic which we should never lose. I acknowledge the Labor Party's strong tradition and heritage in that area, but it has been over the last 20 years that it got right out of kilter. There are senior unionists in this country who will tell you over a quiet beer that it got right out of kilter. What did it create? It created the sort of unemployment and the social issues we are facing now.

In conclusion, my questions to the government are: how many jobs will this legislation create? How many cheques have those opposite written from their own pockets to pay wages, create businesses and contribute to real economic wealth? How many jobs have Martin Ferguson and Bill Kelty created? Has anyone worked out how many jobs we have exported last year? Surely the only place employment can be created is in the business sector and through encouragement of the business sector.

There is too much hype, too much posturing and too much of a charade between the government and the ACTU. We have this talk tough, play the game attitude, but we come back and we have a more conservative approach than when we started and, sadly, fewer job opportunities. There is too much vested interest, too little national interest and too many lost opportunities.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industrial Relations Reform Bill is designed to empower the major players in industrial relations. It places the onus upon those most acutely and centrally involved in the industrial relations process. This bill gives those players the opportunity to master their own destiny and to stimulate productivity, whilst maintaining the award safety net.

PARA.TAB: It is this bill that represents the best possible mix of motivation, self-determination, security and choice that our industrial relations system and its players could design. I suggest that the best possible way for me to depict the advantages of this bill is to use the example of the ACL Bearings Co. in my electorate of Bass.

I recently represented the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) at a cheque presentation for $30,000 to ACL Bearings. That $30,000 represented the first instalment of a federal government grant. This company is the workplace of the future, and it is enterprises such as this that this bill supports. ACL Bearings has, in recent years, undergone very radical organisational changes at its own cost to ensure that it is in the best position to respond to the national and international economic climate, and I commend the company for its future projection and forward thinking.

Considerable effort has been put into establishing an ongoing and effective consultative mechanism with employees. Its purpose has been to ensure that they are aware of the requirements of the marketplace, and to ensure that they can have input into the way the organisation addresses those requirements.

This is an example of the workplace of the future. The entrenchment of consultative mechanisms between management and employees can only lead to more stable and efficient systems of workplace industrial relations. This program ensures that employees are not only involved in manufacture, but they also have input into how the company responds to the market for its products. ACL Bearings is a company that supplies automotive components to the domestic market and also to the highly competitive international market.

For Australian enterprises to begin to maintain competitiveness nationally and internationally we need a sound system of industrial relations and workplace harmony. The Industrial Relations Reform Bill will guarantee this. Workplace reform contracts such as the one instituted at ACL Bearings mean that everyone involved in an enterprise has a stake in its national and international success. So how, one may ask, is this achieved? The enterprise agreement for ACL Bearings has now been agreed to by all unions on site, and has been submitted to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission for ratification.

The role of the unions is incredibly important in this process. This agreement shows unionism at its best. It confirms the fact that unions are not only supportive of their members, but they are also supportive of the enterprises for which their members work. Enterprise agreements represent the removal of the old combative system of workplace industrial relations and its replacement by one which is consultative and team oriented.

One of the most important aspects of this agreement is its training component—and I know all about training components. My own recent background lies in the training area, and I cannot overstate just how important it is to have ongoing training in companies to create a more work oriented workplace and to improve output. Training will be provided to the members of the ACL consultative committee and this will give to those involved skills to effectively undertake their functions in relation to monitoring plant performance.

The previous speaker, the honourable member for Grey (Mr Wakelin), noted that we need to have a fair go for all Australians, especially young people. I ask him where that fair go was in the coalition's suggestion that we should employ young people at a wage of $3 an hour. In my training background, I asked young people would they work for $3 an hour and they said, `No, definitely not'. That was slave labour. The opposition made a scurrilous suggestion, but fortunately on 13 March the people of Australia rejected it, and a lot of those people were young people.

At ACL Bearings all employees will be integrated into an effective team structure. I have personally been to ACL Bearings and I have seen how that mechanism is beginning. This means that employees no longer work in isolation; they are part of a team. They are efficient and, I might add, very motivated.

These are the reasons why the government is so keen to support workplace reform contracts. Under this particular contract the federal government will provide $50,000 and the company will provide $90,000. I commend ACL Bearings. I commend its employees. I commend its unions.

It is confidently expected that the outcome of this project will be of significant interest to private sector operations throughout Australia. This is the type of project that this government is endeavouring to motivate in the entire industrial relations sphere. This bill will make these projects commonplace.

The example of ACL Bearings shows what this bill is all about. This legislation is designed so that individual workplaces will have individual working conditions—conditions which will be to the benefit of the organisation, the workers and the unions. It will be of benefit to everyone concerned because industrial relations under this bill becomes flexible—a flexibility that has been unprecedented in the past. This bill seeks to create that flexibility. But, unlike the industrial relations policies of the coalition at the last election, this is a safe and secure flexibility rather than exploitive flexibility.

The honourable member for Grey sounded as if he had not really grasped what this bill is all about. The whole thrust of this bill is to encourage employers to employ, whilst still maintaining support for employees. That is our award safety net. Through this bill the award system will be strengthened and maintained, making sure that beneath any enterprise bargain a sound, secure, constantly revised and updated award system remains in place. This bill and our policy better the nation's system of industrial relations. The coalition policy would have smashed it. We would have been thrown back into an industrial dark age with division, combat and exploitation as its hallmarks.

The problem of industrial action is also dealt with by this bill. The movement towards a strong framework for bargaining has also necessitated dealing with industrial action in a similar manner. This bill will enable industrial action, including the basic right for workers to withdraw their labour during a bargaining period. What it will not allow is an action of a destructive nature, including wilful or reckless damage, personal injury or defamation. At the same time as this bill guarantees industrial rights, it also maintains industrial protection.

What does this bill represent? It is a dramatic, yet totally balanced and progressive change in the thrust and emphasis of our national industrial relations system. It represents a shift from a centralised to a decentralised system of industrial relations. It gives industrial relations back to its practitioners and allows the industrial relations system to reflect the attitude of each and every workplace. It is no longer monolithic.

This bill is the final step in achieving the perfect balance in industrial relations. It is motivational for workers and management, and stimulating to business and, therefore, the economy. Most of all, it is safe for employees, because the safety structure of awards will be enhanced and maintained. I commend such companies as ACL Bearings and congratulate the minister on this reform bill. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even if the honourable member for Bass (Mrs Silvia Smith) does not understand, the community and the national media understand, and the government as a whole well knows—the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) knows it even better—the Industrial Relations Reform Bill represents a remarkable and political failure. The bill was to have been of enormous significance to the nation's economic future. When the minister first took office, he clearly recognised the importance of genuine labour market reforms for the future competitiveness of the Australian economy.

PARA.TAB: The challenge of increased productivity is a primary concern in every economic sector, in the services, manufacturing, mining and resources sectors. The minister knew that when he embarked on this ambitious plan of reform; it remains commonsense. There is a broad, widely accepted understanding that if Australia is to pull itself towards a higher level of across-the-board global competitiveness, it is vital to address this issue of labour market flexibility at the level of enterprises, to provide enterprise based solutions to enterprise based problems.

The government knows that meaningful reform of this kind is vital. I wish that were the only reform obstacle in the way of increased productivity; but it is not. Nevertheless, it is one of the biggest of the many remaining areas of reform and one which has long been sought after by all industries as it is by the many—especially the young—who are squeezed out of the labour market by the rigid award system.

As have other members, I have read the recent laments of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) in the public media, that he fears the government and caucus are losing their reformist zeal. There is good cause to be worried by this insider's view of government. If the bill before the House represents the government's reformist drive at its best, the best the government can achieve at the height of its powers in this session of parliament, Australian industry may as well give up the ghost of achieving any real change.

Since the budget, in which the community witnessed a marked additional increase in the cost structures bearing down on industry, most have already given up the hope of any substantive changes in industry settings. This is so despite the vague, generalised comments emanating from the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Griffiths) who is hunting around for a new industry policy to improve the efficiency of industry, a policy which—as a result of the bill before the House—does not have a hope of addressing the crucial contribution that labour market flexibility makes to market efficiency.

The bill has not lived up to the ambitions of the Minister for Industrial Relations. There is no productivity dividend for the community; it will not feed through the business chain and lead to more efficient industries. All it does is spread the old, near criminal, combative, union based labour system even more persuasively than before. It is characteristic of the government that, when it gets caught in a corner and has to face up to unpalatable economic reality, it embraces the language of reform and runs a scare campaign against the real challenge of reform.

It is a sad, predictable response which demeans the nature of the debate and the many distinguished members of the community outside the parliament who participate in it. Even more importantly, it buries the crucial economic issues on which the future of industry hinge. With the legislation before the House and with the government's having failed to achieve its desired and much promoted level of change, we anticipate that the government will now proceed to misleadingly characterise the real task of labour market reform as a means of destroying workers' wages and conditions—and nothing more.

Rather than a key measure for locking in the productivity improvements and expanding growth and employment, the government will now claim real labour market change is a threat to existing jobs. This is an old game for the government; when in doubt make your failures your successes and exploit the old labour class divisions.

Meanwhile, the urgent need to create a flexible, decentralised, mature and sensible enterprise focused industrial relations system, which binds together the interests of the employer and employee, is shelved. Consequently, the bill extends the union driven award system into the non-unionised private sector, adds a new and complex layer of bureaucracy to the industrial relations system, decreases the legitimate opportunity for employers to seek protection against damaging third party union actions and represents a further push by the federal government to import foreign treaty clauses into Australia for the purposes of overriding state based industrial relations jurisdictions.

In short, the legislation is a political response to an issue at the hub of the economic challenges before our nation. There is nothing in the bill which meets its originally stated aim of providing genuine enterprise bargaining opportunities for the non-union sector. All the bill does is rigidify the existing institutional industrial relations arrangements and make a mockery of the need for flexibility and industry level bargaining. These matters are being made abundantly clear by countless commentators, as well as by other members on this side of the House who have contributed to the debate already—or will do so later.

I would like to extend my remarks into one important corner of the labour market which has been totally overlooked in the bill and utterly pushed aside by the government. It is the operation of the Coal Industry Tribunal and the moribund, insulated and uncompetitive system of industrial relations which operates across the coal industry. Before I proceed in detail, I will sketch some background on the coal industry and the industrial relation system which has evolved in that industry. It hardly needs to be said that the industry is a key export enterprise. The black coal sector employs over 25,000 people and produces some 180 million tonnes of black coal, of which about 126 million tonnes—over 70 per cent—is sold abroad at a value of $7 1/4 billion annually. That is about 12 per cent of the total merchandise export trade.

The coal industry is more than a bit player in the national economy. It is the largest single commodity export earner in this country, and it represents one of the more technologically sophisticated and globally geared industries in the economy. The industrial relations arrangements within that industry, by contrast, are antiquated and serve only to shackle the industry as it strives to build its competitiveness. The industry has its own industry specific industrial relations system, which stands outside the mainstream of the current industrial relations arrangements. The industrial relations system within the coal industry operates through the Coal Industry Tribunal—a one-man board which, in conjunction with the New South Wales Industrial Relations Commission and other lesser tribunals in Queensland and Tasmania, acts with virtually the same powers as the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

The tribunal was established under the Coal Industry Act 1946. Its roots reside in a period of Australian industrial history which is no longer relevant to contemporary needs. The Coal Industry Tribunal was established at a time when Australian coal production was directed almost exclusively at domestic consumption—electricity generation and steel manufacturing in the main, which were especially important for postwar reconstruction and development purposes.

The Coal Industry Tribunal had, as its brief, the requirement to maintain domestic production levels in an industrial relations environment which was extremely volatile. The tribunal failed the test of the miners strike of 1949 and supply to vital industries was disrupted. As time passed and the industry shifted its focus from domestic supply to international marketing by the late 1950s, the Coal Industry Tribunal had already outlived its shelf life—if it ever had one to start with. But in the early 1990s, we are still stuck with this tribunal. Apart from its industrial relations system, the industry has changed dramatically over the past 50 years from when the Coal Industry Tribunal was first established.

Coalmining is now largely an open-cut activity and resembles quarrying in many respects. Underground mining constitutes the minority of mining activity—about 30 per cent of production and less than half of all employment. It is also being transformed by longwall mining technologies. Overall, the occupational health and safety standards associated with mining have improved dramatically, as would be expected of a modern industry, and the skill base to the mining industry has deepened greatly.

Most importantly, the coal industry—now almost exclusively internationalised—exports to the major global markets. As with farmers and others, the industry therefore is a price taker. It is a price taker in a market where, while volumes are projected to be up over the next decade, returns are down and are set to remain flat for some time to come. In this environment, the industry has to absorb costs and inefficiencies or else lose markets. Regrettably, because of the massive leakage in productivity through the industrial relations system, the price competitiveness of the coal industry is on the wane. Many of Australia's coal producers are looking at having to cut their coal prices by around $10 per tonne to stay competitive with alternative overseas suppliers. That is a price cut of around 20 per cent on their current selling prices. This is not just a useful market signal to rationalise the industry. That has already happened, and many of the non-longwall underground pits have already passed into history.

What we are looking at here is for basically already competitive companies to grab every extra productivity gain they can to keep their place in the markets in the years to come. Apart from the costly and inefficient industrial relations system, there is not much fat left anywhere on the coal industry today. The industry has already embraced best practice in most of its operations, like other resource based companies which live and work in the global market. It has adopted a policy of across-the-board incremental improvements. It has pushed itself and continues to push the micro-reform agenda to win extra savings. Port costs have been cut with privatisation and other challenges remain in respect of rail freight costs and particularly so in labour productivity. The coal industry labour market is a real source of concern, and that cannot be concealed. It is a problem which will be made worse by the bill before the parliament.

The level of industrial disputation in the coal sector is still well above national averages. Back in 1988, the number of days lost to industrial dispute per 1,000 employees was—wait for it—15,548. It is now 2,970 per 1,000 employees. That is a great advance but still, when compared with the all-industry average of 158 days, it is appalling. Looked at in another way, the issue is even more sharply defined. The coalmining sector accounts for 0.3 per cent of the work force, but in 1991-92—one of its better industrial relations years—it accounted for 23 per cent of all industrial disputes.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—It was 0.3 per cent of the work force which accounted for 23 per cent of all industrial disputes. If honourable members wanted an example of the coal sector industrial relations system at work, all they needed to have done was follow last September's disastrous strike over BHP coal contract prices. The Coal Industry Tribunal was powerless to control the United Mine Workers. The union openly brushed aside the one-man tribunal. Before various companies took section 45D remedies, and before injunctions requiring a return to work were issued, five days of production were lost. If the government does not think something is inherently wrong with the coal industry's industrial relations system which allows such events to unfold, and if it thinks the current arrangement which keeps that system frozen out of the mainstream labour system is of a beneficial state to either employers or employees, the community is in a deeper economic malaise than it thinks.

PARA.TAB: Industrial disputation is one thing. Consider the wages bill across the industry. Average weekly earnings in the industry are twice that of the national average. It might interest honourable members to know that the average weekly earnings in the industry amount to $1,230—about $60,000 per year. Even more important from a coal industry productivity point of view, coal industry earnings have totally outstripped industry productivity growth. These sorts of trends kill off industries, and this trend has afflicted the coal industry for a very long time. All the industry asks is that, if its preferred devolutionary industrial relations model is unacceptable to the accord partners who framed the bill now before the House, its current antiquated industrial relations system be absorbed within the national system. This is important for the future of the industry. It is equally important for the security of employment within the industry and for future job growth.

As I said before, growth in traded volumes of coal will continue. A good prospect is that, if the industry can increase its across-the-board productivity, it can expand. But equally so, competition from low-cost coal suppliers is fierce, and there is every chance the industry could drop by the wayside unless improvements are forthcoming. Whatever its goodwill, the Coal Industry Tribunal can do nothing to lock in labour productivity growth in the industry. Its former companion in the New South Wales coal labour relations field, the Joint Coal Board, has virtually ceased its role as an arbiter in the state industrial relations system. Now the day has come for the Coal Industry Tribunal as well. This is not a partisan perspective either. The last three major studies of the coal industry—the Hancock report of 1983, the Niland report of 1989 and the Industry Commission study of 1991—have all recommended the Coal Industry Tribunal be abolished.

Keeping the industry's industrial relations arrangements out in the cold does not do those in the labour force any good in the long term. It isolates them from the realities of the open market, which will ultimately determine whether or not they or their children continue to work in the industry. It restricts the flexibility of individual companies to respond to market challenges and hold their export positions or win new contract opportunities. It entrenches old industrial practices we all thought went out with the restructuring of the waterfront.

There is even more than this that is of concern to the industry. The level of industrial disputation in the industry is already draining the industry of its profitability. But the bill before the House will exacerbate the problem even more. In so far as the bill is about weakening the 45D and 45E provisions of the Trade Practices Act, transferring them into the new Australian Industrial Relations Act and, from there, for the final effect, to the labour court, then the coal industry has been placed at risk.

In so far as the coal industry is outside of the government's industrial relations system, under the bill the industry will have to attempt appeals across jurisdictions to win even weakened protection against secondary boycotts or to exercise its due common law remedies. This will not only prove time consuming, a factor which is absolutely critical in responding to secondary boycotts, but it is also doubtful that the industry will have the administrative platform to gain access to the relocated sections 45D and 45E in the first place.

If this system had been in place at the time of last September's strike action, the industry could have been permanently incapacitated. Again, this all arises from the simple fact that the government has allowed a segmented, redundant industrial relations tribunal to run the coal industry into the ground. Yet again the industry may not believe what the government is doing in this bill is at all its preferred option, but if it can at least bring the coal sector's industrial relations arrangements in from out of the cold and link them with the national system, there is some hope for the industry. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Industrial Relations Reform Bill, one of the most important pieces of legislation that has been before this parliament for a considerable time. The government's reforms provide the framework for the further spread of enterprise bargaining throughout the Australian economy and they build on the reforms of the last decade. Previous speakers on the other side of the House, of course, continue to argue that we are introducing legislation which will not be effective. I think they need to look at their own operations in order to see whether their own procedures are effective in relation to how the Australian people judge their position. We continue to sit on the government benches, they continue to sit on the opposition benches, and I am absolutely convinced that industrial relations was one of the major issues in the last election and that the people clearly made the decision that they wanted a Labor government to introduce legislation on these issues.

PARA.TAB: The reforms allow Australian workplaces to implement cooperatively and constructively the changes needed to compete with the best companies in the world. The legislation provides employers with the flexibility they need to improve productivity and compete internationally, while recognising that employee protection is crucial to the success of enterprise bargaining. The legislation clearly distinguishes between the bargaining stream, where an increasing number of workplaces will determine their actual wages and conditions, and the arbitrated award safety net.

I would like to comment on the safety net issue. A safety net of wages and conditions and a number of other employee protections are a fundamental part of the total legislative package, designed to protect workers' living standards. This is the issue that we are discussing here tonight, which is so important to the Australian community. Employee protections are important on social justice grounds and crucial to the success of enterprise bargaining. They increase the level of trust and cooperation between workers and employers, thus strengthening the commitment of the work force to productivity improvement. They also encourage workplace negotiations to focus on sustainable productivity improvements, rather than on one-off cuts to workers' wages and conditions, as is espoused by our opponents.

Under the legislation, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission is charged with ensuring that the award system provides secure, relevant and consistent awards. When deciding whether awards are relevant and consistent, the government intends that the commission will consider the objects and statements of the legislative intent included in this legislation. The government intends that the award framework will be maintained as an effective safety net to underpin enterprise bargaining. When setting safety net increases in wages and conditions—for example, through test cases—the public interest will still be particularly important.

In providing for consistency across awards, the government intends that the commission will maintain stable and appropriate relationships between job classifications. A key element of the wage system since 1989 has been the development of a framework of consistent minimum rates awards. The legislation will reflect and reinforce the importance of maintaining this framework.

The legislation provides for paid rates awards to continue and be maintained in areas where employees' terms and conditions of employment have customarily been fixed in this way. However, if the integrity of such awards is not maintained, they will be able to be cancelled or varied appropriately. The government expects many parties on paid rates to progressively move to certified agreements.

The amendments are directed at making awards more streamlined and modern regulatory instruments. The commission must encourage the parties to awards to keep them up to date. Changes to legislation require the commission to review awards to make sure that they are simple, written in plain English and, where appropriate, meet the safety net requirements. This will assist in the removal of unnecessary and outdated provisions and allow for more flexibility in the application of awards and for keeping them up to date.

The commission will be encouraged to include enterprise flexibility clauses in each award. The award safety net will be extended by guaranteeing minimum entitlements to all workers—fair minimum wages, equal pay for work of equal value by men and women, rights to redundancy pay, protection against unfair dismissal and 12 months unpaid parental leave on a shared basis. The award safety net stream and the direct bargaining stream will be separately administered by the commission. The no disadvantage test that applies to certified agreements will continue to enable awards to act as benchmarks for certification and approval of agreements.

Enterprise bargaining is a very important part of the total package. The government's reform package supports fair and flexible enterprise bargaining, which promotes productivity and efficiency improvements at the workplace while protecting employees. Enterprise bargaining has already delivered significant benefits to Australia through improved productivity and a more cooperative workplace culture. These benefits have been clearly demonstrated in many areas of Australia and have proved more than evident in my electorate of McMillan.

Amcor, one of Australia's largest producers of paper products, and the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union, the CFMEU, have recently signed an enterprise agreement, a significant milestone and a first for the pulp and paper industry. So it can be done and it will be done within the structures that we are legislating for. That agreement is a positive result of cooperation between employers and employees and has been developed over a period of five or six years. A further welcome development in my electorate has seen our great industry, based on power generation, also move positively towards enterprise agreements, which are crucial to the future prosperity of the area, all done within the administrative structures and the regulations introduced by this government.

There are areas that have been of great concern and need to be reflected upon. The no disadvantage test, for instance, provides workplaces with the flexibility to implement innovative reforms, including a wide range of variations to award conditions, while protecting employees. To access agreements, employees' terms and conditions of employment must first be covered by an award. The award and the relevant legislation will be the benchmark for the no disadvantage test.

The new legislation builds on the existing certified agreement provisions. Requirements covering dispute resolution procedures and consultation are enhanced. A certified agreement may now contain a provision that enables it to be varied under circumstances and in a way defined in the agreement. This will give greater incentive for longer term agreements. On their expiry, certified agreements continue to apply indefinitely as awards unless another award or agreement is made or the agreement is cancelled.

The legislation provides new procedures for the variation of agreements after expiry. This will increase certainty and provide an incentive for the parties to negotiate further enterprise agreements. Enterprise flexibility agreements may be made directly between an employer and his or her employees. These provisions will use the corporations powers of the constitution. This makes them more widely accessible as the parties will not need to demonstrate an interstate industrial dispute.

In addition to the no disadvantage test, enterprise flexibility agreements contain safe-guards to ensure that employees are protected. In this way we can ensure that a majority of employees must approve it. If unions respondent to the relevant award have members at the workplace they must be given an opportunity to take part in negotiations and to be party to any ensuing agreement. If they do not have members at the workplace relevant unions party to the award must be given an opportunity to be heard when the application for approval of the agreement is before the commission. However, the unions will have no right of veto.

In recognition of the non-unionised employees, in that they may require further protection, the commission is able to refuse on public interest grounds to approve an agreement because of exceptional circumstances. Agreements are not to be taken to be contrary to the public interest merely because they are inconsistent with general principles established by the commission concerning awards. For enterprise flexibility agreements as well as certified agreements there must be no inducement or pressure on employees to leave a union, no discrimination on the ground of union membership, prohibition on dismissal or employment discrimination by reason only of refusing to agree to a proposed agreement.

This legislation is extremely important to the total future of Australia and I fully support it. Other areas of concern about the total structure of negotiations on employment and industrial relations relate to many of the issues at the moment which are extremely important to the development of Australia and investment in Australia.

We constantly hear opposition members in this House saying that, if wages could be reduced by some magical figure by abolishing the rights of workers, things would suddenly be okay. Mr Deputy Speaker, let me put to you a few other areas I believe are extremely important to the employment opportunities of Australians and the need for change.

The area that I represent in McMillan covers the Latrobe Valley which is one of the major energy generating areas in Australia. Just off the coast of the electorate of McMillan we have the major gas and oil reserves of Bass Strait. It is a crucial area of energy supply to Victoria and to the nation and, as such, will play an important part in the future development of the nation both nationally and internationally.

I continually hear our opponents in this House talking about the fault of the worker, the need to reduce workers' wages, that we cannot have laws guaranteeing minimum wage rates, and that it should be possible to negotiate wage rates down to a minimum. Those arguments are red herrings. I listened to the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), my next-door neighbour since his electorate is just outside the Latrobe Valley region. His electorate covers the rural sectors of Gippsland, while the electorate I represent covers the industrial area and part of the rural area. The honourable member continually talks about the need for workers to pay the price of industrial reform.

The big issue facing crucial areas of the nation, one of which I represent—I will continue to maintain this in every forum I possibly can—is that there are several areas of Australia today which have the capacity to compete with any area in the world. Any major investor that is looking to put a major manufacturing plant in our nation in preference to New Zealand or somewhere in South-East Asia need look no further than an area such as the Latrobe Valley. The one crucial factor that is missing is realistic pricing of our major products.

We produce the energy on which Victoria operates and we produce energy which goes into the national grid; but our region is expected to subsidise the rest of Victoria and the rest of Australia. That power cannot be bought any cheaper 500 yards from the power station than it is 500 miles away. Some 10 or 12 years ago a major energy using plant was established at Portland in the Western District of Victoria. For that period of time the Victorian taxpayers have been subsidising the transmission costs of generating power to that power plant to the tune of $1,000 million, simply because the plant was put by our political opponents in an area where there was no power or energy, and I could never work out the reason.

I have become absolutely convinced that we need to fight very hard now to ensure that the Latrobe Valley, the Hunter Valley, Gladstone in Queensland, perhaps Collie in Western Australia and other areas that have a natural advantage, are allowed to take advantage of that natural advantage. A major energy industry such as a smelter plant should not be located in an area like Portland in Victoria. It should be located right near the power station so that the power can be delivered at the cheapest possible price to enable that plant to be competitive.

If we do not develop these policies in the future those companies that wish to invest in this part of the world will certainly not invest in Australia. It is not the wages that are killing us. It is not this industrial relations issue. It is the basic fundamentals of cross-subsidies. There are no better operators of cross-subsidies in this parliament than members of the National Party of Australia. Due to the bargaining position it held in government over many years, the National Party has created situations in Australia where industry has been sadly disadvantaged for political purposes.

In 1984, 1985 and 1986, in my electorate we ripped apart the subsidy structures of the dairy industry. Today we see that industry responding very effectively to the market forces, and it is the most prosperous industry in the rural sector in Australia today. We need the same situation developed for power, energy, electricity and gas. The boards of national and international companies will not make the required decisions about where to place their substantial investments of $300 million, $400 million, $600 million and $800 million until we develop the policies that are required.

Industrial relations is not the key issue. The key issue is the elimination of the cross-subsidies that do not allow those areas of Australia which have the natural advantages to compete against our Asian competitors and attract the investment to Australia. So I am getting a little sick and tired of hearing our opponents on the other side constantly talking about the need in industrial relations to somehow reduce wages.

In its reports, the Industry Commission keeps coming up with the same theory. It does mention other issues of adjustment but it keeps on the same theme: if only wages could be adjusted this subsidy problem would be fixed. But that is not the answer. The answer lies in Australians realising that certain sectors of Australia have certain advantages through our natural resources which have to be put to use for the benefit of the nation. It means that if an area has a distinct advantage in where the supply of energy is derived from, that advantage should not be distorted by forcing the people in that region to pay the same price for that power as they would if they were 500 miles away, whether it be in Portland or Mildura.

They are the big issues we are debating now and the big issues that have to be fought through. Under the stewardship of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) as Treasurer, this government set about the restructuring of Australia. Some people at the moment are starting to believe that perhaps the restructuring is causing too many problems. But I would make this plea in this parliament—and I will continue to make it in the forums of the political party that I belong to—that now is not the time to back off. Now is the time to finish the job, not to attack the working people of the nation. It is time to attack the structural problems that we still have.

We have gone through transport and we have worked through the waterfront. The two big issues that are still to be delivered to the Australian economy are our energy pricing for electricity and gas. My ambition in this parliament for the next 12 months is to work in every possible way to see that the benefits that can accrue to the Australian community do accrue from our natural benefits and that we do not have the workers being asked to take lower wages simply because some people want to keep subsidies in place which should not be there. The natural market must be allowed to proceed.

I had the privilege of chairing the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs for a considerable number of years. I had the opportunity to work very hard to eliminate the problems in many areas of the rural sector. In my electorate the dairy industry has responded, but there are several that have not responded—
Mr Katter interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Party member has just arrived. In the fruit industry, for instance, SPC did well; Letona in New South Wales is still struggling under the old system. I am sure that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, would know about the orange industry on the Murray River. While many orange growers made the right moves to restructure, many have not and they are still paying the price because they are still in the old world.

PARA.TAB: I appeal to everybody in this House to recognise that the restructuring changes that have been put in place are important. We must finish the job. I represent an electorate which produces energy. The coastal electorate of the honourable member for Gippsland produces gas and oil. We must provide those products to industry at a price which will encourage the investment that is so important to Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993 would surely be one of the most disappointing pieces of legislation ever to be brought before the Commonwealth parliament. It was a much heralded item of legislation designed to reform a system which was much in need of repair. Unfortunately, despite much huffing and puffing by the Minister for Industrial Relations, the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton), the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the government and the ACTU, the industrial legislation before the parliament at present is woefully inadequate.

PARA.TAB: It proves beyond any measure of doubt that this Labor government is a government of the unions, by the unions, for the unions—or, put another way, a government of mates, by mates, for mates. The Keating government and the industrial relations minister are clearly the puppets of their trade union masters. The honourable member for Kingsford-Smith could face the same fate as his predecessor, Senator Peter Cook. Alan Wood of the Australian wrote on 24 August 1993:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook was a man of good, if strictly limited intentions who was brutally run over by the ACTU steamroller. Is the same about to happen to Laurie Brereton?
He went on:
Already one experienced unionist has privately described his job as `holding the phone while Keating talks to Bill'.

That really is the sum total of the history of this legislation. The minister said that certain things were going to happen. They have not happened. Every time he claimed that there was going to be needed reform in a certain area, we found intrusion from the ACTU and others. The result is that the legislation has been redrafted many times to accord with the wishes of the ACTU. This bill has been devised by the government and the ACTU. Employer organisations, small business and the little people of Australia have been excluded from discussions and are totally opposed to it.

PARA.TAB: This bill has nothing going for it. It purports, if one could believe the minister, to encourage enterprise bargaining. It claims to seek to guarantee minimum standards through reliance on various treaty obligations. It plans also to undermine the secondary boycott provisions and to create a new federal court, the industrial relations court of Australia. The reality is that this draconian piece of legislation actually reinforces the award system, prevents true flexibility and takes us back to the last century.

Every one of the 147 members of the House of Representatives and most people in Australia agree that there is an urgent need for reform of the industrial relations system. It is the most important remaining micro-economic reform. While there has been some deregulation in the economy, there is little chance of reduction in unemployment until we have reform in the labour market. There will be a continued high jobless rate and jobs and investment will be threatened.

We are not talking about slave labour. We are not talking about reduced wages, as suggested by the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham). Wages in Australia are already comparable to or lower than many similar countries. The problems are: on-costs, crazy work practices, redundancy payments, superannuation and the training guarantee levy. The list goes on and on. When they are added up, the result is that we are not as competitive as we should be.
This legislation is a lot of hot air. It is Clayton's reform. It is a total debacle. The minister's backflip is indeed quite shocking as he now marches to the tune of his union masters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I thank the honourable member for Kennedy. The government's proposals essentially are in three categories. They prop up the award system, denying real flexibility. They further misuse the external affairs power to enable the Industrial Relations Commission to set minimum entitlements for all workers. These include: minimum wages, equal pay, termination and unpaid parental leave. There is a massive extension of the commission's jurisdiction beyond the previous limitation of dealing only with disputes extending beyond the borders of one state. This legislation is designed to attack the much needed industrial relations reforms in Victoria and other places.

PARA.TAB: The bill seeks to use the external affairs power to enact minimum entitlements on pay and key conditions for workers not covered by federal awards. There is an attempt to involve the ILO in Australia. This government talks about independence; it talks about becoming a free nation. The reality of the situation is that it is subverting and surrendering our independence to international bodies. This was highlighted very well by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) only a short while ago.

The legislation seeks to tie Australian industrial laws to what the minister calls our treaty obligations as set out in the ILO conventions. This means that our labour market is hostage to the deliberations of this international organisation. For instance, all workers are guaranteed 12 months unpaid parental leave to be shared between both parents. Businesses will have to consider the hidden cost of hiring potential parents. Imagine what a nightmare that would be!

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially a Prime Minister.
—The Prime Minister has special rules for himself, particularly in relation to child care. In my view, the Prime Minister is not worthy of employment in that position.

PARA.TAB: Rules applying to termination of employment will be determined by the ILO convention with the new industrial relations court able to order reinstatement or other appropriate relief, including compensation, for employees dismissed in breach of that convention. Changes to the ILO rules covering termination arrangements will fall under Australia's treaty obligations.

There will be a threat to employment. The more obstacles that one puts in the place of employment, the more disadvantages one puts in front of employers, the more difficult it is for an employer to run his or her business and the less likely employers will be to put on staff. What we need at a time of one million people out of work, possibly two million people with inadequate work, is more jobs. There are absolutely no jobs contained in this legislation. The ILO conventions are supposed to be a safety net but they will raise wages and conditions when they offer more than an award. This means that Australia will become a social laboratory for the ILO.

I turn to enterprise bargaining—what a great fizzer! The intention of this government is not to have enterprise bargaining. The real intention of this government is to go on with the failed award system although the package purports to involve a new process whereby more people are able to have enterprise bargaining. The government, though, had earlier announced that it intended to strip the union movement of its monopoly in brokering enterprise deals.

TALK.START.PARA: —You never believed that, did you?

—I do not think anyone believed it. But the ACTU would not budge from its position. We have to look at the tremendous amount of support, financial and otherwise, given by the ACTU to the government in the election campaign. This government is now delivering back to the ACTU. It is buying off the ACTU. It is repaying a debt to the ACTU at the expense of the people—the employers and the employees of Australia.

PARA.TAB: Before an enterprise bargain can be adopted it must pass a public interest test. The deal must not result in an overall loss of entitlements for the work force.
