There can be no discrimination against union members, although there is no protection for non-union members, and unions have a right to argue against the certification of these agreements. This is despite the fact that the unions could well have absolutely no membership in the enterprise seeking the enterprise agreement. The insistence on the no disadvantage test is likely to keep most enterprise agreements merely as add-ons to the award. The overall result, the effect, is to render the new path to enterprise bargaining absolutely worthless. The involvement of unions will render proposals totally ineffective. That is dreadful. The government, if it were honest, would probably say that that was its intention.

The altered provisions mean that the push to accelerate our move from the arbitration system has now been abandoned. The government has dressed the legislation up in a lot of fancy, nice words, but the net result is that this government is encouraging a continuation of Australia's discredited industrial relations system. The enterprise flexibility agreements will not work because they will give unions too much involvement in the process. Small, non-unionised businesses will not risk drawing themselves to the unions' attention by seeking official ratification of the deals they have done with their workers. So the legislation will be ineffective.

I mentioned before that there is protection for unionists. No-one in the Liberal Party or in the National Party would say that a person should be prejudiced as a result of being a member of a union, but surely in a democratic society a person has a right to choose not to be a member of a union—

TALK.START.PARA: —And not be victimised.

—Quite correct. It will be very interesting to see whether the minister accepts the amendments to be moved by my colleague the honourable member for Bennelong. No reasonable person in Australia should say that compulsory unionism is acceptable. If a person does not wish to join a union, that ought to be that person's democratic right in the Australia of 1993.

PARA.TAB: The secondary boycott provisions really have been very successful. The Fraser government introduced them. The shadow minister for industrial relations, the honourable member for Bennelong, was responsible for the inclusion of those very important provisions in the law of Australia. That meant that unions were protected from lawless employers and employers were able to obtain protection from lawless unions. It was a fair situation. There was equality of treatment. There was equity. But the government is removing those provisions from the Trade Practices Act and putting them into the Industrial Relations Act—in other words, watering them down.

The government is also allowing a 72-hour delay before the provisions can be accessed. The reason is that unions want special deals. Many small businesses will not stay in business if they have to wait 72 hours before the new provisions are available. It is a tragedy. Instead of moving in the right direction, we are now moving in the wrong direction. The unions claimed that it was necessary to curb the legal remedies because of their interference—or alleged interference—with the rights of workers to withdraw their labour in pursuit of industrial objectives. In a civilised society we should all be held responsible for the consequences of our actions. If we do something resulting in another person sustaining a financial loss, then we would be sued, as we should be, in the ordinary courts of the land, because a citizen ought to have redress in the ordinary courts when the law is broken. But, sadly, the government wants to remove these secondary boycott provisions from the ordinary courts and pass them over to a kangaroo court—the new industrial relations court that will be set up at very great expense. It is a very unnecessary change.

The unions want special deals and they know the ordinary law will not apply in the industrial relations court. It is very likely that the government will appoint many of its union cronies to the Industrial Relations Commission with the result that there will be travesties of justice. It will be criminal if ordinary businesses, ordinary employers and ordinary people are not able to have redress in the ordinary courts of the land. I get very suspicious when people are denied access to the ordinary courts. When these specialist tribunals, operating on a dubious basis, are set up justice may well not be seen to be done. That is a matter which I worry about, and I believe my colleagues and the nation share my concern.

The legislation before the House dashes the very real hopes offered by the Prime Minister when a number of months ago he sought in a speech to the Institute of Directors to unveil the model of industrial relations. He said that we were working towards a situation where awards and arbitration would diminish in importance and where enterprise agreements would not be mere add-ons to awards but full substitutes for awards, which means that they would have to spread to non-unionised workers.

The legislation is a sad disappointment. Originally it may well have been the government's intention to bring in legislation as the Prime Minister suggested. However, he had not taken into account the fact that the ACTU would call for payment of its election debt. As surely as night follows day, we found the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industrial Relations reacting to the dictates of the ACTU, and therefore this particularly useless piece of legislation being brought into the parliament. It does not move in the right direction; it moves in the wrong direction.

As I said earlier, the legislation is simply an indication that the Labor government is a government of the unions, by the unions, for the unions. This legislation is a complete and utter sell-out to the ACTU. It waters down the ban on secondary boycotts; it legislates for a right to strike; it protects unions against actions for damages under the common law; and it establishes a separate labour court. It is a payback to the ACTU for its election support. I am not suggesting that all unions are bad. Of course, unions are not bad. I believe that many unions seek to do the right thing by their members, but justice must not only be done but be seen to be done.

This legislation before the House is a travesty of justice. People will lose confidence in the system that the government is setting up because it simply does nothing for real reform. It sets in concrete a hybrid system somewhere between a centralised and decentralised system and somewhere between a regulated and deregulated system. It is neither fish nor fowl; it is a complete failure.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's f-o-u-l.

—Yes, it is certainly foul. The government stands condemned for the legislation before the House at the moment. The government has failed to carry forward its election commitments. The government has sold out to the unions. I believe that the people of Australia will react very strongly at the next election because this legislation fails to deliver any benefits and particularly fails to offer any hope for the unemployed on Labor's dole queues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to enter the debate and to support the government's Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993, coming as it does after an election campaign in which industrial relations was one of the key issues before the people. One of the difficulties with debates of this sort in the chamber is that too many people on the opposition benches are stuck in a time warp.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper), who has just spoken, is clearly one of those. His opening tirade of rhetoric really stemmed from the good old 1960s and 1970s knee-jerk reaction when employers and employees thought they had to stand toe to toe and slug it out until one of them fell over. That sort of 1960s and 1970s mentality which seems to permeate through some of the members of the opposition benches has been reflected in some of the contributions in the debate on this bill.

It may well be that the honourable member for Fisher has lapsed into his old clothes—the old Queensland National Party clothes—that he was once proud to wear. The Queensland National Party government was fairly well renowned for its performance in industrial relations, the protection of civil liberties and the protection of the rights of individuals—a National Party of which at that time the honourable member for Fisher was proud to be a member.

Of course, he has rather changed his suit these days; he has decided that the Liberal Party has a better chance of winning the seat in the growing urban areas of northern Brisbane. He is now a Liberally minded person, having shaken off those terrible shackles of the National Party days in Queensland. But it seems to me that he lapsed into a bit of that 1960s, 1970s conservative rhetoric as he tried to launch an attack on this bill. It really was a string of outdated cliches.

It is about time we exploded some of those outdated myths. Anyone who has followed closely the industrial relations situation in the last decade would know only too well the changing culture and the changing attitude amongst all practitioners on both sides of the arbitration table, on both sides of the negotiation table. Increasingly, it has been a negotiating table rather than an arbitration table.

I would commend to people on the other side of the House the sorts of comments that have been made by people involved in private business. In a number of industries, firms—some of which were renowned for having very poor industrial relations—are now participating in the best practice demonstration program. In the space of five years they have turned their problems around to now be regarded as being at the forefront. I think of companies like Goninan, a major metal fabrication shop which was renowned for difficult industrial relations in the 1970s and early 1980s. It is now regarded as one of the model metal shops in the country, a metal shop that has been transformed by agreements at the workshop floor level between employees and employers with unions involved.

I can recall before the last election addressing an industrial relations seminar in the Hunter Valley where there were representatives from Goninan present—management, workers and unions. The management, workers and union proudly stood there together to tell all of the participants—a mixed audience, some employers, some employees—of their turnaround in that company and the turnaround in their attitudes. That turnaround, the management at that seminar acknowledged, could not have occurred without the involvement of the union and, in fact, the union had been the catalyst for that dramatic change.

That is the sort of difference that industrial relations and good management is about in the 1990s. It is the sort of transformation which this government has been seriously putting in place over the last decade. It is lamentable that in industrial relations debates of this sort members of the opposition want to lapse into their 1960s and 1970s rhetoric and try to find new reds under the bed.

There are indeed some members of the opposition—and the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) is clearly one of them—who have followed the debate closely. I think that in his more earnest moments at night by himself he actually believes that what I say is true, even if it may not be the best line for him to run for his own purposes.

Let me turn to some of the key points of the bill before the parliament. The bill seeks to establish a new stream for enterprise agreements for establishing a basis of remuneration for workers in Australia. It differs markedly from the sort of enterprise agreement which was before the people as opposition policy at the last election. Our stream of enterprise bargaining included in this legislation is underpinned by an award system, a guarantee to all workers that they will not be exploited, that there will be a safety net of an award applying before an employer can decide to go off and seek to establish an enterprise agreement. Lamentably, there are still some employers who would seek to exploit their employees to the full extent of their opportunities rather than according to what might be reasonable.

This bill establishes a new stream underpinned by awards. It provides a number of safeguards for employees as well as opportunities for both employees and employers. In those enterprises in which there are some union members, those union members are entitled, as of right in this bill, to have their union representatives involved in the negotiations. And so they should be.

An employer who does not wish to discuss a condition of employment for union members with the union's representative is clearly not of a mind to strike a fair and reasonable bargain. The situation of an enterprise with no union members is also addressed in the bill. In those circumstances it is possible for the employer to negotiate an agreement directly with the employees. However, those agreements, whether they be in a unionised shop or a non-unionised shop, are required to be submitted to the commission for approval and scrutiny—and that is a proper and appropriate course to follow in a civilised society determined to ensure that there is equity and justice in the way in which people are treated.

At the bottom of the line, that is what we are talking about in industrial relations—the way in which people are treated in their work environment. That is a matter that should properly be the subject of some scrutiny by an independent body. It should not be a secret matter. It should not be the sort of secret enterprise agreement that the National Party in Queensland established some years ago under the Bjelke-Petersen government which was designed and promoted in an effort to reduce conditions of employment for workers and was then kept secret from all concerned. These documents under this legislation will be public documents, they will be open to scrutiny, and that is wholly appropriate.

Registered unions of employees and registered unions of employers that are party to the award in this industry will have the right to appear before the commission and will have the right to scrutinise the document to ensure that it is fair and reasonable and that it does not contravene the provisions of the act. The commission is required to take into account a number of things in determining whether or not to endorse the enterprise agreement under this new stream. The commission must be satisfied that there is no disadvantage as a whole to the benefits for those employees. The commission must be satisfied that there has been informed agreement of a majority of the workers to the proposal and additionally that there are no penalties for union members. In other words, as has happened in some other places, people cannot be put on differential pay rates; that is, a person in the union will not get paid less money than if he or she was not in the union. Those sorts of discriminatory actions are prohibited in the bill.

This bill provides flexibility and opportunities for employers, employees and unions to negotiate any variation in the conditions, provided the sum total of the variations does not push the conditions of those workers down. So we can have lateral changes and changes that improve the total package but we cannot have a change that pushes the total package down. That is the fundamental difference between the view on this side of the parliament and that on the opposition benches.

There is no union veto in the process. I have heard a couple of speakers in this debate refer to the union veto. It is simply not there. It is absolute, patent nonsense. It is not in the bill; it is not in the new procedure. Anybody who wants to go and talk to union officials that have scrutinised the bill will know only too well that it is not in the bill. It is simply a furphy and those opposite should remove it from their repertoire in this debate.

Let us have a look at what the opposition's policy on this matter has been—not that there have been too many pronouncements on industrial relations or, for that matter, on any other area of policy since the election. The last time the opposition sought to make some statements about industrial relations, it was committed to individual contracts—not group enterprise agreements but individual contracts, one on one—with no right of representation, no protection for the workers. In fact, there was not even a right to go to the Industrial Relations Commission. Under the Fightback program that the opposition took to the people earlier this year, it denied workers access to the commission unless the employer agreed. That was its proposal; that is its brand of fairness.

Yet those opposite have the hypocrisy to stand here and try to attack the government for introducing a bill which enshrines the rights of workers, whether or not they be in a union, to have their conditions fairly assessed by the Industrial Relations Commission. Of course, when it comes to industrial relations, we have the social laboratory of Victoria to give us some idea of what opposition policy would be in the federal sphere if those opposite had the opportunity.

The Victorian industrial relations policy, I was disappointed to see, was actually endorsed by the opposition. The opposition spokesperson for industrial relations, the honourable member for Bennelong, was at the National Press Club in October last year talking about this; it was the week after the Victorian state election. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the election of a Liberal government in Victoria last Saturday . . . is a very significant development.
At that stage he was assuming that Australia would get a federal Liberal government to go with the newly elected Liberal state government in Victoria. He further said:
. . . you will have governments sharing identical views, give or take a comma here or there, identical views on industrial relations.

They are the words of the honourable member for Bennelong in October of last year, following the election of the Kennett government—a clear commitment that the policy of those opposite would do to Australia in industrial relations terms what Kennett's policy has done in Victoria.

PARA.TAB: Those opposite keep talking in this and other debates about freedom of choice. Let me tell those opposite: we are going to provide a freedom of choice in systems. When this bill goes through, the people of Victoria will actually have a choice. If they think that Jeff Kennett's industrial relations package is as flash as those opposite seem to think it is, they will be quite happy to ignore this and stay with it. No-one is telling them they have to come under this new umbrella; they do not have to do that. But I tell you what: I would lay good money down on the table that that is exactly what the workers of Victoria will do; they will vote with their feet and leave the sort of draconian divisive industrial relations system which the policies of those opposite have generated in Victoria, and they will move in their hordes to federal awards to get coverage in this new enterprise agreement stream.

Of course, the Queensland National Party, for its part, made no secret of its policy a year or so ago. Last year, before the last election, the Queensland Nationals released a policy in which they were going to abolish the Queensland State Industrial Commission. So I wonder what the honourable member for Fisher or the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter), who were in the chamber a little while ago, would think about that attitude from their own—I should not say `their own' in the case of the honourable member for Fisher; but from the National Party in Queensland—policy to abolish the Industrial Relations Commission: `Don't muck around with it; just get rid of it. Get it out of the way'. That is the sort of position which those opposite have been proud to support.

I have mentioned on previous occasions the exploits of Troubleshooters Available; it is a fairly renowned outfit. A fellow called Graeme Haycroft is its chief operator. It is an organisation which has been publicly supported by the honourable member for Bennelong and also by the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), in a video that the National Farmers Federation put out. In that video, they extolled the virtues of the Troubleshooters organisation. This Troubleshooters organisation in 1992 put out what it called a Synopsis of labour-hire contracting system. Under the heading, `What are the savings to employers?', it said:

SPEECH.PARA: The employer no longer has to worry about:
1. penalty rates . . .

Those opposite tell me they are not interested in reducing conditions of employment, but the opposition spokesperson on industrial relations and the shadow Attorney-General are on a public video endorsing this organisation which says in black and white, `If you tie in with us, you don't have to worry about penalty rates, the training guarantee levy, workers compensation, union superannuation, payroll tax, holiday pay, long service leave, sick leave, redundancy pay, group tax, and stupid union rules'. It will do away with holiday pay. It will get rid of long service leave; people should not have that. It will do away with sick leave. This is another thing that has been endorsed by the opposition spokesperson on industrial relations. Then it cites a few of these so-called stupid union rules: things like preference, seniority and maternity leave. Well, that is a pretty silly old rule, is it not: maternity leave; the thought that when a woman is pregnant she should actually get some leave.

PARA.TAB: I wondered what the honourable member for Fisher was proposing when he was complaining about the minimum conditions we are inserting in this bill which provide for parental leave. What is he suggesting? Is he supporting the sort of Troubleshooters program so that, if women have children, they just lose their job? `No more work for you; we can't afford to employ you. The penalty for being pregnant is the sack!' That sounds pretty bizarre at the best of times.

We should remind ourselves that it was only 20 years ago—not a long time ago—that that was the practice followed by major employers, including governments, around this country. If a woman employed in the public service became pregnant she lost her job—end of story. Is that the sort of position the honourable member for Fisher is promoting? It is certainly the position which Troubleshooters is promoting—and Troubleshooters has been publicly endorsed by the opposition spokespeople on industrial relations. Of course, we would then do away with paternity leave as well—if we do away with maternity leave we might as well do away with paternity leave into the bargain. So it goes on. We would not have to worry about unfair dismissals either if we were to go down the Troubleshooters track.

That is the sort of industrial relations outcome that the opposition has supported publicly on the record. When opposition members tell us that they are really not about pushing wages down but are really about freedom and the rights of the individual, no-one believes them. The people of Australia did not believe them at the last election either. Any doubt about these sorts of things was cleared up some time ago when the shadow spokesperson on industrial relations, the honourable member for Bennelong, made it quite plain that he thought we should increase the hours of work. He actually argued that the government should be making an application to the industrial commission to increase the standard number of hours worked to 40 hours. Then, by some strange twist of logic, he said that increasing the number of hours that existing employees worked without increasing their pay was going to improve the employment position.

There are no magic criteria or results which hang off a particular system. It is people who make the system work. This government has been about getting people together in a cooperative way in the area of industrial relations in order to produce results for them and for the nation. If there is any doubt about that, I refer to an article on this topic written by Ross Gittins—who is probably not a great friend of the government—a couple of years ago. He wrote:

Japan has company bargaining and an amazingly good productivity record. America has company bargaining, but a record on productivity growth that's worse than ours. Germany has an enviable productivity record, but a system of centralised collective bargaining.

SPEECH.PARA: Those opposite who want to paint a picture which says that individual contracts or free bargaining situations produce greater productivity, fly in the face of the facts and the experiences of countries around the world. They should strip away that sort of sham.

PARA.TAB: In the minute remaining, I will quickly mention some of the minimum conditions that we are including in this bill using our foreign affairs powers. There is a minimum wage for all Australians—as there should be. Using ILO convention 100, we are providing, by law, equal pay for equal work. There will be no discrimination on the basis of sex, and nor should there be. There is protection against unfair dismissal. Parental leave of up to 52 weeks will be, by law, a right for all Australians—and I am pleased to say that this includes parents adopting children.

This is a fine bill which enhances the reforms in industrial relations that this government has been about over the last decade. It enhances the opportunities and rights of both workers and employers to change their working arrangements and to enter into new, agreed conditions, but to do this on a fair and equitable basis. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is very appropriate that we are addressing tonight the issue of enterprise bargaining and the new Industrial Relations Reform Bill. The honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) is, of course, misguided in his understanding of enterprise agreements and what they really mean.

PARA.TAB: I draw the attention of the House to the fact that today Neil Brown launched his book, entitled On the Other Hand, in the presence of the Governor-General. In that book he draws on his experiences as the shadow industrial relations spokesman, including the drawing up of the enterprise agreements policy in 1985 together with the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). I had the honour of being the chairman of the backbench committee during those years when enterprise agreements were the source of great argument in this parliament, amongst the industrial relations club and amongst all those practitioners of industrial relations—the union movement and the employers.

I pay tribute to the foresight of the honourable member for Bennelong and Neil Brown in developing those arguments and changing the culture of industrial relations in Australia forever. For the first time in some 90 years there was an attitude that we could move away from the award system and that at the enterprise level agreements could be reached between management and the work force to increase productivity, to increase job satisfaction and, in an all-round sense, to improve the productivity of Australia.

I draw the attention of the House to a couple of those examples. In the case of the ICI Botany plant, which is well documented, enterprise agreements were entered into and annualised salaries replaced overtime arrangements, shift premiums and penalty rates. Employees were put into semi-autonomous teams to provide shift cover in the case of absence. Performance and productivity measures were included. There was a strong commitment to skills formation. That was the basis of the enterprise agreement. There was an arrangement between the work force and the company to make these changes. The Botany plant, as the honourable member for Brisbane would understand, had a long history of difficulties in the labour relations area.

Likewise, in the Alcoa plant in Victoria in recent times the management negotiated with the work force to come up with an arrangement whereby the working week was increased to 40 hours from 38, but the working week was three or four days, according to the shift pattern. In that factory the work force was prepared to adapt to a set of arrangements that were compatible with their lifestyle and with the production of aluminium from that plant.

At a time when the world moves to a more decentralised model, this government is centralising the power of the industrial relations agreements and the power of the trade union movement. The government is entrenching the power of that group at a time when everyone around the world has agreed that the focus should be at the enterprise level and that that is the way to increase productivity and increase employment opportunities. At a time when, under this government, we have 11.2 per cent unemployment, or 982,000 persons unemployed, we have these sets of industrial relations arrangements in place. America, where there is a more flexible arrangement, has seven per cent unemployment.

The Prime Minister was very supportive of industrial enterprise agreements. In the One Nation statement of February 1992 he supported the culture, the attitude and the general approach of the Fightback programs and the industrial relations approach of the coalition over the last five years. The One Nation statement says:

The focus of reform has now shifted from the industry and award level to the individual workplace to generate the productivity gains necessary for Australia to reap . . . the full benefits from the general market liberalisation, structural adjustment and other micro-economic reforms.

SPEECH.PARA: It goes on to say that workplace bargaining provides clear and direct incentives for parties to seek out and share the maximum possible productivity gains. He goes on in that particular document to support the general thesis of enterprise bargaining. He reiterated his position at the Institute of Directors in April 1993 with a fairly important speech expressing similar sentiments.

PARA.TAB: I would like to draw the attention of the House to the draft report by the Industry Commission Impediments to regional industry adjustment. This draft report was brought down on 20 September 1993. It looked at regional Australia and at some of the elements that might improve job opportunities. It looked at the process of regional adjustment, regional labour costs, regional mobility of labour, labour retraining, land capital adjustment services, regional industry adjustment, infrastructure and regional ramifications of financial relations between governments. The key recommendation in the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The commission considers that greater recognition needs to be given to the particular conditions faced by workplaces in different regions when enterprise bargaining is undertaken. This would be best achieved under a system with:

PARA.TAB: no restrictions on the terms and conditions covered by enterprise agreements other than general minimum employment standards . . .
freedom for employees to choose who may negotiate on their behalf at the workplace.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a quite clear and strong recommendation that there be enterprise agreements organised between the workers and their management. I am sure that honourable members and people concerned about industrial relations will be interested in the well-known example of SPC based at Shepparton, which is mentioned in the same publication. In that enterprise agreement, which saved the financial future of that company, the following 11 points were agreed to between the work force and the management. These points made a number of changes in the way in which that company operated.

PARA.TAB: First, they removed the four rostered days off for all employees during the harvest season of January to April 1991. Second, they suspended weekend penalty rates. Third, they applied sick leave provisions for the metal industry award to seasonal employees covered by the Food Preservers Union. Fourth, they removed crib and meal allowances. Fifth, they reduced afternoon shift loading to 15 per cent. Sixth, they removed additional rest breaks. Seventh, they removed over-award payment to seasonal workers. Eighth, they required electronic funds transfer for all employees. Ninth, they required supervisory staff to perform hands-on work as required. Tenth, they removed the holiday loading of 17 per cent for staff not covered by industrial awards. Eleventh, they required staff to work 10 Saturdays or Sundays. These arrangements were supported by 93 per cent of the work force. Those changes in conditions had a very big impact on the profitability of the company, the wage structure, the on-costs and the work practice.

We have examples of what enterprise bargaining has achieved in the workplace and now we have a bill before this parliament which has horrendous implications. Whilst the government and the government's spokesmen—through rhetoric—support the opposition's position on enterprise agreements, the reality is that this bill will create some considerable problems once it is passed. Let us look at the external affairs power. This parliament and this nation will be forever more guided—if I can put it that way—by the terms and conditions laid down by the International Labour Organisation that is based in Geneva. Anyone in this House, and anyone with an understanding of that organisation, would know that some of the resolutions and activities of the ILO leave a lot to be desired. Some of the countries advocating certain minimum standards in their own backyards are not any great example, especially for Australia. They have put up the minimum conditions of equal pay for equal work—which is the sort of thing that is now happening in Australia—and special conditions surrounding the termination of employment.

I raise the whole issue of the ILO. Who sets the standards? Who would allow it to apply these standards to the Australian set of conditions? At least the arbitration commission was historically an Australian institution which set basic wage conditions emanating from this parliament and from a lot of ongoing discussion about wages, terms and conditions. The sovereignty of this parliament and this nation has been overruled by the activities of the ILO. As an employer of labour, I know that it is only too easy to put a person on the payroll, but much more difficult to terminate his or her employment if times get tough or there is a change of arrangements. All companies have a similar problem.

There is a proposition that if there are 15 or more employees in a company then the company has to go into dialogue with the union and the CES and have a long discussion about any termination arrangements for its employees for bona fide reasons. Does it encourage employment opportunities throughout Australia if people know that at the end of the day in a change of economic circumstances they will have to almost get permission to lay people off because of economics?

As I have indicated, enterprise agreements are the way to go in the change of culture. The break-out in wages in 1974-75 and 1981-82 under a centralised wage fixing system was the basis of a leapfrogging arrangement of over-award payments. This House and everyone who is interested in industrial relations should fully understand that enterprise agreements should be based on the new environment that we face in Australia after the deregulation of the Australian dollar in 1983 and that labour rates in Australia, plus their oncosts, are now comparable to those of other industrialised nations. No longer can we hide behind the excuse that we are insular and we are different. Wages, like other costs in the manufacturing of products, affect whether or not we have internationally competitive structures.

We talk about achieving enterprise flexibility agreements—an interesting set of words. Under the proposal of the shadow minister for industrial relations, the honourable member for Bennelong, enterprise agreements were quite easy to set up. On the one hand, the boss had a talk to his personnel on the shop floor and they came to personalised arrangements. As the shadow minister has gone to great pains to demonstrate to honourable members opposite, that was the fundamental arrangement.

Under this bill, anyone setting up an enterprise flexibility agreement—that little word `flexibility' is included just to try to persuade the world that it is more flexible than it really is—has 13 hurdles to jump to get it in place.In the first case, parties must establish respondency to a federal award. In an enterprise agreement, some part of the outfit must respond to some part of the federal award. Secondly, parties must comply with the award system safety net; that is, a basic wage in terms and conditions. We have no problem with that.

Thirdly, parties must comply with the new legislated minimum standards based on International Labour Organisation conventions and recommendations. We totally reject the proposition that some organisation in Geneva can set the terms and conditions in Melbourne, Sydney, Marble Bar or Perth. That is an outrageous proposition that will not stand up in this parliament or in any state parliament.

The fourth step is that parties must comply with the bargaining-in-good-faith directives of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. What does that mean? An enterprise agreement in which the Australian Industrial Relations Commission will give a directive of good faith. The fifth step is that agreements must comply with the public interest test. I challenge the government to define what `public interest' really means. That in itself creates a legal conundrum about what public interest means in the Australian context and within the Australian setting of this bill.

The seventh step is that the agreement must comply with the no disadvantage test. That is an interesting set of words. What that really means is that any agreement made in regional Australia—as I indicated, referring to the Industry Commission report—must not interfere with any existing award arrangements. So there can be no flexibility and there can be no change; there can just be an ongoing domination by the award union arrangements.

The eighth step is that unions which do not have any members at the particular workplace but which are respondents to the applicable federal award must be notified and given the opportunity to argue against approval of the agreement by the Industrial Relations Commission. So unions which have nothing to do with the particular workplace must be informed. They have a say in it. Even if the agreement has been directly reached between employees and management, the unions are still able to have a say in it.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I draw your attention to the interesting example at Bondswear in Taree. A vast majority of the clothing plant's 60 employees agreed in a secret ballot that a new workplace agreement which reduced penalty rates but compensated them in other ways would help save their jobs. The union would not agree with that but, inevitably, it was persuaded that it should be allowed. The union wanted to interfere. That was a well-known case.

The 10th step is that the IRC must be satisfied that all employees to be covered by the agreement have been properly informed about the agreement. Again the union movement is interfering with this enterprise agreement. The 11th step is that it must be established that a majority of the employees to be covered by the agreement generally consent to the agreement. Again we have the union making sure of these preconditions.

The 12th step says that it must be established that there has been no pressure exerted on or inducement extended to any employee to leave a union. That is all very well, but what about the very important proposition that the bill is silent about—the right not to join a union. The shadow minister at the table made a very strong case about the ability of workers not to join a union and to be free from coercion.

Even if all these 12 hurdles were cleared, the agreement could still be subjected to an Industrial Relations Commission review if it were thought to be operating unfairly. So we have a situation where the so-called enterprise agreements are subject to all these conditions by a union movement which is in a very powerful position. On 17 October 1993 the Business Council of Australia was very upfront about its view when it was talking about an urgent need to free up competitive forces in the Australian economy. In a section of its press release the Business Council of Australia had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, we need to come to grips with real reform of our labour market. The third report of the Employee Relations Study Commission `Working Relations' sets out a practical path to improved competition within the labour market through facilitating genuine and effective enterprise bargaining as the primary vehicle for introducing workplace change and wage rate increases.

That is the view of the Business Council of Australia about genuine enterprise agreements. I move on to a couple of other very important matters in this bill. I refer to the matter of secondary boycotts in sections 45D and 45E. In 1977 the shadow minister at the table was instrumental in introducing this measure. It has been most helpful in bringing to heel some of those rogue unions which, on occasions, wanted to use strongarm tactics. The threat of action against secondary boycotts through the use of section 45D has been a very important feature in maintaining some sense and balance within the trade union movement. The threat of real common law action has been used successfully in some of the more outrageous secondary boycotts by the union movement, such as in the case of Mudginberri.

PARA.TAB: We have a lot of concern about the 72-hour breathing period. If there is substantial injustice, there is the hope that the Industrial Relations Commission may help. With regard to the size of unions, we have a remarkable turnaround by the government. The government was advocating mega-unions of 10,000 members or more; now it is happy to advocate union membership of 100.

This bill entrenches union power and has ILO conventions as minimum standards. It is a 200-page bill of very complex industrial law. It places the unions in an uneven position compared with the employers. I support the foreshadowed amendment to be moved by the shadow minister that the bill should contain the right not to join a trade union if a worker so desires.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lee) adjourned.
Motion (by Mr Lee) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today there was a remarkable situation inasmuch as people from around Australia met in the council of the National Farmers Federation for the purpose of considering various matters, and one of those was the Mabo legislation. Mr Blight and Mr Rick Farley informed us from a national perspective. They have issued a news release which is headed `NFF Supports the Mabo Package'. Since we have had some comment about this matter in this House today, it might be a good idea to state exactly the NFF resolution, which was said to be unanimous. It decided:

PARA.TAB: (a)A national response to resolving Mabo issues is desirable.

SPEECH.PARA: That could hardly be said to be absolute support for the Keating government proposition. It goes on:

PARA.TAB: (b)Complementary Commonwealth/State/Territory legislation to validate existing title is desirable.

SPEECH.PARA: That of course is not the case. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has made it very clear that he intends to trample all over what Western Australia thinks is a necessary solution. It further states:

PARA.TAB: (c)Existing title must be validated as a matter of urgency.

SPEECH.PARA: I must state the view that I think when the Commonwealth legislation gets before the High Court, as it will, the major issue will be whether the Commonwealth has ever had the power to validate someone's land title. Of course, the Prime Minister has told us in this place that he cannot really validate valid title and that, of course, in the normal processes of the law it could be subject to legal claim. The NFF resolution continues:

PARA.TAB: (d)There should be no revival of native title on the expiry of a pastoral lease.

SPEECH.PARA: That has been mentioned in the legislation, but it is not exactly true either. Further, it says:

PARA.TAB: (e)There should be no exposure to any compensation claim by landholders with existing title.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not know exactly what that will be, but we do know that in the legislation persons can be called upon to pay compensation. It continues:

PARA.TAB: (f)Legal costs of landholders joined in Mabo claims should be met by the Crown (Commonwealth or State).

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation of course does not provide for that but provides that the Attorney-General may, considering the circumstances of the defendant, do so. Mr Farley tried to convince me personally that he had a letter from the Prime Minister guaranteeing that such funding would be available. I would like to see the Prime Minister say that. In fact, Mr Farley himself started to duck and dive on that issue in the end and argue that the only real promise it had of that was that it would have one person on the committee deciding whether people who are subject to these claims and have to use their own resources might get government help. Finally it states:

PARA.TAB: (g)Normal State/Territory laws in relation to land management must apply to native title land and native title equivalent.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the legislation allows for that. They are the grounds on which Mr Farley, a paid executive officer of the NFF, and his boss, the rice grower Graham Blight, give themselves the right to say that the NFF supports the Mabo package. It is an outrageous statement. Of course, it has severely embarrassed the representatives from Western Australia, who are very supportive of the Court legislation, are very much opposed to the Keating legislation and who did no more than agree to those motherhood statements, if you like. It gave no authority, in my view, for Mr Farley or Mr Blight to make the claims they have.

PARA.TAB: Let me add to that. In questioning I have established beyond doubt that during the whole intense period of the negotiations there was no formal meeting of the NFF Aboriginal affairs committee. Its chairman was overseas for a substantial period of it and the NFF has become a joke.

I am writing to all my constituent bodies in the only completely rural electorate left in Australia advising that there is no further advantage in being a paid-up member of the NFF. I will work assiduously to see that the Western Australian branches remove themselves from this organisation, which has become just a tool of Canberra and no longer represents the people.

If I had longer, I would give other lengthy examples of where the NFF has failed people such as wheat growers—sold them out on the guaranteed minimum price so it could get a two per cent levy on wheat. These are the problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to deal with two matters relating to the topic of war. Firstly, I would just like to correct a couple of points from the speech I made in the adjournment debate on 18 August of this year with respect to the massacre of Australian troops on the island of Ambon in 1942. In that speech I stated the names of Japanese soldiers. I stated the family names second, in the English style rather than in the Japanese style. I also stated that Hatakeyama Kunito and Nakagowa Kenichi were sentenced to 20 years gaol on 14 July 1947 and 17 July 1947 respectively. In fact, they were tried together between these two dates and sentenced on the latter date together. I add one other point; that is, that Yamashita Kyusuke was involved in two trials—one on 7 August 1950 and one on 8 September 1950—and was sentenced to 20 years imprisonment.

PARA.TAB: I wish to refer now to a more contemporary matter, the very serious problem of the remaining mines in Cambodia—another tragic situation arising from warfare in our region. The United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia is in the process of withdrawing from that country after the elections. It is estimated that there are 10 million anti-personnel mines in Cambodia. The approach of the United Nations to dealing with this problem was to train Cambodian deminers. Over 2,000 people have been trained, approximately 40 demining teams being put into the field. It is acknowledged that roughly another two years is required for the management supervision of those demining teams.

There is now a serious risk that the process of demining Cambodia will not continue with the same degree of effort that was envisaged, and that the people employed by the Cambodian Mine Action Centre will be laid off because of a lack of funding. As is well known, the mines maim and kill up to 300 people per month. Cambodia has the highest proportion of amputees in the world. There are also indirect economic consequences arising from problems associated with access to land, because of the lack of knowledge about the presence of mines and the obvious risk to people caused by the widespread presence of mines in many rural areas.

The United Kingdom based Mines Advisory Group has indicated that without a solution to the problem of widespread mine presence in Cambodia, long-term economic development in that country is not feasible. This problem is yet another classic and tragic illustration of the difficulties the international arms trade causes for underdeveloped countries, including some countries in our region, and how massive tragedy has been fuelled by the contest between the wealthy Western nations to sell weapons of mass destruction and slaughter to underdeveloped countries. It also shows how the struggling economies in many of these areas are further distorted by the competing power groups involved devoting more and more of their limited resources and output to the purchase of arms. I urge honourable members on both sides of the House to give urgent consideration to the role Australia can continue to play in the limitation of the production and export of arms throughout the world.

It is quite clear, whether we look at the Iran-Iraq war or at the more recent conflicts in continents such as Africa, Asia and Central America, that these conflicts have been seriously exacerbated by the fact that major weapons of mass destruction are made available as a result of intense competition between Western manufacturers of those arms. The end result of that process is an even greater degree of tragedy, slaughter and misery for the populations of the countries involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knott Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to read into Hansard a media report from a prominent British newspaper headed `The privatisation dream that got lost in the post'. The article reads:

With only the Parcel-Force service designated for sell-off so far, both the Royal Mail and Post Office Counters look set to stay in the public sector.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 7 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is he able to say whether the statutes of (a) New South Wales, (b) Victoria, (c) Queensland and (d) the Australian Capital Territory require a unanimous verdict by a jury if a person is to be convicted of any offence on indictment.
(2) Is he able to say whether the statutes of (a) Western Australia, (b) South Australia, (c) Tasmania, and (d) the Northern Territory permit a majority verdict.

(3) In Cheatle v. The Queen did the High Court of Australia unanimously allow appeals from the Supreme Court of South Australia because the appellants had been convicted of offences against the laws of the Commonwealth by majority verdicts.
(4) Which States and Territories intervened in Cheatle v The Queen to (a) support and (b) oppose majority verdicts.
(5) Did the High Court hand down its ruling on 3 June 1993 and unanimous reasons on 26 August 1993.

(6) How many persons were in prison on (a) 3 June 1993 and (b) 26 August 1993 for federal offences following majority verdicts in (i) Western Australia, (ii) South Australia, (iii) Tasmania and (iv) the Northern Territory.
(7) How many persons are awaiting trial for federal offences in (a) Western Australia, (b) South Australia, (c) Tasmania and (d) the Northern Territory.
(8) How many persons are awaiting joint trial for federal and State offences in (a) Western Australia, (b) South Australia, (c) Tasmania and (d) the Northern Territory.

(9) How many persons have been acquitted of federal offences in recent years in (a) New South Wales, (b) Victoria, (c) Queensland and (d) the Australian Capital Territory because juries were not unanimous.

(10) On 10 August 1993, did the Attorney-General of Victoria give the first reading of a Juries (Amendment) Bill which, if enacted, would purport to permit majority verdicts in trials for either federal or State offences.

(11) Is he able to say whether, on 26 August 1993, a report was tabled in the Parliament of Queensland from the Hon. W. J. Carter, QC, on the selection of the jury in the trial of Sir Johannes Bjelke-Petersen.
(12) Is he able to say what jury laws have hitherto applied in the Territories other than the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory.
(13) How soon can the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General consider coordinated federal, State and Territory jury laws and practices.
(14) How soon can fresh consideration be given to the recommendations on jury laws by the Australian Constitutional Convention and the Constitutional Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am advised that, as at 17 September 1993, there are no statutory provisions in any of these jurisdictions which expressly require a unanimous jury verdict in order for a person to be convicted of any offence on indictment.

(2) I am advised that statutory provision has been made for majority verdicts in Western Australia, South Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory. See, for example, section 41 of the Juries Act 1957(WA), section 57 of the Juries Act 1927(SA), section 48(2) of the Jury Act 1899(Tas) and section 368 of the Criminal Code (NT).

(3) I am advised that both the appellants in Cheatle v. The Queen had been convicted by majority verdicts of the offence of conspiring to defraud the Commonwealth under section 86A of the Crimes Act 1914. The High Court unanimously allowed the appeal from the Supreme Court of South Australia because majority verdicts were found to be incompatible with section 80 of the Constitution.
(4) I am advised that:-
(a) South Australia, Tasmania, New South Wales and Victoria intervened in Cheatle v. The Queen to support majority verdicts. No Territories intervened to support majority verdicts.
(b) No States or Territories intervened to oppose majority verdicts.
(5) I am advised that the answer to this question is `Yes'.
(6) I am advised that the answer to this question is:-
(a)(iii)—0
(b)(iii)—0
(7) I am advised that, as at 17 September 1993, the answer to this question is:-
(8) I am advised that, as at 17 September 1993, no individuals are awaiting joint trial for federal and State offences in Western Australia, South Australia, Tasmania or the Northern Territory.

(9) I am advised that, in New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland and the Australian Capital Territory, the accused is not acquitted where the jury is unable to reach a unanimous verdict. Rather the accused will be remanded either in custody or on bail for a new trial. Whether the accused is retried is a matter to be determined by the relevant prosecuting authority. If the decision is made not to proceed with a re-trial, and accordingly a nolle prosequi is entered, the accused would not be regarded as a person who had been acquitted.

(10) I am advised that the answer to this question is `Yes'. However, due to the decision in Cheatle, the provisions allowing for majority verdicts cannot be applied to federal offences by the Judiciary Act 1903.
(11) I am advised that such a report was tabled in the Parliament of Queensland on 26 August 1993.
12) I am advised the following jury laws apply to criminal trials in the following Territories:—
(a) Jervis Bay Territory—the laws of the Australian Capital Territory.
(b) The Territory of Norfolk Island—the Juries Ordinance 1960 of the Territory which does not make any provision for, nor reference to, majority verdicts.

(c) The Territory of Cocos (Keeling) Islands—criminal trial by jury, abolished in 1955, was restored in 1989. As part of the Territory's legal regime, the courts of Western Australia now have jurisdiction and the jury laws of Western Australia will soon be applied. In the meantime, the common law applies (which requires unanimous verdicts).

(d) The Territory of Christmas Island—criminal trial by jury, abolished in 1958, was restored by the Juries Ordinance 1987 (C.I.). The Juries Ordinance makes no provision for majority verdicts, therefore, unanimous verdicts are required. The courts of Western Australia now have jurisdiction and the jury laws of Western Australia will soon be applied.
(e) The Coral Sea Islands Territory—the laws of Norfolk Island; the courts of Norfolk Island have jurisdiction in the Territory.
(f) The Territory of Ashmore and Cartier Islands—the laws of the Northern Territory.
(g) The Australian Antarctic Territory—the laws in force are those of the Jervis Bay Territory; that is, the laws of the Australian Capital Territory.
(h) The Territory of Heard and McDonald Island—the laws in force are those of the Jervis Bay Territory; that is, the laws of the Australian Capital Territory.

(13) It is not envisaged that the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General will take any immediate steps to consider co-ordinated federal, State and Territory jury laws and practices. There will be a monitoring period to gauge the effect of the decision in Cheatle before changes, if any, are sought.

(14) The recommendations on jury laws by the Australian Constitutional Convention and the Constitutional Commission will not be considered immediately. Again there will be a monitoring period to gauge the effect of the decision before the recommendations are considered.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services, upon notice, on 29 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What programs does the Office of Local Government offer to assist councils in developing regionally based strategies and countering high rates of unemployment.
(2) What does each program cost.
(3) What are the eligibility criteria for each program.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) While there are a number of programs administered in the Local Government and Urban Development Division primarily aimed at either assisting Councils to develop regionally based strategies (e.g. the Integrated Local Area Planning Program; and the Strengthening Local Economic Capacity Program) or in assisting with countering high rates of unemployment (e.g. the Local Capital Works Program (LCWP)) very few have both these objectives as their predominant aim. Development of area based strategies is intended to assist the employment situation of a region, but this is a longer term outcome rather than a result of the strategy development itself. The program which comes closest to both the objectives is the LCWP which provides funds to Local Government for construction of economic and social infrastructure of lasting value to the community in regions and local government areas with sustained higher than average unemployment.
(2) The total funds appropriated for LCWP in 1992-93 and 1993-94 were $347.678 million.
(3) LCWP projects were selected on the basis that they were:
(a) strategically important to economic and social development;
(b) involved high local content in terms of labour, goods and services; and
(c) had early commencement dates.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 20 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What sums have been or will be allocated to the Rural Adjustment Scheme (RAS) in (a) 1992-93, (b) 1993-94 and (c) 1994-95.

(b) Commonwealth funds of $157 million will be available for RAS assistance in 1993-94. This will be made up of Commonwealth payments to the States during the 1993-94 financial year of $52.3 million and Commonwealth funds previously provided to the States of $103.8 million.

(2) Page 3.172 of the 1993-94 Budget Paper Number 1 refers to an amount of $103.8 million in State reserves. These funds represent Commonwealth allocations to the States for RAS purposes in prior years that were surplus to their immediate requirements. State contributions to RAS in 1993-94 will be made in accordance with the agreement between the Commonwealth and the States.
(3) In July 1993 Commonwealth and State Ministers resolved that States without reserves will be provided with one month's working capital in advance to be acquitted monthly.
The funding arrangements now in place will ensure that the amount of reserves held by a State will be equivalent to at least one month's expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 21 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will the sugar industry package which was announced in February 1993 result in lower prices being paid to No. 1 Pool growers and higher prices to No. 2 Pool suppliers.
(2) Have No. 1 Pool growers been primarily responsible for the financing and development of industry infrastructure over many years.
(3) Will priority be given under the $40 million sugar industry infrastructure program to projects which compensate No. 1 Pool growers for their loss of income under the Government's sugar plan.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. As part of the Sugar Industry Package and so as to provide more appropriate market signals, achieve more rapid expansion of the industry, and in order to bring the No 2 pool price to world market price or better, the Queensland Government agreed to reduce the pool price differential from 12 percent to 10 percent in 1993, 8 percent in 1994, and 6 percent in both 1995 and 1996. The balance of the differential will be subject to a 1996 review of the arrangements under Queensland legislation.

(2) The raw sugar industry was responsible for financing the construction of industry infrastructure, ie the bulk terminals, in Queensland with funds drawn from pooled returns from sugar sales. In the report of the Sugar Industry Task Force, the Queensland Sugar Corporation is quoted as stating that "in general these funds were deducted from pool receipts before the prices for No 1 and No 2 pool sugar were calculated". The terminals are, however, nominally owned by the relevant port authorities.

The Sugar Industry Package acknowledges this industry contribution and the Commonwealth and Queensland Governments agreed, in principle, that ownership of bulk terminals would be transferred to the industry and managed as a whole. The mechanics of the transfer were to be determined following further consultation with the industry through the Queensland Sugar Industry Policy Council.

(3) The objective of the Sugar Industry Infrastructure Program is to provide funding for projects which will enhance the economic performance of the industry through industry expansion arising from increased area of sugar cane cultivation and/or enhanced yields, or through a reduction in costs associated with the production of sugar cane. Projects to be funded under the Program will be determined by myself and the Queensland Minister for Primary Industries, the Hon Ed Casey, MLA based on project selection criteria released on 14 July 1993.

The seven criteria cover the need for projects to be for infrastructure works; to be economically viable; ecologically sustainable and consistent with best land management practices; for the region to

ANSWER.PARA: be viable in the long term; and desirably for projects to be spread throughout the State, contain an appropriate industry financial contribution and provide some benefit to No 1 pool growers. Criteria number seven directly refers to the need to have some balance in project selection relative to the changes in pooling arrangements.
